mnemonics.meaning: See the cactus coming out of the ground? It's happy to see you!
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means proclaim.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means showy.

This is a post with signs on it. And on top is a winter marker, showing that if you go north it's winter up there. The signs say things like "Narnia ↑" and "Meridell ←" and "Bananaland →" so you know it's a signpost.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means wife.
In the trash is a weird looking fruit. Someone decided to abandon it here. Most people abandon fruit when it's misshapen. It's probably fine though...
mnemonics.reading: You reach into the trash, take out the abandoned fruit, and bite into it. OUCH! There's a key (き) inside, and you just bit into it. You abandon the fruit and stare intently at this key. It must be why the fruit was weird looking and abandoned in the trash... but what does it go to?! You dig through the trash and try the key on everything that's been abandoned in there.

mnemonics.meaning: Your ice wife is amazing. She's also terrible, because she's very cold and has many ice powers, but that's also part of what makes her amazing! Picture your amazing and terrible ice wife. She's floating in your backyard cackling and shooting ice all around.
mnemonics.reading: She turns her amazing gaze onto your saber (せい) and hits it with an ice beam. Woah! Instead of turning to ice or shattering, it steals her awful powers. Now your saber is amazing and terrible too! Now you're floating in the backyard cackling with your amazing wife as you use your terrible saber and freeze things with her!

mnemonics.meaning: Dig up a mole and you attain a mole status. You're always trying to attain a new level for yourself and now you get to be on the mole level! It's actually pretty easy to attain mole status. Just stand in a field. Wait for the ground to move under you and shove your hand in the earth. Blam! An achievement pops up above your head and you're there.
mnemonics.reading: Mole isn't enough, you want to attain sheep (し) status next. Everyone knows it goes human > mole> sheep. Now you need to stand in the field with the mole and get a sheep to come over. If you can attain two animal levels in one day you'll be a legend on the leaderboards.

mnemonics.meaning: Wipe your fingers on this table in winter to see what it was based on. The cold winter weathers cover the table in frost, and when you wipe it away, you can see traces of what the table was originally based on. All tables have to be based on something, even if it's just other tables that came before them. Imagine tracing your fingers over the table, the cold winter frost stinging them, as you reveal the secrets of this table and what it was based on.
mnemonics.reading: This particular table was based on Little Kyoto (きょ). Little buildings and temples, that sort of look like Little Kyoto. Problem is, it was made by a 子 (こ), so it's not very good. The buildings and temples are all very childlike. Like crayon drawn on a table.

mnemonics.meaning: On the insect signpost there is a single sign that says bee. This particular insect signpost points you to where the bee is.
mnemonics.reading: Thanks to the insect signpost you find the bee. You make it just in time to see the bee hatch (はち) from its egg. You got to see a single bee hatch! What a beautiful sight. Weird that a signpost points to it.

mnemonics.meaning: The leader of righteousness is the only one who can run this ceremony. Why? Because it's a very pure ceremony, and only those with an extremely righteous mind can run it. Have him run your ceremony for you. Think about why he is so righteous, then think about an extremely righteous ceremony.
mnemonics.reading: Sadly, the reason only the righteous can run this ceremony is because it's a punishment ceremony, where he pulls the cord to cut someone's head off via a guillotine (ぎ). *CHOP*

mnemonics.meaning: You climb up a mountain and a cliff in search of fire, but all you find is charcoal. You can make fire with the charcoal, but you were hoping to find fire itself. All that climbing for nothing. You’re angry that you could only find charcoal so you take the charcoal in your hands and you crush it atop the cliff on the mountain. Feel the charcoal breaking in your hands as the wind carries the charcoal dust off from the top of the cliff on the mountain.
mnemonics.reading: After crushing the charcoal, you decide to take advantage of your current location and lay out in the sun for a while to get a tan (たん). Instead of getting a tan though, you catch on fire. Oops. Imagine lying out in the sun next to the crushed charcoal, thinking you’re going to get tan. You’re very surprised when you actually catch on fire. Hot hot hot!

mnemonics.meaning: The clothes radical and the clothes kanji are exactly the same! Surprising!
mnemonics.reading: An eagle (い) sees a pile of your clothes and lays an egg (え) in them. The eagle’s egg needs a soft warm place to incubate, and your pile of clothes is the perfect place. Look at the eagle and her egg sitting atop your clothes. Every time you get close the eagle starts to screech at you fiercely. Screee! Screee!

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami carries a husband and his husband up into the sun where they conceal their centaur. The two husbands run a centaur farm, but the local government isn’t too pleased by this so they have to conceal their centaurs in the sun unless they want them to be confiscated by the government. Imagine the tsunami carrying the husbands and the centaur up into the sun. Hear the water gushing as they conceal the centaur up there. That tsunami is gigantic.
mnemonics.reading: What is it the husbands are going to conceal? Oh that’s right, a centaur (せん). They are concealing a centaur in the sun. How forgetful of you. Just make sure to remember there is a centaur up on that tsunami with the husbands. They need to conceal the centaur to keep it safe.

mnemonics.meaning: The leader gets a nice uniform for the sake of not wanting to look like a fake. The leader is a fake, he just doesn’t want to look like one. He’s not really a leader, but he thinks he should get an official-looking uniform for the sake of not looking like a fake. Look at this fake leader. See him scramble into a uniform. Does he look like a real leader? Or can you tell that he is a fake?
mnemonics.reading: Well, everyone found out he was a fake anyway, and now you're all going to use a guillotine (ぎ) to cut off his fake head. Watch as the guillotine comes down. You close your eyes for a second, and when you open them you see that the leader's body was a fake! Wait, where did he go?!

mnemonics.meaning: A fire in the rice paddy burns down the field. The rice paddy fire spreads out from the paddy and consumes the field next to it. This rice paddy fire has ravaged your entire farm! Look at this fire burning the rice paddy and the surrounding field. Smell burnt rice in the air as you see the flames dance before your eyes.
mnemonics.reading: Your rice paddy farm and field are on a cay. A cay is a small, sandy island, and since your farm is on fire, this cay has turned into a hot cay. Or as Mario would say, that’s one-a hot-a cay! (はたけ) Mama mia! Imagine running around this hot cay as you try to put out the fire in your field. The fire is ravaging the entire hot cay, so it takes you a while to put it out. Man those flames are hot. Also, this kanji can have the reading はた for the kun'yomi as well. If you learn the longer version (はたけ) it will be easier to just shave off a kana to remember the shorter version.

mnemonics.meaning: A Viking insect is a firefly. In the insect kingdom, the insect most resembling a Viking is undoubtedly the firefly. Imagine this little firefly blinking his firefly light as he flies around shouting a Viking warcry and brandishing an axe. Yaaaargh!
mnemonics.reading: The Viking firefly is attacking Hotaru (ほたる) Tomoe (alter ego of Sailor Saturn) because the Viking firefly hates the show Sailor Moon and everyone on it. Hotaru screams in terror as she is deathly afraid of fireflies, especially Viking ones. Hear Hotaru’s shrill scream as she runs away from the Viking firefly. If you don’t know what Hotaru Tomoe looks like, Google a picture of her to get a better visualization.

mnemonics.meaning: A gladiator turns his hand into a fist. A fist for punching other gladiators. Picture the gladiator squeezing his hand into a tight fist, raising it up and yelling.
mnemonics.reading: The gladiator's fist is now aimed at Ken (けん) the samurai. Little does the gladiator know, Ken knows the ways of the samurai and the gladiator. He slowly raises his own hands and turns them into fists. Ken and the gladiator clash! Fists fly! You've never seen hand-to-hand combat like this! You can hardly keep up!!

mnemonics.meaning: Everyone has a poop guy from their hometown. You know. That poop guy. And every single time you try to visit your hometown, poop guy is there making everyone uncomfortable and reminding you why you left in the first place. Picture the poop guy from your hometown. Picture him really vividly. The awkward, rude things he does. The way he smells. The way he makes you never want to come back.
mnemonics.reading: Your hometown is in きょうと which, unfortunately, means your poop guy is in きょうと too. Now every time you go back home he's there stinking everything up. Imagine all the wonderful things that exist in your hometown of きょうと. All the things you love to do and see. And now picture poop guy. Ruining it all with his poop hands.

mnemonics.meaning: The roof (hive) on a certain insect (a bee) is what protects all of the honey. Bees are a certain insect that build a roof around their honey.
mnemonics.reading: To get the honey out, you need to put on special mitts (みつ) so your hands don't get stung. Your thick mitts make it so the bees can't even sting your hands. Unfortunately, you are naked and only wearing mitts, what were you thinking?

mnemonics.meaning: This leader has two things that remind him of his humanity: his shoes, and his hat. These two things remind the leader of his humanity because humans are the only ones who wear shoes and hats. Reflect upon your own humanity. What does it mean to be human? Is it wearing shoes and hats? Probably.
mnemonics.reading: Another thing that reminds you and the leader about your humanity is wearing jeans (じん). Jeans are the go-to legwear for many people, and no one but humans wear them. Jeans are another great symbol of humanity. Are you wearing jeans right now? If so, rub them with your hands and say aloud “Oh, the humanity!” Or just imagine wearing jeans if you aren’t actually wearing them.

mnemonics.meaning: On this scooter is a child who's trying to show that his lineage is humble. All of the other children are going around in fancy cars or helicopters, but this one child wants to be a humble child of the people, so he scoots on a plebeian scooter. Picture this child scooting to his fancy, expensive university in a little suit. Compared to the other kids, his wheels are quite humble!
mnemonics.reading: This humble child is your son (そん). You don't want any child of yours flaunting his wealth and good standing in the faces of other people. You've taught them to be humble. You even bought your son this humble scooter and you really hope they don't grow up to be a selfish, spoiled kid this way.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a tiny leader on Wolverine’s forehead sitting on a stool and commanding his troops to invade Wolverine’s brain. These tiny soldiers are going to invade Wolverine’s body in an attempt to destroy him. The leader himself isn’t going to invade Wolverine’s brain, he’s just going to sit on the stool and supervise. Imagine the little leader sitting on Wolverine’s forehead as he shouts “Invade! Invade invade! Invade his brain and destroy the Wolverine!”
mnemonics.reading: Soon they realize that they cannot invade Wolverine through his head so they travel down to his leg and try to enter through his shin (しん). The little soldiers take a big knife and slice open Wolverine’s shin in order to invade his body. See the little soldiers slicing open Wolverine’s shin as Wolverine grunts in pain. Getting your leg cut open is not a comfortable thing, even for someone as manly as Wolverine.

mnemonics.meaning: Open your mouth. A tiger fell in there on some spikes! That's what you tell everybody, but when they look in your mouth there's nothing there. It's all a big lie! Of course there isn't a tiger in your mouth. And those spikes are just normal teeth. No matter how you look at it, you're saying a lie.
mnemonics.reading: Lie about spikes in your mouth and I'll put soap with spikes in it in your mouth to teach you a lesson. That's why I'm using uni soap (うそ). Now at least you're not lying about spikes being in your mouth.

mnemonics.meaning: Aside from gold there are a wide variety of other minerals as well. Think of the wide range of minerals there are that aren't gold. There are a lot.
mnemonics.reading: One person is trying to control all the minerals of the world. That person is Emperor こういち. Emperor こういち is getting all the minerals, and the 鋼, so he can take over all neighboring nations and force them into a subjugation of efficient kanji learning.

mnemonics.meaning: Your mouth proclaims "I am noisy and I am picky!" It keeps repeating this over and over to everyone you pass by. The townsfolk agree with your mouth, you are noisy and you are picky and you need to shut up.
mnemonics.reading: You are so noisy and picky that the townsfolk hired Ken (けん) the Samurai to shut you up. "Ken, your armor color is so last year. That squid you have is gross. Your sword is so gaudy. You talk like you're from the Edo Period, but it's Reiwa right now." Your noisy and picky self just goes off on Ken the Samurai. He skulks off, defeated by your noisy and picky words.

mnemonics.meaning: Your leader is also a director so you need to pay respects to him before you can start filming. He’s a huge big-shot and you don’t want to offend him by not paying the proper respects, so you make sure to bow every time you go on stage. Imagine bowing really really low as you walk on set. Don’t look him in the eye! He might get upset. Just do as you’re told!
mnemonics.reading: The name of the director is Ook Aga (うかが). Ook Aga is a caveman which is why everyone has to be really careful and make sure they pay respects to him. Ook Aga doesn’t know how to live in a civilized society so your phones and clothes scare him. You have to bow really low and respect what he says, moving slowly, so that he continues to direct you and won’t run away or hurt anyone. Imagine Ook Aga looking down on you and you bow, slowly walking onto the stage. Oh no, your cell phone is ringing. He’s grunting Ook Aga Ook Aga and looking around angrily. Quick, put it away and pay your respects harder!! Bow, BOW!

mnemonics.meaning: You decide to loiter next to the trash under the moon in winter so the moon's light will penetrate you. The sky is clearest in winter, and this spot next to the trash happens to get the most of it. Picture a single beam of moonlight penetrating through the winter sky, right onto the trash.
mnemonics.reading: You want the light to penetrate you, so you put your face in the way of the beam and it shoots clear through you. Your mouth fills with the taste of 鉄 (てつ). The clear, penetrating beam tastes exactly like iron, which is something you really weren't expecting. But now it's filling your entire mouth and you don't want it to stop.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami hits a bundle of geoducks, swirling around their weird shapes, and creating rapids! The rapids are so violent, some of the geoducks break out of the bundle and get washed into the shallows. Picture the bundle of geoducks getting smashed by the tsunami, breaking apart, and getting tossed around in the rapids.
mnemonics.reading: After being washed through the rapids and into the shallows, the living geoducks are screaming “Save (せ) me! Save me!” They need to be saved from the water, and you are the only one who can save them. You gotta run over and help them out. Imagine reaching into the shallows and saving the geoducks as they scream, “Save me! Save me!” into your ear.

mnemonics.meaning: Your mouth is showy so it makes everybody around you rowdy. Your mouth is showy because it's covered in grills and bright red lipstick. People get rowdy because you're a celebrity and your showy mouth is your signature look, and everyone's so excited to see your mouth in person.
mnemonics.reading: Everyone is getting rowdy so you get in your car (か) to escape. As you drive away in your car you flash that signature mouth at them one more time, and you can see them getting even more rowdy.

mnemonics.meaning: You're digging in the dirt when you find a tiger and a cactus. You keep digging until you realize that these are a part of some big ruins. They're the ruins of tiger and cactus statues. It looks like whoever used to live here worshiped tigers and cacti. Or maybe they ate them. But now their whole civilization is just ruins. Imagine looking through these ruins. Picture the broken tiger and cactus statues. Try to imagine the people who used to live here before it turned to ruins.
mnemonics.reading: Well, as it turns out, these are the ruins of Little Kyoto (きょ), the city that existed before the modern day one. And it looks like the citizens of Little Kyoto faced their end a long time ago. Picture the ruins of Little Kyoto. Try to imagine what it was like before the whole place fell apart. Maybe they would have lived on if they hadn't been doing things with sharp cacti and bitey tigers.

mnemonics.meaning: The alcohol you take a measurement most carefully of is sake. Sake is very important to the alcohol culture in Japan, so you must make sure to measure it out to the precise amount. Imagine this sake as you measure it out. Hear it pouring out of the bottle as you catch the whiff of sweet alcohol in the air.
mnemonics.reading: You know who enjoyed sake a lot? Chewbacca (ちゅう). He was always drinking, which is concerning when you think about all the driving he did. Imagine Chewbacca drinking sake all the time while Han Solo told him he needed to stop and get help, but Chewbacca just did his yell thing and drank more sake.

mnemonics.meaning: You find some fingers from long ago. They must have been set aside by their previous owners. They definitely weren't cut off or anything, someone just decided they didn't want them anymore and set them aside. What would have to happen for you to set aside your own fingers? Try to imagine it right now.
mnemonics.reading: I know why they set aside their fingers long ago, it's because there was no soap (そ). If you didn't have soap to clean your fingers you wouldn't want to keep them for very long... Think of all the things you do with your fingers. Now picture how they would look if you had never ever cleaned them with soap. Uhg, disgusting. You should just set them aside here, and find some new ones.

mnemonics.meaning: Something you say to someone you become attached to should be said with sincerity. You need to speak with sincerity when you say things to someone who will eventually become your significant other, for example. Imagine saying something with sincerity to someone you want to become important to you. Say something like, “I love you” out loud. Say it with the utmost sincerity.
mnemonics.reading: When you say something with complete, unabashed sincerity your special saber (せい) starts to pulse with the beating of your heart. It shows the person you want to become close to that you truly are sincere! Say, "I love you," again and watch your saber beating in time with your heart. If you weren't sincere it would fade and grow dull.

mnemonics.meaning: A tiger has legs that belong to a tiger. You know, a tiger has the legs of a tiger. This is common knowledge. Nothing new here. Look at the tiger running with his tiger legs. So majestic. So fierce.
mnemonics.reading: The tiger is using his legs to run away from the Torah (とら). This tiger is deathly afraid of religion, so a holy book like the Torah causes the tiger to run away. Imagine watching the tiger as it notices the Torah and then runs away. The tiger sounds as if it is screaming in terror as it flees from the proximity of the Torah.

mnemonics.meaning: The boat that oversees other boats, land, and people is usually a warship. They're the big boats that oversee everything around them. And if anyone steps out of line, a warship can take care of it. Picture a huge warship overseeing everything around it. It's big and kinda scary.
mnemonics.reading: This huge warship is run by Genghis Khan (かん), the famous warlord. Really, what did you expect? Who else is strong enough to captain a warship but him? Picture Genghis Khan aboard a monstrous warship. He's carefully watching the sea and land that he's conquered.

mnemonics.meaning: You use your fingers to dig through the trash in the light of the moon in winter because you're going through withdrawal. You need your fix and you need it now, so you're willing to freeze your fingers off digging through moonlit trash to get it. Imagine withdrawal this bad, that you're in the trash like this. Close your eyes and feel the cold, smell the stink.
mnemonics.reading: The withdrawal makes you withdraw a 鉄 (てつ) and try to eat it. The taste of the 鉄 fills your entire mouth. These withdrawals are turning you into an 鉄 eater. Ahhh!

mnemonics.meaning: Each tree needs its drum measurement done before you can say it's really made of wood. There are a lot of hoodlums out there that try to dress as trees and confuse people. So make sure you measure their drum before you cut one down or tell someone your secrets under it.
mnemonics.reading: If you're still not sure if the tree is really made of wood, just take out a small juice (じゅ) box and start drinking it. A wooden tree will show no interest in the juice box at all. However! A non-wood tree will be really thirsty from pretending to be a wood tree. It will start making sounds and moving and probably say, "Can I have a juice box, please?"

mnemonics.meaning: The wrap radical and the wrap kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: Think about being wrapped up, nice and warm and safe in your home (ほう). Home is where you wrap yourself in a blanket, in the warmth of the fireplace, in the arms of those you love.  Home is where the wrapped heart is.

mnemonics.meaning: Something you throw out and abandon has been sent to the realm of abandonment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the on'yomi for 投 when you learned 投資 a long time ago.

sentences: それが不法投棄になるとは知らなかったんです。
I didn’t know it would be unlawful dumping.

mnemonics.meaning: An aviation (航空) mother warship is a warship that is like mother to all the aviation things (the airplanes). They come home to their mother warship, which is an aircraft carrier.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その航空母艦は突然視界から消えたんです。
The aircraft carrier suddenly disappeared out my field of vision.

mnemonics.meaning: Penetrate the night and go on through to the morning. You were up all night and had a sleepless night aka all nighter.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 英語を徹夜で勉強するなんて、いかにもあの子らしいよね。
It’s just like her to study English all night.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of amazing? It's also amazing! Or terrible. This word can be both good and bad, it really depends on the context, because what is amazing is usually also a little awful. You know?
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The most amazing and terrible thing you've ever seen is Suit Godzilla (すご). Godzilla was wearing a nice suit (amazing!) but also destroying your home, your friends, and your family (terrible!).

sentences: 生後半年で話せるようになったなんて、凄い！
It's amazing that he was able to speak half a year after he was born!
雨、凄いですね。
The rain is awful, isn't it?
東大に受かったなんて、凄いじゃないですか！
That's wonderful that you got accepted by Tokyo University!

mnemonics.meaning: A mineral mountain is one that you should build a mine in, to get all those minerals.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 鉱山で働いてる時は、いつも背中に痛みがありました。
When I worked in a mine, I always had back pain.

mnemonics.meaning: It's obsolete so I'm going to abandon it. This is annulment. You are sending something to disposal.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 古いテレビの廃棄に支払うお金、五千円もあれば十分なんじゃないの？
5,000 yen should be enough to dispose of the old TV, shouldn’t it?

mnemonics.meaning: 原 is often tied to atomic things, as atoms are the origin of all things. If an atom explodes, you have yourself an atomic bomb.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 原爆のことを言ってるんじゃないよ。
I’m not talking about atomic bombs.

mnemonics.meaning: Your hand's turtle shell is the back of it (see you can make it shaped like a turtle shell if you try hard!). That's why this is the back of one's hand.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the respective vocab readings of 手 and 甲.

sentences: とても綺麗な手の甲を持っていることが彼女の自慢です。
She is proud that the backs of her hands are so beautiful.

mnemonics.meaning: The root that this is based on is the basis and grounds for my argument. Look, it goes all the way down to the root problem!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼が高所恐怖症だと思ったのには何か根拠があるんですか？
What basis is there for you to think that he has a fear of heights?

mnemonics.meaning: An army warship is a battleship. Did you sink it? Oh oh! You sunk my 軍艦!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 軍艦プラモの専門店を開く予定なんだよ。
I’m going to open a specialty shop for plastic battleship models.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: スズメ蜂に腕を刺され、大きく腫れ上がりました。
A hornet stung my arm and it got really swollen.

mnemonics.meaning: Some fake attire doesn't make you look fake, it makes you disappear. This fake attire is fake surroundings. So, if you're in a shrub, it's shrub attire. If you're in the darkness, it's dark attire. This is camouflage.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 伯父は、自社製品の表示を偽装して逮捕され、現在は刑務所にいます。
My uncle was arrested for disguising his products with false labels and is currently in prison.

mnemonics.meaning: Things of the charcoal element are made up of much carbon. Just look deep into the charcoal to see all the carbon in there.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 一酸化炭素と二酸化炭素の違いは何ですか？
What’s the difference between carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide?

mnemonics.meaning: A celebrate ceremony is a celebration.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just need to remember that 祝 is read as しゅう for this one and you'll be fine.

sentences: 封筒の表には「御祝儀」と自分の名前を、裏には金額を書いたよ。
I wrote "congratulations" and my name on the front of the envelope and the amount of money on the back.

mnemonics.meaning: A ceremony ceremony is a ceremony.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 昨夜我が家で生贄の儀式が行われた。
The sacrificial ritual was held in my house last night.

mnemonics.meaning: An again clothes room is a changing room. You get to change again, even after changing in the morning for the first time to leave your house. This can also be a locker room or a dressing room, so really anywhere you can change that's not your home, usually.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今更衣室であの女のロッカーを探しているところよ。
I’m in the dressing room looking for her locker now.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: I'm gonna put charcoal in your mouth. Whatchoo gonna do? Sue me (すみ)?

sentences: 彼の口車に乗って、炭をしこたま購入してしまった。
I ended up buying a lot of charcoal because of his cajoling.

mnemonics.meaning: A fist that's like a bone (hard) is a fist that's clenched and ready to punch, making this a clenched fist or knuckles, if you want to get even bonier about it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. But 拳 doesn't use the one you learned, it uses げん instead. Just imagine someone clenching their fist at you. You gulp and say げん instead of けん out of fear.

sentences: 父は、僕に拳骨を食らわせるふりをしました。
My dad pretended to hit me with his fists clenched.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: You pick up some clothes. Hmm, I'd like to wear these, you think. But, the shopkeeper comes up and says, in a really weird accent, "No, I'm afraid those are ころも clothes." ころも clothes? What is that? Oh... you find out this guy has a speech impediment and is trying to say "こども (子供) clothes." Try to say the word with him, but he keeps saying it wrong. You get frustrated and blurt out, "It's the key to not being nude (きぬ)!" This does the trick, he lets you have your ころも clothes and goes into the back room to cry.

sentences: 衣替えをするのって、とても面倒くさいと思うんだけど、どう思う？
I think dressing for the season is so tiresome, what do you think?

mnemonics.meaning: Clothes clothes are still clothes!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あなたが彼女の衣服を盗んだんですね。
You stole your girlfriend’s clothes, didn’t you?

mnemonics.meaning: A stone charcoal is charcoal shaped like a little stone. Or, maybe it's often found in stone. That's coal.
mnemonics.reading: This uses the on'yomi for both kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は、石炭ビジネスでの成功を自慢しました。
He boasted about his success in the coal business.

mnemonics.meaning: Charcoal mineral has been found! Time to dig a coal mine or coal pit to retrieve it!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: うーん。この炭鉱が閉山するってのは、本当に残念ですね。
Well, it is really disappointing that this coal mine is going to be closed.

mnemonics.meaning: If you dispatch what you think to the other person, you're thinking about them, and you're being nice. You're showing consideration, sympathy, and compassion for the other person.
mnemonics.reading: One reading comes from 思う, so that's all good. 遣り has a weird alternate reading, though (やり). To remember it, just think about how much consideration you're always showing. You're always like "Yah (や), yah, no, I totally understand. SOOO sad." /end sympathy/

sentences: 思い遣りのつもりだったのかもしれないけど、嘘なんてついてほしくなかった。
Maybe you did it out of consideration, but I didn't want you to lie.
思い遣りのカケラもない奴だと思っていたが、そんなことはなかった。
I had thought he was a man without a shred of compassion, but I was wrong.
こんなに臭い部屋でいつまでも待たせるなんて、あいつはなんて思い遣りのないやつなんだ。
It’s not very considerate of him to keep us waiting for so long in such a stinky room like this.

mnemonics.meaning: To conceal yourself in water, you'd better start diving and get under the water where it can conceal you!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: うちの妹は今年の夏に潜水士免許を取得したんだよ。
My sister got her diver’s license this summer.

mnemonics.meaning: An employment (雇用) someone is someone who gives you employment, aka an employer.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 雇用者に新しい電話番号を何度も教えてるのに、いっつも古い方の番号に掛けてくるんだよな。
I’ve told my new phone number to my employer over and over again, but he always calls me at the old number.

mnemonics.meaning: Something really terrible causing mass extinction will be extremely gruesome. It will also probably be extremely violent, so don't look.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

sentences: 殺人現場は凄絶だった。
The murder scene was extremely gruesome.
私の祖母は戦争を経験し、凄絶な時代を生きました。
My grandmother experienced a war and lived in an extremely fierce era.
たった今、世界の凄絶さを目にした気がした。
I feel like I just saw the extreme violence of this world with my own eyes.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  It turns out she is a fake. Your niece (にせ) was a robot this whole time, just pretending to be your niece. What is wrong with this world, where your niece can be an imitation niece. A 偽niece, if you will.

sentences: どうして俺が偽札を偽札じゃないということが皆の為になるのさ？
What benefit is there to telling everyone this forged document isn’t a forged document?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Stick this onto a type of crop, and you have a ____field or ____crop.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 私は、苺畑づたいにヨロヨロと歩いている老人を見かけました。
I saw an old man stumble along the strawberry field.

mnemonics.meaning: A rice paddy field. You'd think this would refer only to a rice field, but it actually refers to other types of fields too, making this word simply field. I guess that shows how important rice is, because if a field isn't growing rice, it ain't no field o' mine.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from what you learned with the kanji. 畑 uses the shorter はた reading that you learned.

sentences: 今時田畑を機械を使わずに耕すなんて、時間の無駄だよ。
Nowadays ploughing fields without any machinery is a waste of time.

mnemonics.meaning: When things get noisy and rowdy there's a good chance things will end in a fight.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 喧嘩しないでよ。
Stop fighting!
妖精同士の喧嘩って、見たことある？
Have you ever seen fairies fight?
夫婦喧嘩に第三者が口を挟んでくるなよ。
As a third party, don't butt in our spousal argument!

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 蛍の光は、誰にとっても見ていて心地の良いものです。
The glow of fireflies is pleasant for anyone who watches.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You make a fist. Why? Because she stole your corn on the cob. "Cob! She (こぶし) stole my cob!"

sentences: 彼は拳についた血をハンカチで拭いました。
He cleaned the blood off his fist with his handkerchief.

mnemonics.meaning: Let's create a fake. This fake we've created? It's a forgery.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 全く同じ日に、二種類の偽造紙幣が東京で出回り出しました。
Two kinds of fake bills started floating around in Tokyo on the very same day.

mnemonics.meaning: Tear off a one-sided piece. It's only one part, not all the parts. It's a fragment.
mnemonics.reading: The 破 reading is the one you learned, the 片 reading isn't one you've learned. Just think about how you're tearing off pieces of a hen (へん), one fragment at a time. Here little chicken, I want another feather from you please. *CAW*

sentences: 地面はガラスの破片だらけなので、気をつけて下さい。
The ground is covered with glass fragments, so be careful.

mnemonics.meaning: A fruit wood is what a fruit grows on (the wood of a fruit is a tree, dummy). That makes this word a fruit tree.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 果樹園での仕事は結構退屈です。
The job at the orchard is pretty boring.

mnemonics.meaning: A burial ceremony is known as a funeral.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 中村は、葬儀に一人で行くと言って聞かなかった。
Nakamura insisted on going to the funeral by himself.

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen how 岐阜 is "Gifu." Now make it a prefecture to make Gifu prefecture.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 岐阜県に行くには、電車の乗り換えが必要ですか？
Do I have to change trains to get to Gifu prefecture?

mnemonics.meaning: By circumstance this is your hometown. Not much to say other than it's your hometown and birthplace.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. While こきょう is the more common reading for this word, it can also be read as ふるさと, which is a native Japanese word that originally didn't have kanji. ふるさと is also common in hiragana.

sentences: 聞いたところによると、彼女、離婚後故郷に戻ったらしいぜ。
From what I’ve heard, she moved back to her hometown after the divorce.

mnemonics.meaning: Your hometown home village is the one that's your hometown. It's also your birthplace, where you were born.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 郷 is the one you learned, but the reading for 里 isn't the one you learned. To remember this reading, just think about how your birthplace is the place you were reared (り), and you really (り) miss the place.

sentences: 郷里を訪れるのはお金と時間の無駄です。
Visiting my hometown is a waste of time and money.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. That's honey, baby!

sentences: その熊は、蜜の入った瓶を五本、次々飲み干しました。
The bear swallowed five jars of the honey, one after the other.

mnemonics.meaning: A bee's honey is its honey, honey.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 彼女は私の蜂蜜プリンを一口味見しました。
She took a bite of my honey pudding.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

sentences: 私の一番好きな日本の諺は、「身を殺して仁を成す」です。
My favorite Japanese proverb is "sacrifice one’s life to do good."

mnemonics.meaning: Humanity and righteousness. This is your duty. This is humanity and justice.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 盗人には仁義はない。
There is no honor among thieves.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have modesty and are humble, then you are probably humble and have humility (and have modesty too, I guess).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その四十歳のGoogle社員は、自分の事を謙遜して「過去の遺物だ」なんて言っていたが、実際は全然そんなことないからね。
The 40-year-old Google worker was so humble that he called himself a relic from another age, which really isn’t true at all.

mnemonics.meaning: If it's certain that you will attain it, then it is inevitable. It is a foregone conclusion.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 子どもへの性教育はある時期では必至になると思うんですが、日本はそうした教育については通常どのように行われるんですか。
I think it’s necessary to teach kids sex education at some point, but how do people usually teach those things in Japan?

mnemonics.meaning: You invaded and damaged me. You are doing infringement on my territory. This is a violation of me.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 髭を禁止することは人権侵害です。
Banning facial hair is a human rights violation.

mnemonics.meaning: If you invade and enter that is an intrusion.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このコンピュータウィルスは、大晦日の夜に時計の針が12時を告げると、何千台ものパソコンに侵入をするんですよ。
This computer virus is going to penetrate thousands of computers at the stroke of midnight on the night of New Year’s Eve.

mnemonics.meaning: If you invade with aggression that's an invasion.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 奴らが山のてっぺんにある俺たちの村を侵攻しようとした時、敵陣が全員高山病に罹ってしまったのには笑えたよ。
It was funny that when they tried to invade our village high atop the mountain, the entire enemy camp got altitude sickness.

mnemonics.meaning: The iron mineral is iron ore.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: マイクラでたくさん鉄鉱石を採掘した。
I mined a bunch of iron ore in Minecraft.

mnemonics.meaning: If 躍る is "to leap" or "to jump," then this noun version will be jumping or leaping.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 躍る.

sentences: 私は小躍りして喜びました。
I jumped for joy.

mnemonics.meaning: Wrap up the street and take it away. I cut it apart with my kitchen knife (don't ask why this word comes from these kanji). Just imagine yourself using a kitchen knife to cut up the street so you can wrap it up and take it away.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 包丁を研いで二、三時間潰しました。
I killed a couple hours by sharpening my kitchen knife.

mnemonics.meaning: If lies puke (吐く) out of your mouth, you're a liar.
mnemonics.reading: This is a combination of the kun'yomi readings, one of which you haven't seen yet. You'll often see this word without the 吐 kanji, as in 嘘つき, but for now let's learn its kanji reading!  You can't just tell one lie, it always turns into two (つ). Kind of like a chip or pretzel, you can't just have one. With lies, you have to open your mouth for two more. And then two more.... and... well you get it.

sentences: ウソップは嘘吐きだ。
Usopp is a liar.
フグ子ちゃん、大嘘つきの彼氏がいて、よくケンカするんだって。
Apparently, Fuguko has a boyfriend who is a complete liar and they fight quite often.
その時代、嘘吐きは全員燃やされていた。
In that era, all liars were to be burned.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. A lie is a lie!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned with reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

sentences: 嘘ですよね？
It's not true, is it?
「嘘をつかない」は私のモットーです。
My motto is, "I will not tell a lie."
宝くじで1億円当たったなんて、嘘の話みたいで信じられない！
Saying you won 100 million yen in the lottery sounds like a lie, I can't believe that!

mnemonics.meaning: I have sincerity about my loyalty. That shows loyalty, right?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今振り返ってみると、ハチ公は絶対的な忠誠心を持ったいい犬だったよな。
Looking back, Hachiko was a dog that had absolute loyalty.

mnemonics.meaning: The thanks ceremony is the dance you do in life when it comes to your manners and courtesy to others. Also means etiquette.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本の礼儀作法について学んでいます。
I’m studying Japanese etiquette.

mnemonics.meaning: Set aside and put what you'll need to get the job done over there. These are the measures and steps we're taking to make sure things get done properly.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その生徒の今後の措置についてはどうお考えですか。
What do you think of the next steps for that student?

mnemonics.meaning: A mineral thing is a mineral.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: これは今までで最高の鉱物さ。これに敵うものはないね。
This is the best mineral I’ve ever seen. Nothing can match it.

mnemonics.meaning: The mineral business is the mining industry.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は鉱業の過去十年間を振り返りました。
He looked back on the past 10 years of the mining industry.

mnemonics.meaning: A warship squad is a naval fleet or an armada.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 敵の艦隊からもっと激しい抵抗があると思っていたので、なんだか拍子抜けです。
I expected stronger resistance from the enemy’s naval fleet, so I’m kind of disappointed.

mnemonics.meaning: You can guess this is an adjective from the い at the end. The meaning for the kanji is noisy and picky, so the adjective version is also noisy and picky. This type of noisy can be just about being noisy, like a group of turkeys. It can also be a ""picky"" sort of noisy, when someone is being particular in a vocal sort of way.
mnemonics.reading: My noisy mom has earned the nickname yak-a-Ma (やかま). "Yakka yakka yakka," is what my mom says about my life choices.

sentences: 「ああ、喧しい！だまれ！」
"Ahh, so loud. Shut up!"
喧しくてワニカニに集中できない。
It's so noisy I can't focus on WaniKani.
あいつは妖怪について喧しく質問してくるのでうざい。
That dude bugs me with so many Yokai related questions, he's so annoying.

mnemonics.meaning: A mineral stone is an ore / mineral.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of the kanji, you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: どんな鉱石でも、彼が触ると金に変わってしまうのさ。
Every mineral he touches turns to gold.

mnemonics.meaning: The evidence is based on something. What is it based on? This physical evidence. Ha ha! Guilty!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just need to remember that 拠 is using the こ reading you learned, not the きょ one. Just remember that you can never trust the word of a 子 (こ), so you always require them to provide physical evidence.

sentences: 私が不法侵入をしたという証拠はあるんですか。
Do you have any physical evidence that I trespassed?

mnemonics.meaning: Something based on points has a ranking, meaning you'll know where your position or location is, compared to everyone else.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 我々は生産拠点を海外に移します。
We are going to move our production bases overseas.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, actually!

sentences: 「沈む瀬あれば浮かぶ瀬あり」なんていう言い回しがあるのは知ってるけど、今はマジで沈んでるわ。
I know there’s a saying, "life has its ups and its downs," but right now I’m really down.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 甲斐 is "effect" or "worth." So, the "worth for being alive" is your reason for living. It gives life worth. It's your reason for living.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 甲斐 and 生き, so if you know those you may have a reason for living, or at least a reason for doing your kanji study.

sentences: ロッククライミングは私の生き甲斐です。
Rock climbing is what I live for.

mnemonics.meaning: If you bite into something bitter (twice!) you'll take your next bite reluctantly. Because who would want that much of something bitter? Not you.
mnemonics.reading: This is the kun'yomi reading twice. You learned this reading when you learned 渋い. If you remember that, you know this too!

sentences: 渋々自分がやったことを認めました。
I reluctantly admitted to the things I did.

mnemonics.meaning: I release and abandon my post. This is my resignation. This is my abandonment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は典型的な育児放棄をされた子どもで、孤児院で育ちました。
I was a typical neglected child who grew up in an orphanage.

mnemonics.meaning: The result (甲斐) of being your own gender shows your resourcefulness. Depending on your gender, certain things are harder than others, so your resourcefulness and competence will help you to overcome those hurdles.
mnemonics.reading: This word combines the word 甲斐 (that you already learned) with the on'yomi reading for 性. You know them both, just put them together!

sentences: どうしてあの甲斐性無しが彼女の愛を復活させることができたのか、全く理解できないね。
I really can’t understand how such an incompetent man like that was able to rekindle her love.

mnemonics.meaning: You know 手洗い, right? This is like that, but way more polite sounding. The meaning is still the same though: restroom, bathroom, toilet.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for the 御 is お, the rest is てあらい, even though the い isn't showing on the end. It gets pushed into the 洗い.

sentences: 何時までに御手洗からバスに戻らなくてはいけませんか？行列ができているので、遅れないか心配してるんですが。
How long before we have to be back to the bus from the bathroom? There is a long line, so I’m worried I’ll be late.

mnemonics.meaning: A fist gun is a small fistish sized gun that has some punch (because, you know, fist!). The gun I'm describing is a revolver, or a handgun.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は拳銃を派手なスパンコールで飾り付けしてみました。
I decorated my revolver with flashy sequins.

mnemonics.meaning: Obsolete ruins are places that are abandoned because nobody can run them anymore (due to being obsolete, or due to not having money, or due to whatever else). These things are ruins or abandoned buildings. People like to explore these, a lot.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 昨日廃墟で鬼ごっこをしたので、筋肉痛になりました。
I have muscle pain because I played tag in the abandoned building yesterday.

mnemonics.meaning: The rapids door is actually Seto, which is the name of a few different places in Japan. One of those places is where the famous earthenware Seto ware comes from 🍶
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 瀬戸内海の魚は美味しい。
Fish from the Seto Inland Sea is delicious.
赤西仁を瀬戸市で見たよ。
I saw Jin Akanishi in Seto City.
今日市場ですごくいい瀬戸物を見つけたんだよ。
I found really nice Seto ware at the market today.

mnemonics.meaning: The tall rapids are the shallows. I have no idea how this makes sense, but I suppose if the water is taller, it's not going to have as much rapids going on, meaning it's just shallows (but not too tall to become something else, like a lake, or whatever).
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 高い and the reading you learned for 瀬.

sentences: この川はこの辺りは高瀬になってるから、きっと足が底に着くと思うよ。
The river is pretty shallow around here, so I’m sure you’ll reach the bottom.

mnemonics.meaning: The bitter valley is a place known as Shibuya. This is a very famous area in Tokyo. Very busy too.
mnemonics.reading: The reading of 渋 comes from 渋い. The reading for 谷 is an exception. Just think about someone asking you if  Shibuya is cool. Your answer of course is "yah." (や)

sentences: 私はよく渋谷駅で外国人を見ます。
I usually see foreigners at Shibuya Station.

mnemonics.meaning: Cooked sake is slightly higher in alcohol content. This is shochu, which I'm guessing gets cooked in some way during its production.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 焼 and 酎 are the on'yomi readings, but you didn't learn the reading for 焼 yet. That's okay, because if you know the (also English) word Shochu, you'll be able to remember the reading for this one as well too.

sentences: この焼酎のもっと大きい瓶ってありますか。
Do you have a bigger bottle of this shochu?

mnemonics.meaning: Wrap and surround them. We are going to siege the enemy. This is encirclement around their base!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その建物はじきに警察に包囲されるでしょう。
The building will be surrounded by the police in a moment.

mnemonics.meaning: You have sincerity and you have truth. You are so sincere and honest and faithful, good friend.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は僕の誠実な友人だから、心配する必要は無いよ。絶対に取引から手を引いたりなんかしないさ。
He is my faithful friend, so don’t worry. He will never back out of the deal.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Sincerity and truth are so important to me that I always keep them inside my coat (まこと). That's where I keep everything that's dearest to me, and what could be more important that sincerity and truth? Where do you keep sincerity and truth? I bet your answer is "my coat" too.

sentences: この映画には武士の誠の姿が描かれています。
The film depicts the truth about samurai.
裁判官が彼の心神喪失による刑事責任能力の回避の申し立てを受け入れたことは、誠に遺憾です。
I’m sincerely upset that the judge accepted his plea of not guilty by reason of insanity.

mnemonics.meaning: The idea of sincerity is sincerity. It's also to have good faith in others.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 誠意のこもった説明が聞けたので、今回は彼女の言い分を聞いて上げることにしました。
After hearing her sincere explanation, I decided to give her the benefit of the doubt this time around.

mnemonics.meaning: 福祉 is welfare, 社会 is society. So, a society's welfare is social welfare.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 明日なら、家族の墓参りをした後に、その社会福祉施設に寄れなくもないよ。
I could stop by the social welfare facility after visiting my family’s graves tomorrow.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember 御免? This is a polite way to say it. It means sorry and I beg your pardon.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 御免. The addition is all kana.

sentences: 御免なさい。このＴシャツのMサイズは売り切れちゃったんです。
I’m sorry. We’re sold out of medium sizes for this T-shirt.

mnemonics.meaning: If 意識 is consciously, then what exists concealed in your mind is your subconscious.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 夢ってのは、僕たちの潜在意識を反映しているとよく言われるよね。
Dreams are often said to reflect our subconscious.

mnemonics.meaning: A conceal in the water warship is a submarine.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 多分あの潜水艦の中で片方のイヤリングを失くしてしまったの。
I probably lost my other earring while I was on the submarine.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have attained summer, that must mean you finished out with the previous season and are going into summer. This is the summer solstice.
mnemonics.reading: You didn't learn this reading of 夏 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help: Just think about how cute little geckos (げ) start to come out into the open during the summer solstice. It's too cold for them to be out in the open before that, so if you look outside at the right time, you'll see geckos popping out of the ground all over the place!

sentences: 父に夏至から11日目のことを何と呼ぶか知っているかと聞かれたので、得意気に「ハゲ症」って答えたんですけど、それって「ハゲ頭の症状」って意味になるみたいで。父は笑って、正しい答えは「半夏生」だよって教えてくれましたけどね。

My dad asked me if I knew what to call the eleventh day after the summer solstice, so I said triumphantly "hageshou," which literally means "baldness-symptom". He laughed and told me the correct answer was "hangeshou."

mnemonics.meaning: If you attain above it means you're up above everyone, and you're looking down on them. You have supremacy.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は名門大学を主席で卒業した頭のいい男性なんでしょうが、明らかに白人至上主義者なのでそこが嫌いなんですよ。
He may be a smart guy who graduated at the top of his class from an elite university, but he is obviously a white supremacist and I hate that.

mnemonics.meaning: A quick rapids is going to have swift currents.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 早い and the reading you learned for 瀬.

sentences: 小舟は早瀬で横転してしまいました。
The boat flipped over in the rapids.

mnemonics.meaning: Penetrate to the bottom. ALL the way to the bottom. Don't stop half way. This is thoroughness. This is completeness.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 底 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Thoroughness is important when you're making tater (てい) tots. Each tater has to be cut carefully into little pieces then smashed back together again. Don't even get me started on the completeness I feel when I finish and eat them. Mm.

sentences: 彼女は徹底した化粧を施さないと、外出することができません。
She can’t go out until she thoroughly applies her make-up.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 恐い虎の顔が描かれたお揃いのTシャツを着たカップルが、今目の前を腕を組みながら歩いています。
A couple in matching T-shirts that have scary tigers on them are walking arm in arm in front of me right now.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means abstain and the verb vocab version is to abstain as well!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already, good for you!

sentences: お酒を控えるなんてらしくないね。もしかして、妊娠したとか？
It’s not like you to abstain from alcohol. Unless maybe, are you pregnant?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means attain but the meaning of this verb is to arrive at. I suppose that's because if you attain something like enlightenment, you also arrive at that enlightenment as well. Thus, to arrive at.
mnemonics.reading: To arrive at enlightenment is to eat (いた) all the knowledge and understanding that you can. You are enlightened!

sentences: そういう訳で、あの化け物は今日に至るまで牢屋にぶちこまれることになったんですよ。
And that’s how the monster ended up behind bars to this very day.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means based on and the verb means to be due to. This is probably because when something is based off something, it does something else, which is due to what it was based on. It was caused by what it was based on.
mnemonics.reading: For example, yogurt is due to milk. If milk didn't exist, neither would yogurt.

sentences: 皆様のお力に拠って、成功することができました。感謝の気持ちをこめて、ベーコンをプレゼントさせて頂きます。
I was able to succeed because of everyone’s support. I’ll give you guys a lot of bacon in thanks.

mnemonics.meaning: The quit ceremony is when you quit and are ready to go somewhere, so you bow and then get going. That's why this verb is to bow.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本人はどうしてペコペコお辞儀ばっかりするんですか？
Why do Japanese people bow so often?

mnemonics.meaning: If 充電 is a recharge then the verb version is going to be to recharge or to charge a battery.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 充電.

sentences: 充電するのを忘れたから携帯の電源が切れて、目覚ましが鳴らなかったんだ。
I forgot to charge my battery and my cellphone died, so my alarm didn’t go off.

mnemonics.meaning: 埋める is "to bury." 合わせる is "to unify together." If you bury somebody in order to unify them with you, you're almost certainly trying to compensate for something.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 埋める and 合わせる. Combine them into one big happy word.

sentences: どうにかこの損失を埋め合わせることはできないだろうか。
Can’t we make up for this loss in some way or another?

mnemonics.meaning: If you do penetrate, sure, you can to penetrate. But, if you penetrate something you really get into it, like, you are going to devote oneself.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the one you learned with the kanji. Look out for the shortening on this one.

sentences: ギャンブルに徹する覚悟を決めました。
I am determined to devote myself to gambling.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 群れ is a flock? This is the verb version, and means to flock or to crowd together with a bunch of other people.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 群れ, so if you know that you can flock together the two memories in your brain.

sentences: どうして日本では、不良少年少女は、コンビニの前で群れる傾向があるんでしょうか。
I wonder why delinquent kids tend to hang out in front of the convenience stores in Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 埋める is "to bury." This verb is to get buried or to be buried. You know this because it's more rare (もれる) to get buried than it is for you to bury someone else. Really you can only get buried once, to be honest, because you're probably going to die.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 埋める.

sentences: 昨夜、雪が30cmも積もり、車が埋もれてしまいました。
The snow piled up 30 centimeters deep last night and my car got buried.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means pay respects but the verb is to inquire, to hear, or to visit. Basically this is a humble way to use any of these verbs. It's often used in a professional context.
mnemonics.reading: Excuse me, I'd like to inquire about you, kaga (うかが). You're asking questions about Chairman Kaga, the ruler over the Iron Chef kingdom.

sentences: 残って最後まで彼の話を伺いたいのは山々なんですが、残念ながらどうしても行かなくてはいけないんです。
I’d love to stay here and hear his whole speech, but unfortunately I have to go.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means invade and the verb vocab version means to invade as well!
mnemonics.reading: I'm going to invade your country, okay (おか)? Sorry about that, but everything will be okay when I'm done.

sentences: たくさんの人たちが、プライバシーを侵されたことに憤慨しています。
Many people are upset about their privacy being violated.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fake and the verb vocab version is similar, it means to lie or to cheat or to deceive.
mnemonics.reading: Someone tries to lie to you. You can't believe it. It's what (いつわ)??? You can't believe it.

sentences: 日本では「言わぬが花」だと聞いたので、日本にいる間中自分は口がきけないと偽りました。
I heard "silence is a virtue" in Japan, so I pretended that I was incapable of speech while I was there.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conceal, so if you conceal yourself and walk around you are going to lurk or you are going to lie dormant.
mnemonics.reading: He so (ひそ) hidden. Where you at?

sentences: ワニカニはあなたの部屋の片隅に潜んでいるかもしれませんよ。
The crabigator might be lurking in the corners of your room.

mnemonics.meaning: If you return to the hometown you are going to return to one's hometown.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 帰 is the on'yomi reading, which you haven't learned. Just think about how when you return to your hometown, you're going to need a key (き) to get into your old home, which you haven't been to in a long time.

sentences: ほとんどの博打打ちが思っているように、彼女も自分には天分があると思っていたんだが、結局あるポーカーのゲームで全財産を失って、帰郷するはめになったんだ。
Like most gamblers, she believed she had talent, but in the end she lost everything to a poker game and had to go back to her hometown.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wrap so the verb vocab version is to wrap.
mnemonics.reading: You never wrap things once, you always wrap them twice. And then you double that. It's a two two (つつ) wrapping technique. つつむ is the reading we want you to focus on, but it's good to know that 包む can be read as くるむ as well. くるむ is used when you wrap something up carefully and protectively, like a baby in a blanket. つつむ on the other hand, has broader use and is commonly used for wrapping things like presents.

sentences: 睡眠薬をビニールラップで包みました。
I wrapped up my sleeping pills with the plastic wrap.

mnemonics.meaning: A wood skin is tree bark. It's the wooden skin around trees.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その樹皮は食べられますか？
Is the bark edible?

mnemonics.meaning: If you plant wood you are doing tree planting, since only trees are made of wood.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 結婚の記念として、主人と私はメープルシュガーの木を植樹しました。
My husband and I planted a sugar maple to commemorate our marriage.

mnemonics.meaning: If you undress from clothes you are undressing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 脱衣する前に、鞄を脇へ置いたのは覚えています。
I remember I put my bag to the side before undressing.

mnemonics.meaning: A warship ship is a warship.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: いったいまたどうして艦船に住むことになったんですか？月々のお家賃はいくらぐらいですか。
How did you end up living in a warship? How much is the rent for this every month?

mnemonics.meaning: A wheat field is a wheat field or barley field
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the kun'yomi readings, but they're also the readings you learned with the kanji. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 麦畑が見えてきたとたんに、くしゃみが出始めました。
Once the wheat field came into view, I started sneezing.

mnemonics.meaning: If you are about to attain winter, then it's the winter solstice. Happy winter, everyone!
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 冬 is the on'yomi reading, and one you haven't learned before. You're going to want to think about how you are celebrating the winter solstice in one particular place, that place being とうきょう (とう). See the Tokyo landmarks around you, think that you are there on the winter solstice, and also think about the things you are doing to celebrate, here in Tokyo. Also, watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: どうして日本では冬至の日にカボチャを食べると良いというのですか？
Why do people say it’s good to eat squash on the winter solstice in Japan?

mnemonics.meaning: If you do a withdrawal of something it's like you're revolving back to how things originally were. This is a withdrawal or repeal. It's taking back something you said previously.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Look out for the shortened てつ.

sentences: ごめん。前言撤回するよ。
Sorry, I take back what I said.
部長から辞表の撤回を求められて困っています。
I'm in trouble because the manager is asking me to withdraw my resignation.
スト撤回の知らせがラインで回ってきた。
I got a LINE message about the repeal of the strike.

mnemonics.meaning: A withdrawal is something you do to remove something from the past. It is a withdrawal or removal of what you did or submitted before.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Look out for the shortened てつ.

sentences: 瓦礫の撤去に関するニュースをネットで読みました。
I read the news about removing rubble on the internet.

mnemonics.meaning: A withdrawal of soldiers is a withdrawal of troops.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Look out for the shortened てっ spot.

sentences: 私はその撤兵を恥じた事は一度もありません。
I never felt ashamed about the withdrawal of the troops.

mnemonics.meaning: You set aside these words specifically so you could get the wording right. Wording is important sometimes, like when you're trying to talk about something sensitive, or when you're writing a poem. Sometimes only certain words will do.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 君の詩の措辞が素晴らしいことに感動しました。
I was impressed that the wording of your poem was so beautiful.

mnemonics.meaning: The やり part is from やる which is "to do." So, if the effect (甲斐) is good to do, then it is worth doing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この仕事は、誰かのために役に立つことができるので、とてもやり甲斐があります。
This is a satisfying job for me because I can be useful to other people.

mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means bone.

This is a melon. Imagine a melon cut in half, and you're looking at its insides from the side. See those precious private melon parts? You're gonna keep those for yourself, because melons are delicious and not for sharing.
Look at this radical. Can you see it floating in space? Can you see the antennae and reflectors? That's because it's a satellite.
We already have a roof radical, so we're going to use the secondary kanji meaning for this radical. It's shop, remember?

You hit a tree with an axe so you can do some analysis on it. To do the analysis on the tree, a cross section needs to be obtained, so you must chop it in half with your axe. Imagine taking this axe in your hands and chopping away at this tree to do your analysis. Hear the chop chop chop as wood chips fly into your face.
mnemonics.reading: The person who is doing this analysis is very sexy (せき). Who is this sexy person? Why it’s you of course, you sexy beast. I love watching you do analysis on trees. It’s so sexy. Imagine yourself being sexy and doing tree analysis. What sort of sexy analysis moves can you think of? Oh yeah, so sexy.

mnemonics.meaning: Shoot a melon out of a bow and it will fly in a steep arc. Melons are too heavy to fly straight, after all. Imagine shooting a really heavy melon out of a bow. Watch it make an arc through the air. Trace the arc with your finger.
mnemonics.reading: Shooting melons in an arc is something little 子's (こ) love to do. It also helps that when they come down from the arc they smash all over the place. Imagine being a 子 and watching melons fly in arcs all over. Imagine a little 子 version of yourself giggling and clapping your hands with absolute glee.

mnemonics.meaning: The mole has a knife ready for your arrival. You get out of your airplane, you step on the ground and... ouch! You stepped right on the knife, and there's the mole, sticking it out of the ground. "I checked the schedule for your arrival!" it squeaks happily, and disappears. Welp, your arrival didn't go smoothly. You have a knife in your foot. I'm not sure what you did to make that mole hate you, but you'll have to be more careful next time.
mnemonics.reading: Your arrival to とうきょう is now ruined. And your next stop is now going to be an arrival at a とうきょう hospital to get this mole knife out. This certainly wasn't the type of arrival you were expecting when you bought your tickets to とうきょう.

mnemonics.meaning: For a car, the reason why it works is because its wheels spin on their axis. That is, they have axles. Imagine a car whose wheels don't turn on their axis. It has no axles. Not a car that will work too well.
mnemonics.reading: Your friend's car doesn't have axles, but he loves it anyway. He's all like, "Isn't this a cool car?" You reply: "Gee, cool" (じく) very sarcastically. You're super sarcastic about this, so feel the sarcasm inside of you when you imagine this.

mnemonics.meaning: If you take a thread and wrap up a bunch of it, so much it becomes a hill of thread, you're going to have a lot of thread. You can wrap some of that thread around other thread to create a much thicker thread. This thread is a cable. Imagine yourself twisting this hill of thread up to make thicker cables. They're strong!
mnemonics.reading: You use this cable to swing down from a building but you need to do it soon (つな)! You're being chased by some bad guys and they've almost caught you, so if you're gonna swing to safety with this cable, you need to do it soon. Gotta do it soon. Imagine swinging from this cable and feeling the wind in your hair.

mnemonics.meaning: When your fingers move like that, you know it's an omen of a challenge that will face you soon in the future. What kind of challenge is it? If you look closely at your fingers sometimes you can figure out the challenge that is to come based on their movements.
mnemonics.reading: In your finger, you see a challenge. And... if you look closely, you can see the fast movements of your fingers forming the outline of Mrs. Chou's (ちょう) face. Oh no, the challenge is going to be Mrs. Chou! Whenever you see an omen (radical), there's a good chance that Mrs. Chou will be a part of it. This is not a good sign.

mnemonics.meaning: You take a turkey and try to boil it but you char it instead. That's what happens when you throw meat into a pot on high with no water in there. You should know better than to try to boil something without water! Now what are you going to do with this raw, but charred turkey?!
mnemonics.reading: You're staring sadly at the charred turkey when you suddenly sense the Shougun (しょう) looming behind you. You were supposed to be cooking this turkey for him and now he looks really, really mad. The Shougun reaches down and bites a charred hunk off the turkey. He yells and spits it out. Why did he do that?! You have no idea but it looked nasty.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a flag near the exit, so you use your fingers to dig there. Most flags mark something, and this exit is pretty obvious, so there must be something under here. At least that's what you think to yourself as you dig. Imagine digging under the flag by the exit of your building with your bare fingers. The dirt is getting under your fingernails as you dig. It's getting on your knees. It's everywhere.
mnemonics.reading: You dig until you finally hit something. It's a bunch of buried old coots (くつ). They're in an underground room for old coots. One yells up at you, "Whatcha doing to our roof, ya whipper snapper?! Stop digging in our lawn!" You carefully un-dig the old coots and leave them to their old grumpy coot hole... basement... secret clubhouse? Whatever.

mnemonics.meaning: Take this thread and look at this part. Now look at this part! Now look at this part. You don't know where to look! Haha, I have distracted you! You don't know what part of the thread to look at. What a distraction.
mnemonics.reading: Despite how distracted you are, that was indeed a lot of fun (ふん). Imagine yourself really enjoying looking at parts of the thread. You don't know why it's so fun, but being derpy is exciting, I guess.

mnemonics.meaning: This bamboo can be whittled into an example of anything. See, here's a car. Here's a snake. I can make so many examples just with bamboo. It's amazing how fast this guy can whittle!
mnemonics.reading: One last example for you. Now I'm going to take this bamboo and whittle it into an example of Han (はん) Solo! Han Solo's bamboo example comes to life and runs off.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone's fingers touch your tongue and fasten it together. You can't talk. All you can do is make sad tongue-less sounds as you try to figure out who would fasten your tongue like this. Try to fasten your own tongue with your fingers right now. You probably can't do it, right? That's because your fingers are too big and your tongue is too slippery.
mnemonics.reading: Only one creature could use its fingers to fasten your tongue like this: cats (かつ). Cats are notorious for fastening tongues so that people can't speak. Haven't you ever heard the phrase, "Cat got your tongue?" In this case, many cats fastened your tongue. You should probably be nicer to cats from now on so this doesn't happen again.

mnemonics.meaning: Under the canopy, you use a tree for your floor. It also becomes your bed, because hey, what is a floor but the original bed? You lay it down, cut it into slats, and voila! A floor! And a bed!
mnemonics.reading: News of your amazing floor / bed spreads and reaches the Shougun (しょう), who wants to come see it. He's impressed, and asks you to build floor beds out of trees laying under this canopy in all of his buildings. This new floor + bed invention, along with your other accomplishments, have you being watched really closely by the Shougun now. He seems to be keeping an eye on you so he can swoop down and check out everything you do.

mnemonics.meaning: You use your fingers in a shop to grip what you want to buy. Imagine picking up a few different things in a shop. If something fits nicely in your grip: buy it. If it's too small or too big, put it back.
mnemonics.reading: You have a really strong grip thanks to acupuncture (あく)! All your fingers are primed for buying things. You can grip anything at a shop—pineapples, tires, even live turtles. All thanks to some well-placed needles. Acupuncture is great for strengthening your grip strength. If you do intense shopping (like I do) you should definitely consider it!

mnemonics.meaning: In the tree district of town you can buy a lot of tree products, including doors. With those doors, though, you always need hinges. Don't forget to buy a hinge. Your door purchase will hinge on your hinges.
mnemonics.reading: You buy an awesome hinge and try it out. Instead of working properly, it just falls apart and the door falls on you, crushing your lower body. You yell out (and you have to yell) "I'm GOING TO SUUUUEEE (すう) YOU!" Really lengthen out that "sue" because it's a long "suu" for the reading and that will help.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have fingers it's easy to hoist things above your head. If you don't have fingers, well, it's not so easy. Hoist the sails! Hoist the anchor! Hoist a baby! All of these situations are easier if you have a ton of working fingers. (The more the better.)
mnemonics.reading: Today, you have to hoist so much stuff. "Ah!" you say, "So much hoisting to do." Better get to it! Imagine hoisting things over and over again. Each time you spot a new thing that needs hoisting, you say "Ah! Something else to hoist!"

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami crashes into the sun (breaking it in half) and creating a different wing of the tsunami all together. This wing crashes down and creates a lagoon. The lagoon is beautiful! The water is hot (from hitting the sun) but it isn't so bright that you'll get a sunburn.
mnemonics.reading: This lagoon was created on purpose by a really angry dude and his catapult (かた). He wanted a nice place to lounge that's tropical, but not too bright. So he came up with a plan: use a giant catapult to send a tsunami into the sun! Now picture it all in slow motion.
