The catapult tosses the tsunami into the air, it smashes the sun, breaks off into a wing of nice, hot water, and finally splashes back to the earth into a beautiful, secluded lagoon.

mnemonics.meaning: There are flowers and hills in your front lawn. Your lawn is pretty big and it is covered with both flowers and hills. It’s very pretty. Imagine walking through your lawn and smelling all the flowers as you travel over the rolling hills. What a delightful lawn this is.
mnemonics.reading: You are the proud owner of a Shiba (しば) Inu, y’know, the Japanese dog? Well, this Shiba Inu of yours loves to run around in your lawn and through the flowers and over the hills. This is the perfect lawn for your Shiba. Look at your little Shiba running through the lawn all happy and elated. Hear him barking as he zooms up and down each hill.

mnemonics.meaning: If the moon is dry, it's good for your liver! Haha, get it? Because there's no moonshine to ruin your liver. Don't drink, kids. Imagine holding an empty bottle up to the moon and seeing it's completely dry. You pat your belly above where your liver is and say, "I guess you're safe tonight, liver."
mnemonics.reading: As you pat your liver suddenly a strange feeling bubbles up and the ghost of Genghis Khan (かん) comes out! Right out of your liver. Genghis Khan glares down at you, "You inherited my liver, and that means no moonshine for you. Protect your liver and don't drink, like me, Genghis Khan."

mnemonics.meaning: What do you eat if you’re wearing horns and surrounded by lanterns? Mochi (or sticky rice cakes) of course! Imagine yourself in the lantern light wearing horns and eating delicious mochi.
mnemonics.reading: The reading of mochi is mochi (もち). Yay! As long as you can remember the meaning of this kanji, you'll know the reading too.

mnemonics.meaning: Under the cross is a mouth and another mouth wearing special clothes because they're in mourning. Picture the cross looming overhead, people's mouths open so they can sob loudly, and everyone wearing the same color clothes (just picture whatever color works for your particular culture/religion combo).
mnemonics.reading: As the mourning continues, the soul (そう) of the dead person rises out of the cross. The soul looks around at all of the mourners and nods. Yes, your mourning has pleased it. If you aren't mourning enough, when the soul comes out of the person's body, it will get really mad. "What, I'm not worth a few tears? Really?" And then the soul will haunt you. So you better mourn like you mean it.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a thread hill, but the hill is a bit weird looking (take a look at the hill radical in this kanji). It's not any normal hill, it's a weird lumpy hill that isn't quite right. That's because it is a thread hill of netting, and parts of the nets have caught things, like fish and cats, so there's weird abnormal lumps in them. You'll need to differentiate this from 綱, which uses the same radicals (though 綱 has a real hill radical). Just remember that the weird "hill" has stuff caught in it because it is netting.
mnemonics.reading: There's so much netting that it's out of control. You decide to take your lawn mower to mow (もう) it all down. When you do this, it destroys your lawn mower, because who thought it was a good idea to use a lawn mower on netting? Your dumb idea. C'mon!

mnemonics.meaning: Even though you’ve old legs, you overcome your disability. These old legs of yours don’t work very well, but you overcome the odds and you run a marathon! Imagine running a marathon with your old legs to prove you can overcome anything. Feel your old legs cramping up as you try to overcome the marathon and finish the race.
mnemonics.reading: When you pass the finish line and finally overcome the limits of your old legs, someone hands you an ice cold Coke (こく) as a reward. Mmm, such a refreshing Coke. Filled with the jubilation of achievement from overcoming all odds, imagine the flavor of this cold Coke in your mouth. Fizzy and Coke flavored, it runs down your throat and into your tummy. Yum.

mnemonics.meaning: The tsunami that is white is the most scary tsunami of all. It doesn't come in and destroy everything. No, it comes in, goes inside your door, then stays at your place overnight, without even asking! Imagine the white tsunami knocking on your door, walking into your house, and then just laying down on your bed. You try to tell it to leave, but it's a tsunami, and it says it will be staying overnight thank you very much.
mnemonics.reading: Your cat walks up to the white tsunami that's staying overnight and decides it doesn't like it, so it hacks (はく) up a hairball on it. Even that doesn't get the tsunami to leave. See the hairball slowly sinking into the tsunami. The cat hacks up another one.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have one stool and another stool, you have a pair of stools. Look at this pair of stools. Look at it. Imagine being in front of this pair of stools. Picture yourself sitting on one stool, getting up, then sitting on the other. Repeat this process.
mnemonics.reading: This pair of stools shares a soul (そう). Even if you tried to separate them, they'd eventually find their way back together. It's the same with pairs of socks and pairs of people. Sometimes what looks like two things is really a perfect pair, with one soul. Meant to be together forever.

mnemonics.meaning: You walk up to a tree and put dynamite on it. Then you set it off. BOOM. It explodes, but doesn't do what you'd expect. Instead of blowing the tree up, it blasts a very beautiful pattern into the side of it as well as the ground around it. Think about what pattern it might be. Is it a checkered pattern? Something more complicated and beautiful? Whatever it is, think of something that really impresses you.
mnemonics.reading: The pattern is so beautiful that you want to put it on your garage (がら). So, you do. Imagine painting your garage with the pattern you imagined earlier.

mnemonics.meaning: Put an axe in your mouth with your fingers to express your philosophy. Your philosophy of putting weapons in your mouth. Everyone else seems to think it's a stupid philosophy, so you're showing them that it's not with actions! Imagine expressing your philosophy, your deepest thoughts and beliefs, by putting it in your mouth.
mnemonics.reading: Your philosophy on weapons in mouths means you're always tasting 鉄 (てつ). They say blood tastes like copper, well weapons taste like iron. Your philosophy and your way of life means everything tastes like 鉄 now, and you think everyone should be that way.

mnemonics.meaning: Use simultaneous jackhammers to perform the purification ritual. Two jackhammers running perfectly in sync will purify your body, mind, and soul! (And the ground around you that's being jackhammered.) Close your eyes and feel the purification begin. Try not to let the loud jackhammering sound bother you, just focus on the simultaneous vibrations cleansing you inside and out.
mnemonics.reading: This purification ritual is supposed to help you forget your cyborg (さい). It's been a while, but you can't seem to get it out of your head.  Hopefully this purification (or just the two jackhammers shaking your brain up like pudding) will get the memories of your cyborg to go away. You can't keep picturing it all the time like this.

mnemonics.meaning: You keep your substitute clothes in a sack. The clothes in the sack are just substitute clothes, so they only come out in emergencies. Look at this sack of substitute clothes. Imagine it filled with all the clothes you hardly ever wear. What kind of clothes would be inside this sack?
mnemonics.reading: You need your substitute clothes so you take out your substitute clothes sack. You open it up to grab your substitute clothes, only to find out that there is a ton of salmon roe inside your sack. Oh man, you forgot all about putting that in there. You yell: F**K ROE (ふくろ) because that roe destroyed all your clothes and made it nasty. Imagine how nasty it is in there. Also imagine how smelly it is. Feel angry about putting roe in your sack. Why would you even do that? Why would the roe do this to you, as well.

mnemonics.meaning: You grab a satellite with your fingers and shake it! You're an astronaut and it's your job. Don't worry, the satellite won't break or anything, it's strong for space travel. Just do as you're told and shake the sucker. Imagine being in space and shaking a satellite with your fingers.
mnemonics.reading: You need to shake it because this satellite is full of yogurt (よう). And you only like yogurt that's been well shook. And who can resist space yogurt? Huh? Anyone? Imagine shaking yogurt in space. Now imagine eating yogurt as it continues to shake (in space still)!

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami breaks your bones, not from hitting you, but from making the ground slippery. The water from the tsunami made all the sidewalks and stairs too slippery to walk on, but you tried anyway, slipped, and broke a couple bones. Imagine trying to get back up on the slippery ground. You've already broken a few bones, but you slip again, breaking a few more.
mnemonics.reading: As you struggle on the slippery ground you hear a loud yowling sound. You turn and see a bunch of stray cats (かつ) slipping and sliding too. They're coming right for you, uh oh! Picture the cats trying to walk on the slippery ground. Their legs keep spreading, so they try to jump, but that makes the slipping worse, and they go sliding forward and topple over their fluffy buns and onto your broken body. Now the cats are all perching on top of you and your broken bones as they try to avoid the slippery ground. It would be nice if they didn't have their claws out.

mnemonics.meaning: A servant secures a stool in the dirt so that it is a solid sitting device. If you just throw a stool on the ground it will flop over easily. But if you have a servant to dig it into the dirt a bit, it becomes nice and solid and safe for sitting! Picture two stools in your mind. One is solid, you want to sit on it. The other looks like the wind will knock it over. Don't sit on that!
mnemonics.reading: You need this stool to be extra solid because you're using it to test your new catapult (かた). If it isn't solid, when you launch it and yourself in the catapult, the stool might fall over, killing you both. And you don't want that, now do you? You better hope that catapult is solid too. If it isn't the whole thing will come apart when you try to launch yourself into the air.

mnemonics.meaning: To your car you take an axe. The sun has broken your car for good this time (you think). You're so angry at your car. You think this is permanent. Turns out, though, that it's not permanent. It's just like that temporarily. You did make it permanent by taking an axe to your car, though. Feel sad that you were the one to destroy your car for good, even though the sun messed it up temporarily.
mnemonics.reading: You were driving around in Zanzibar (ざん) when this happened, too, so now you're stuck in Zanzibar, a foreign place, and you have no idea what to do next. You should probably be worried about this situation.

mnemonics.meaning: Thread and vines alone are too weak to hold anything up. You need to twist them together to make them strong. Imagine twisting some threads and vines together. Feel them and twist the two tighter together.
mnemonics.reading: As you twist the thread and vines together, suddenly you feel a lump. You look down and see a cucumber (きゅう) twisted into it. It turns out those vines you were twisting were cucumber vines! Yum!

mnemonics.meaning: Flowers find their death in a river out in the wild. Flowers live on water, but this river drowns the flowers to death. The wild is a dangerous place. Imagine yourself out in the wild wilderness as you hear the flowers screaming until death takes them. The river is raging, there’s nothing you can do to help the flowers. The wild has claimed them.
mnemonics.reading: Ah (あ), the flowers in the wild have been claimed à la (あら) the great flood. Ah, you don’t think so? Well I do. Imagine this scene again, only imagine it like the wild flowers are experiencing their own great flood. Ah, those flowers are drowning to death à la everything that died in the Biblical flood.

mnemonics.meaning: A challenge for war? I accept this challenge. A challenge is always worth accepting!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ありえねえ！お前ってほんと、超天然キャラだよな。なんで蝉の鳴き真似に挑戦なんてしてるんだよ？
No way! You really are such an airhead! Why are you trying to mimic a cicada’s shrilling?

mnemonics.meaning: Fasten everything into one. All together in one batch or lump.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortened いち.

sentences: 日本では焼き菓子作りとか料理の計量方法が違うんだよね。いっそ世界中の計量方法が一括で同じだったらいいのにね。
In Japan they use a different method of measurement for baking sweets and cooking. I think it would be better to have one way of measuring throughout the world.

mnemonics.meaning: Take things apart into parts. Then, do analysis. This is analysis.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: それは先生の息の質の分析結果です。
That’s the result of the teacher’s breath quality analysis.

mnemonics.meaning: If you untie the analysis, you are really just doing analysis to the analysis, if you catch my drift.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は踊りながらそれを解析してみました。
I analyzed it while dancing.

mnemonics.meaning: A round arc is, well, the shape of an arc. It has that round shape to it, you know?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 父親は息子に円弧を描くように命令しました。
The father ordered his son to paint an arc.

mnemonics.meaning: At the arrival time you will arrive. This is your arrival.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本に到着した時、私はちょっとテンションが高すぎましたよね。
I was too hyper when I arrived in Japan, wasn’t I?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 地軸の延長が北方で天球と交わる点で会いましょう。
Let’s meet up at the intersection of the earth’s axis and the celestial sphere in the Arctic.

mnemonics.meaning: The middle of the axis is where the axis is, of course, but it's also where the pivot is too.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 昨日、珊瑚虫の中軸骨格を夢に見た。
Last night I had a dream about a coral insect’s axial skeleton.

mnemonics.meaning: The hinge axis of something is the axle or pivot. It's the axis where things hinge.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「ぐるぐるバット」は、おでこをバットの先に付けて、そのバットを枢軸としてぐるぐる回転した後に、誰が目的地まで速く辿り着けるかを競う遊びです。
"Guruguru-bat" is a game where you compete on how fast you can get to the goal after spinning around a bat with your forehead on the end of the bat.

mnemonics.meaning: A pair of eyeball mirrors - that's binoculars. Binoculars have mirrors in them to allow you to see through the pair of eye holes, which is how this word makes sense.
mnemonics.reading: The 鏡 part uses the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn. To remember this, just think about how when you look down binoculars, you see something strange (like a strange reading for 鏡). That strange thing you see through these fantastic binoculars is... tomorrow. Your binoculars are so strong that you can already see tomorrow, today (きょう)!

sentences: この双眼鏡の黒はありますか？
Do you have these binoculars in black?

mnemonics.meaning: I'm going to twist this bullet and turn it around on you. You're the one I'm going to blame, which is why my blame bullet is twisted back at you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この金融危機について、誰が糾弾されるべきだと思われますか？
Who do you think is to blame for this economic crisis?

mnemonics.meaning: The middle hinge is the center pivot point.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうしてそれが彼女の中枢神経系を刺激したの？
How could it stimulate her central nervous system?

mnemonics.meaning: It will pass through what you believe and run into some netting. Just think about how all these communications are passing through between people, and everyone believes everything that's being said. Netting this all up (all these communications!) leaves you with a communication network. What fun!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 時計が時刻を告げた瞬間、全ての通信網が途絶えました。
The moment the clock announced the time, all the communications networks stopped.

mnemonics.meaning: Distract me with a twist in what we're doing. Just imagine you're working on something. Then, you get distracted by a twist in whatever it is that you're working on. This little twist doesn't destroy everything, but it does cause a complication and confusion.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この問題をこれ以上紛糾させたくないんです。
I don’t want to complicate this problem any more.

mnemonics.meaning: Time to overcome the clothes of our enemies. They all wear the same kind of clothes (let's say blue clothes) so we know that if we overcome the blue coated people, we will have won. It will be a conquest!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 徐々にホームシックを克服していってます。
I’m slowly getting over my homesickness.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're overcome with brightness, you'll be able to see all the little fine detailed things.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 十年前の旧正月のことは、克明に覚えていますよ。
I have detailed memories of the Chinese New Year from ten years ago.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 不孝 is "disobedience to parents"? Well, someone who shows disobedience to parents is a disobedient child or an unfilial child.
mnemonics.reading: 不孝 is a reading you should know already. Add the もの reading for 者 and you have yourself a reading. Now go be obedient to your parents and keep studying your kanji.

sentences: 母に「不孝者」と呼ばれた。
My mother called me a "disobedient child."

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is round and slippery just moves around with no trouble at all. It is so effortless in how it slides around. It is also super smooth.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 英語で円滑なコミュニケーションを取るために、最も重要なことは何だと思いますか？
What do you think the most important things are to have a smooth conversation in English?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned as well!

sentences: もしその野菜が全部安全だというのなら、まず先に彼らがそれを食べて我々に範を垂れるべきだ。
If they say that those vegetables are all safe, they should set an example for us by eating them first.

mnemonics.meaning: Let's departure on our digging up of this site. It is more than just digging, we're going somewhere and learning new things with this dig. This is an excavation!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the 発 getting shortened.

sentences: 化石発掘のバイトをしてみませんか。楽しいですよ！
Would you like to do a part-time job in fossil excavation? It'll be fun!
この鉱山では三十年ほど前まで鉄鉱石が発掘できました。
Until about 30 years ago, iron ore could be found in this mine.
そのタレントはスター発掘オーディションで発掘されました。
The talent was discovered through a star search audition.
ある日、金を求めて穴を掘っていると、大量の古代ギリシャのお宝を発掘しました。
One day, he excavated a large number of old Greek treasures while digging for gold.

mnemonics.meaning: An imitation of an example is the exemplification of something. It is also a model of the example of what you're making.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 君を模範としよう。
I’ll follow your example.

mnemonics.meaning: Let's take a look at this example and surround it. This example shows the extent or scope of what we're doing, and the line that surrounds it shows how far that scope goes.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は守備範囲の広いセンターで、大活躍すると踏んでいたんだが、とんだお門違いだったよ。
I thought he was a wide-ranging center fielder and would play really well, but I was completely wrong.

mnemonics.meaning: You know how 孝行 is "filial piety," right? Well, this is basically the same thing. You're just showing said filial piety to your parents, which, of course, is what filial piety means. That makes this word mean filial piety.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 孝行 plus the kun'yomi of 親. Put them together and you'll become a good filial child.

sentences: 何か両親に親孝行してあげたいと思っています。
I think I want to do something to show my filial piety toward my parents.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You look at the floor. It's disgusting. Dirtiest and nastiest floor you've ever seen. You say yucka (ゆか) because it's covered in yucca (ゆか). Plus, it's all rotten.

sentences: 今日は床掃除をしなければならないの。
I'll have to clean floor today.
床に一匹のゴキブリがはっていた。
A cockroach was crawling on the floor.
テレビを見てる時は、大抵足を組みながら床に寝転がっています。
When I watch TV, I usually lay on the floor with my legs crossed.

mnemonics.meaning: The char point is the part you're looking at so hard it burns a little hole in it. Just imagine yourself looking at a single point so hard that it begins to smolder. This is the focal point or the focus.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 先生が顕微鏡の焦点の合わせ方について説明をしてくれていた時、私は上の空でした。
When our teacher explained how to focus the microscope, I was spacing out.

mnemonics.meaning: Please temporarily wait. Please wait for a little while. In a little while something will happen, but for a moment you'll have to sit still.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: For a little while, we're going to listen to shiba rock (しばらく). This is a form of rock and roll performed by shiba dogs. You should look up shiba inu puppy pictures if you haven't ever heard of shiba inus.

sentences: 暫くお待ち下さい。
Please wait for a moment.
暫くの間、旅に出ます。
I'll be traveling for a little while.
悪阻がひどくて、暫く全然家事ができてないんですよね。
I haven’t done any housework in a while because I have terrible morning sickness.

mnemonics.meaning: A purification location is the place where you perform purification on people. Who needs the most purification? The dead. Where do you purify them? In a funeral hall.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the on'yomi for 場 when you learned 入場 ages ago.

sentences: ちょうど斎場に到着するところです。
We’re about to arrive at the funeral hall.

mnemonics.meaning: A garbage (ゴミ) sack is a garbage sack or garbage bag.
mnemonics.reading: The word for sack (ふくろ) is rendaku'd, so be careful of that.

sentences: 駅員さんに、電車に自転車を持ち込む場合は、持ち運び用の袋の使用が義務づけられているって言われたんだけど、代わりにゴミ袋を使っちゃだめなのかなぁ。
The train station staff told me that I’m required to use a carrying case in order to take a bicycle onto the train, but I’m wondering if I could use a garbage bag for it.

mnemonics.meaning: Your grip power is your grip, or more specifically your grip strength or handgrip.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 自分の父親なんだから、善意に解釈してあげるべきよ。例えば、年を取って握力が弱っているせいで、あなたのビンテージのバカラのグラスを割っちゃったんだ、っていう風に。
He is your father so you should give him the benefit of the doubt. His grip has gotten worse with age and that’s why he dropped your vintage Baccarat crystal‎ glass.

mnemonics.meaning: A grip with your hand (onto another hand) is a handshake.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. With 手 just think back to other vocab words that use the on'yomi reading.

sentences: CDを買うと、オマケで握手券が二枚ついてきた。
I bought a CD that came with two handshake tickets as a bonus. (Handshake tickets are similar to meet and greet tickets.)

mnemonics.meaning: It hangs on an axis point. The axis opens up, and reveals a hanging scroll. This might take a little extra imagination, but I believe in you.
mnemonics.reading: For 掛 you'll want to think back to the word 掛ける, then shorten it and shove it into the kanji half way (the かけ part at least). For 軸 that's the reading you learned with the kanji, so at least you have that to work off of.

sentences: アヤに、掛軸のための絵を描いてもらいたいんです。
I want Aya to paint a picture for the hanging scroll.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have the ol' liver flame then you probably have hepatitis. AUGH! MY LIVER IS ON FIRE.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あのA型肝炎の患者は愛に飢えており、いつも医者や看護師の気を引こうとしている。
The hepatitis A patient is starving for love and always tries to get attention from the nurses and doctors.

mnemonics.meaning: A warm bed is a "hotbed."
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この公園は地元では犯罪の温床になっていることで知られているので、近づかない方がいいですよ。
This park is known as a breeding ground for criminal activity in this area, so you shouldn’t go near there.

mnemonics.meaning: What kills insects with one dose? That's an insecticide or a pesticide.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この農場では殺虫剤の使用は厳禁です。
The use of insecticides is strictly prohibited on this farm.
殺虫剤は人体に入ると危険です。
Pesticides are dangerous if they enter the human body.
蛍は昆虫なので、寒さや殺虫剤に弱い。
Because fireflies are insects, they are vulnerable to cold and insecticides.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 不孝 means "disobedience to parents. So, if you add parents to it, it just means the same thing. Just a longer version of the word, basically. This means lack of filial piety or disobedience to parents.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 不孝 is the one you learned. Then, add 親's reading (vocab) to it.

sentences: もう手遅れですが、私は本当に親不孝な息子でしたよ。
It’s already too late, but I was a really disobedient son.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 去年の夏、秋田県の八郎潟にバス釣りに行きました。
Last summer, I went bass fishing in Hachiro Lagoon in Akita prefecture.

mnemonics.meaning: The lawn grass is the lawn or the turf.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings, which you learned already!

sentences: この芝草が、芝草クッキーを緑色にしてくれるんです。
The turf in these turf cookies gives them their green color.

mnemonics.meaning: Your lawn of life is just your lawn. Of course it's alive, otherwise it wouldn't be a very good lawn.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 芝 is the one you learned with the kanji. The reading for 生 is one you haven't seen before (exception). It's ふ, and you can remember it by thinking how you were such a fool (ふ) for putting all that poison on it. Now it's dying, and now it's becoming less of a lawn.

sentences: この公園では、芝生の上を歩くのは禁止されています。
Walking on the lawn in this park is prohibited.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 芝に水は撒いてくれた？
Did you water the lawn for me?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Though, it also means chutzpah or courage (besides just being liver). Maybe your liver is where your courage is.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Your liver isn't doing great. You have cancer in your liver, so now they're giving you chemo (きも) to help get rid of that cancer.

sentences: トイレに行く前に、鳥の肝をもう一口かじりました。
I took another bite of chicken liver before going to the bathroom.

mnemonics.meaning: The liver internal organ is your liver.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「もし世界中の食料が無くなって、お前がすっげぇお腹がすいてるとしたら、俺の肝臓、食べるか？」「さあ、どうだろう。」「さあ、どうだろうって、それ、どういう意味だよ。」「今は分かんないってこと。」
"If all the food in the world ran out and you were really hungry, would you eat my liver?" "Hmm, Dunno." "What do you mean you dunno?" "I just don’t know right now."

mnemonics.meaning: A lodge where you will stay overnight is lodging. It is where you will stay the night.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: まだ今夜の宿泊先を探しているんです。
I’m still searching for a lodging place for tonight.

mnemonics.meaning: You are mourning your fault. Because of your fault, you have gotten a loss and forfeit.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 介護施設に、どうやら記憶喪失らしいお婆さんがいるんだけど、その人がすっごく面白いのよ。
In the nursing home there is an old woman who seems to have lost her memory, but she is really funny.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. Mochi is mochi.
mnemonics.reading: If you know the meaning, you should be able to read this too. After all, mochi is mochi (もち)!

sentences: 私の親戚はみんな餅にマヨネーズをかけて食べます。
When eating mochi, all of my relatives put mayonnaise on it.
彼のスーツケースには餅しか入ってなかった。
His suitcase was filled with nothing but mochi.
お餅と緑茶のセットを頼みました。
I ordered the mochi and green tea set.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  What's the first two letters of the word mourning? It's mo (も). You can use that to remember.

sentences: 大変申し訳ありませんが、喪に服しているため年賀状が送れないのです。
I’m very sorry but I’m afraid I can’t send a New Year’s card because I’m in mourning.

mnemonics.meaning: The luck sack is a mystery bag. These are bags that are sold during the New Year's holiday. They contain various goods that are sold for a certain price. You don't know what's in them, but you know the minimum value of it at least. These are known as mystery sacks as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 福 and 袋, put together. Also, watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 元旦に、福袋を買う列に並ぶため、妹と私は朝の四時に起きました。
On New Year’s Day my sister and I woke up 4 a.m. to line up to buy Lucky Bags.

mnemonics.meaning: The country pattern is the pattern of things a country does. This is the national character of a nation.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of both kanji. 国 is くに and 柄 is the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: それぞれの国にはそれぞれのお国柄ってものがあって、私達はそれをお互いに尊重し合うべきだと思います。
Each country has their own national character and I think that’s something we should all respect.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  When it comes to nets, you gotta go talk to Amy (あみ) if you want a good one. Only Amy makes good nets.

sentences: うちの娘が虫取り網が欲しいと鼻を鳴らしてせがむもんだから、ついつい買ってあげたんだよ。
My daughter sucked up to me to get the butterfly net she wanted and I ended up buying one for her.

mnemonics.meaning: One overnight is a one night's stay.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortened 一 and the rendaku in this one.

sentences: ねぇ、そう堅いこと言わないでさ。うちに泊まってけばいいじゃん。たったの一泊だけだよ。
Come on! Don’t be so stiff. Stay over at my place! Just for one night!

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 透明 is "transparency" or "transparent" - so, if something is not transparent, then it is opaque, making this word opacity.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 不透明な窓がある女子の更衣室です。
This is the girls locker room, which has opaque windows.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the one used here. They're a pair, you know?

sentences: 妹と私は二卵性双生児ですが、外見がすごく似ています。
My sister and I are fraternal twins, but we look very similar.

mnemonics.meaning: The fasten arcs are arcs that go around something to fasten these things all together. What are these things? They are (parentheses) and [brackets].
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, watch out from the shortening.

sentences: 左の括弧を読む時は単に「括弧」と言いますが、右の括弧を読む時は「括弧閉じる」と言います。
When people read the left bracket, they just say "kakko," but when they read the right bracket, they say "kakko-tojiru," which means "close bracket."

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck. Follow that reading pattern to here, and you should be okay.

sentences: 彼女は私にヒョウ柄の名刺をくれました。
She gave me her leopard print business card.

mnemonics.meaning: A person's pattern is the pattern of actions which they take to become who they are. What do they usually do? What is their pattern? This is the same as their personal character or personality.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are both kun'yomi readings, combined. For 人 you'll just have to remember this. With 柄 that's the reading you learned anyways, so that makes things easier. Just keep it consistent!

sentences: 本の内容を表紙で判断するみたいに、人の人柄を見た目で決めつけないでよ。
Don’t judge people’s personalities by their appearance like you’d judge a book by its cover.

mnemonics.meaning: The philosophy study is the study of philosophy.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は哲学者だが、理路整然と考える人ではない。
He is a philosopher, but he isn’t a logical thinker.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 携帯 means "portable" or "cell phone" or "mobile phone." And then 電話 means "telephone." This is basically just the longer version of simply saying 携帯, making this a portable phone or cell phone or mobile phone. It's sort of like the difference between saying "my cell" and "my cell phone," you dig?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the readings of 携帯 and 電話 for this one.

sentences: 「あなたの携帯電話をお借りしてもいいですか？」「ええ、どうぞ。」
"May I use your cell phone?" "Sure, go ahead."

mnemonics.meaning: My challenge has made a departure and is being sent to the enemy. This challenge that I'm sending is a provocation to see if they'll take me up on my challenge.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 抗議者の一人が、警察を挑発するために火炎瓶を投げつけました。
A protester threw a Molotov cocktail toward the police during a riot to provoke them.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're going to abduct some noodles, make sure it's everybody's favorite noodles, ramen! The other meaning of the first kanji actually makes more sense here though, because you pull the dough to stretch it when you make ramen noodles. Choose whichever meaning helps you remember it best! This word is mostly written in kana, usually as ラーメン, but sometimes らーめん. You'll see the kanji version pretty often on packaging and menus, though, so it's worth knowing! The word is also occasionally written as らー麺.
mnemonics.reading: Both of these kanji take the on'yomi, but the first one has a slightly irregular reading, because it's based on the modern Chinese reading. To remember that it's a long らー, just think how excited you are about these ramen! Raaaaaa! Raaaamen! So exciting!

sentences: 鮭拉麺なんて初めて食べるよ。
This is my first time eating salmon ramen.
小さな会社が成長するのに必要なのは、拉麺です。
What small companies need in order to grow is ramen.
股間に拉麺の汁をこぼしてしまった。
I spilled ramen soup on my crotch.

mnemonics.meaning: Wake up from your bed and get up. You are rising or getting out of bed.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the on'yomi readings for both of these. For 起, just remember how in order to get up out of bed, you have to be let out of your chains, which requires a key (き). Otherwise, you stay laying down forever.

sentences: 彼は起床時間になっても、まだいびきをかいています。
He is still snoring even though it’s time to get out of bed.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji is cable but this word refers to more of a rope, which is pretty similar. This can also mean a sumo champion's belt, though you'll probably see that meaning a lot less, unless you're a huge sumo fan.
mnemonics.reading: The reading used here is the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: ロッククライミング中に落ちないように綱で体を固定しました。
I used a rope to hold myself in place so I wouldn't fall while rock climbing.
新しい横綱のための綱が出来上がった。
The sumo belt for a new sumo champion was completed.
二つの気球の間を綱渡りした男の人の話はもうお聞きになりましたか？
Have you heard of the guy who walked a tightrope between two hot air balloons?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. So, put that knowledge in a sack and move on to the next item.

sentences: 子どもが学校で使う用の袋を縫いました。
I sewed a bag for my kid to use at school.

mnemonics.meaning: A sacrifice fly is a sacrifice fly. In baseball, this is when you hit the ball in the air so the runner can tag up and move up a base.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the on'yomi readings. For 飛 just think about how he (ひ) hit a sacrifice fly, and he hit it so hard the ball heated up.

sentences: 野球用語の犠飛と犠打の意味について教えてもらえませんか？
Could you teach me what the SF and SH baseball terms mean?

mnemonics.meaning: If something moves then shakes, it is shaking and trembling!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女の自然な美しさと魅力的な笑顔に息も出来なくなり、会議中ずっと動揺していました。
Her natural beauty and charming smile took my breath away and I was trembling during the meeting.

mnemonics.meaning: A sick bed is a sickbed. If you're in that bed, you're probably sick.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は病床に臥してついにまた起ちません。
He laid down on his sickbed, never to rise again.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone built from a small pattern has a small build. I know lots of little old ladies that were built from these small patterns.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その店では、一人の小柄なおばあさんが買い物をしていた。
The short old woman did her shopping alone in the store.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of solid? It's solid, serious, upright, or hard. This word is often used in the figurative sense, as in a solid defence, a serious topic, or an upright person.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: この予想は、かなり堅いと思うよ。
I think this prediction is pretty solid.
やっぱり堅い職業の人は、書く文章も堅いね。
As I thought, people who have serious jobs write in a serious way.
レシピには、美味しくてしっとりしたクッキーって書いてあったのに、出来上がったクッキーはすっごく堅かったんだよね。
The recipe calls them delicious, moist cookies, but they turned out to be really hard.

mnemonics.meaning: If can you read this word, you may well know what it means. It's everybody's second favorite noodle dish, somen, or somen noodles, which are fine white noodles.
mnemonics.reading: The first kanji has a slightly irregular reading because it's prolonged. That's because somen are your soul (そう) food.

sentences: みんな冷たい素麺をツルツル食べ始めました。
Everyone started slurping down the cold somen.
最後に素麺を入れるのでスープの味は薄めになっています。
The taste of the soup is lighter because the somen noodles are added at the end.
マミさんが日本から持ってきた素麺を作ってくれた。
Mami made us somen that she'd brought from Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: 最新 is, as you can probably guess, "the newest." So, the newest sharp thing, is the cutting edge. It is state of the art.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: かつて、少し前までは、3Dプリンタは最新鋭の機械でした。
Once, a little while ago, 3D printers were cutting edge machines.

mnemonics.meaning: I write for purification. I do this purification writing in my study and den.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今日は一日中書斎で重要書類を探していたんですが、まだ見つからないんですよ。
I was searching for an important document in my study all day today, but haven’t found it yet.

mnemonics.meaning: I want to take the whole and fasten it together. Take all the parts and put it together in a synthesis and recap of the information.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は情報を総括し、上司の注意を促すために報告しましたが、彼は聞く耳を持ちませんでした。
I summed up the information and reported it to my boss, but he wouldn’t listen.

mnemonics.meaning: Temporarily determine something. That makes it tentative and temporary.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: こちらの料金設定は暫定的ですのでご留意下さいませ。
Please bear in mind that these prices are temporary.

mnemonics.meaning: A dry lagoon is a tidal flat.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 干 is an exceptional one. Just think to why the lagoon is dry. It's because of the heat (ひ) of the sun. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 交際一ヶ月記念の日に、干潟に潮干狩りに行ってきたの。
We went to a tidal flat to go clamming for the one month anniversary of our friendship.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means char, but the verb version is to be burned or to get burned. You're not doing the burning, of course, but you're getting burned (owch!).
mnemonics.reading: The times where you were burned were mostly when you were a kid (子). That's because kids aren't good at working with hot things.

sentences: 一定にかき混ぜることで、鍋の底が焦げることが防げるとお母さんが言っていたわ。
My mom told me that constant stirring keeps the bottom of the pan from burning.

mnemonics.meaning: If 吹く is "to blow" and 出す is "to remove," then you are removing your blowing. You need to begin to blow to do that!
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 吹く and 出す.

sentences: 俺の新しい髪型を見て、あいつプッと吹き出したんだぜ。失礼だよな。
She chuckled when she saw my new hairstyle. That’s rude, isn’t it?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji is wild and the verb is to be stormy or to be rough. If something is wild, like a storm or something, then it will be stormy and rough, after all.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 美容師として働いている限りは、手が荒れるのはどうしようもありません。
My hands will be rough as long as I’m a beauty artist, there’s nothing I can do about it.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a combination of the words 透ける and 通る. When you are transparent enough to pass through other things, you're still going to be transparent and people will be able to see through you.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女の手は透き通るほど白かった。
Her hand was so white it was almost transparent.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 吹く is "to blow" and that 飛ばす is "To let fly." So, if you use your blowing to let something fly, you are going to blow away it.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 吹く and 飛ばす, put together.

sentences: パーティーに行って、憂鬱なんて吹き飛ばしちゃおうぜ。
Let’s go to the party and brush off your depression.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 吹く is "to blow" and 込む is "to be crowded." So if you blow into something to the point where it's crowded, you are blowing into it, making this word "to blow in.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 吹く and 込む.

sentences: 家はおんぼろで、嵐が来る度に雨風が吹き込むのが現実です。
The reality is that the house is so old that the rain and wind blows in whenever a storm comes.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means challenge and the verb vocab version is to challenge someone.
mnemonics.reading: I don't (いど) just challenge anyone, but when I challenge someone, it's for real. My challenging reflexes come from my Id (いど), after all.

sentences: 私はこの日曜日、有名なベーコン鑑定家に挑みます。
I’m going to challenge the famous bacon connoisseur this Sunday.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dig and the verb vocab version is to dig.
mnemonics.reading: If you are going to dig you are going to end up making a hole (ほ).

sentences: クママンは中年の男やもめで、家業で金を掘っています。
Kumaman is a middle-aged, widower living and digging gold like his father before him.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dilute and the verb vocab version means to dilute or to water down.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 薄い, so if you know that you'll be able to read this too.

sentences: この味噌汁はしょっぱすぎるよ。もうちょっと薄めてもらってもいいかな？
This miso soup is too salty. Can you water down a little bit?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means distract and the verb vocab version of this word is to distract and to divert.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to divert and to distract Maggie (まぎ).

sentences: 不快な気分を紛らすために、裁縫針で耳にピアスの穴を開けました。
I pierced my ear with a sewing needle to distract myself from my unpleasant feelings.

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen 逃げる and 逃す. This one is 逃れる. This one simply means to escape. So that's not too bad. The difference between this one and the other escapes is that it has to do more with luck.
mnemonics.reading: This is the same reading you learned for 逃す, so you should be able to read this word as well.

sentences: 万が一ゾンビが実際に現れた場合を想定して、どうやってゾンビから逃れるのかを考えているんです。
I’m thinking about how to escape from zombies if they actually showed up.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means grip and the verb vocab version is to grasp.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You go to grasp someone. You really need them. You are soooo needy (にぎ). Except, you can't really pronounce "d" sounds very well, so you say にぎ.

sentences: おにぎりは、ご飯を握って作るので「お握り」と呼ばれています。
Since you make rice balls by pressing rice, it's called "onigiri."

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hoist. This strange word means to hoist, to fly, to raise, and (most importantly) to deep fry. The hoisting part usually has to do with hoisting or raising a flag, or something similar.
mnemonics.reading: Remember the other "to raise" vocabs? They are all あげる as well. For example, 上げる is あげる and 挙げる is あげる as well.

sentences: ちょうど今からトンカツを揚げるところです。
I’m just about to deep fry pork cutlets.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 逃げる means "to escape"? Well this verbs means to let go, to set free, or to let escape.
mnemonics.reading: You learned the に reading for this kanji when you learned 逃げる. If you have trouble telling the two words apart, remember that if you're going to let go of someone, make sure they have their knee guards (にが). It's a dangerous world, you can't have them running free without some extra protection, you know.

sentences: あの犯人を逃がすことはできない。
We can’t let the criminal escape.
この施設に捕らえられている人質を逃がすために潜入しました。
I've infiltrated this facility to set free the hostages who are being held here.
いいカモだったのに、逃がしちゃったね。
He was a real stitting duck, but we let him go.

mnemonics.meaning: To 駆ける is "to gallop." 回る is "to revolve." So if you're galloping around in a revolving fashion, you are going to run around.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 駆ける and 回る.

sentences: レシピにサフランがいるって書いてあったから、あちこち駆け回って探したんだけど見つからなくて、結局今回はサフランは使わなかったの。
The recipe said to put in saffron, so I ran around searching for it everywhere, but I couldn’t find any, so I didn’t add saffron this time.

mnemonics.meaning: 駆ける is "to gallop" and 込む is "to be crowded." If you gallop into someone and crowd them, you are going to rush into them.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 駆ける and 込む.

sentences: 終電に駆け込み乗車をしようとしましたが、目の前でドアが閉まりました。
I was rushing onto the last train, but the door closed before my eyes.

mnemonics.meaning: 駆ける is "to gallop" and 出す is "to remove." So if you gallop out to remove yourself you are probably going to rush out a little fast. Calm down and slow down, man!
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 駆ける and 出す.

sentences: 彼に質問を尋ねた時、駆け出しただけだ。
When I asked him a question he just ran off.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shake and the verb vocab is to shake.
mnemonics.reading: If everything starts to shake what else will shake along with it? You (ゆ), of course.

sentences: カヌーを揺らないで！
Don’t rock the canoe!

mnemonics.meaning: The east lawn isn't some eastern lawn, it's in reference to the company Toshiba. Might be better to look at the reading first for this one.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from the readings you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 東芝のお客様センターから届いたメールは、全文文字化けしていました。
The email from Toshiba’s customer center was all garbled.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means slippery and the verb vocab version is to slide or to slip.
mnemonics.reading: It wouldn't be so slippery in here if your friend Beth hadn't spilled something all over the floor. This is the third time you've slipped this month! You know what you have to do. You have to sue Beth (すべ)! She'll pay for making you slip and slide!

sentences: 雪解けは始まったけど、まだ滑りやすい場所もあるから気をつけてね。
Although the snow is starting to thaw, there are still some places where it’s easy to slip, so you should be careful.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means overnight and the verb vocab version is to stay the night.
mnemonics.reading: We are just going to stay tonight (と) and maybe tomorrow (と) tonight.

sentences: 今までで一番面白い最高傑作のお笑いのDVDを買ったんだけど、今日うちに泊まって一緒に観ない？
I bought a DVD of the funniest comedy skits ever, so why don’t you stay over and watch it with me tonight?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fasten and the verb vocab version is to fasten or to tie up or to tie together.
mnemonics.reading: You are fastening up the coocoo (くく) clock, so the coocoo bird doesn't come out anymore. That annoying coocoo bird.

sentences: どうしてこの文章を括弧で括ったんですか？
Why did you enclose this sentence in brackets?

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 口笛 is "whistling." So, if you're blowing your whistle you're going to whistle.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are of 口笛 and the reading you learned from 吹.

sentences: 口笛を吹くことにどんな魅力を感じますか。
What attracts you to whistling?

mnemonics.meaning: A mix of cars that pass through a net, that's a traffic network.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大地震が首都圏の交通網を麻痺させました。
A massive earthquake paralyzed the transportation network in and around Tokyo.

mnemonics.meaning: The cable pull. Both sides are pulling on the cable. That is a tug of war.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are from 綱 and 引く.

sentences: 綱引きは、日本と同じくらいアメリカでも人気がありますか？
Is tug of war as popular in America as it is in Japan?

mnemonics.meaning: The pair of children are the same as each other. They're twins.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is like 二人, (the ふた part) plus 子, combined together. A little weird, but makes sense. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 「男の子ですか？女の子ですか？」「実は双子の男の子なんです。」
"Is it a boy or a girl?" "They are actually twin boys."

mnemonics.meaning: Two overnights is a two night's stay.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 継母がうちに二泊泊めてくれって言ってるんだけど、どう思う？
My stepmother is asking if she can stay at our place for two nights, what do you think?

mnemonics.meaning: Unite something together and fasten it and you have unification or generalization. Nowadays this word is used to mean management in some contexts too.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 父は会社では100人の部下を統括する責任者です。
My father is responsible for unifying 100 subordinates at his company.
新しく入った統括マネージャーってあいつのこと？
Is that guy the new general manager?
俺たちはいつもリスク統括部の奴らとは意見が合わないんだよ。
We always disagree with the people in Risk Management.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of wild? It's wild or rough.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is one of the readings you've learned from the kanji. The あら one.

sentences: 私の初めての彼氏はいつも鼻が詰まっていて、電話をする時は息づかいが荒かったです。
My first boyfriend always had a stuffy nose and would breathe hard when we talked on the phone.

mnemonics.meaning: The "side cable." This doesn't make much sense. What this is, though (you'll want to look at the reading), is the Yokozuna. This is the Sumo Grand Champion.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 今は単なる凡人のように見えるかもしれないけど、こう見えてもかつては横綱だったんだよ。
I may look like just an ordinary man now, but I used to be a Sumo grand champion.

mnemonics.meaning: You know the animal radical. This is just like that with a little extra. It's an animal already... which means all you have to do is remember what kind of animal. In this case, it's a badger.
Stand up on the moon so you can look down on your countries. The thing with all the lines and borders are the borders of all the countries you rule, for you are an imperial.
You're sliding some dirt around with a tree you cut down. This contraption you've made is called a plow. Use it to push dirt around!

Imperial clothes allow you to perform an ancient attack that cannot be repelled. IMPERIAL ATTACK, GO! Imagine what this imperial attack might look like and imagine yourself in some swanky imperial clothes while you perform it.
mnemonics.reading: The attack's power is concentrated in the shoes (しゅう) in this imperial outfit. You attack with your feet, kicking the enemy with your old, fancy shoes. Picture the shoes as you attack, they glow—full of attack power! These +4 attack shoes are really special.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami can't resist the call of a bog. Whenever a tsunami is headed toward land, a bog will always call out to it, "Hey tsunami, don't you want to hit me with your water? Come this way~" Close your eyes and hear the bog's tempting call.
mnemonics.reading: As you listen to the bog's call you realize it looks just like the Numa (ぬま) Numa guy in your mind. You open your eyes and it's just a bog. You close your eyes, and there he is. The Numa Numa guy. So that's what happened to him! If you're a youngun, just do a little Google and you'll be pretty pleased, I'm sure.

mnemonics.meaning: A good moon is a bright moon. Not just in terms of light, but in mood as well. Like, gee wiz, what a bright, happy moon. Picture the good, good bright moon. Shining and shimmering and smiling down at us on Earth.
mnemonics.reading: It's so bright that you can see all the roe (ろう) in the sea glowing and reflecting the light like stars. And the tiny baby fishies inside the roe are smiling brightly back up at the moon! Picture this scene like it's a Disney cartoon. The good moon is smiling brightly down at the roe which are smiling right back. They might even start singing a song!

mnemonics.meaning: Below the canopy of trees is a hand. The hand is just there to chafe against the trees. There's a hand just chafing against some trees. That's... interesting.
mnemonics.reading: As the hand chafes on the trees, it says mama (ま), mama. This is the hand of a child looking for its mama. And, it chafes against trees to try and find the warm, soft touch of its mama. Instead, it only finds rough bark, so it continues its chafing.

mnemonics.meaning: You have to run, put your ear on the stool, then run back. That's the charm of this game. Imagine yourself playing this game and basking in the charm of tapping your ear on the stool.
mnemonics.reading: The added charm of this game is that there's this big chute (しゅ) at the end. It's so charming because you love chutes.  As you watch, you really see the charm of this game. Some people are throwing the stool down the chute, some people are sliding down it on their ears...how charming.

mnemonics.meaning: The loitering mountain king who hangs around during winter to provide an indication (this kanji uses the "indication" kanji as its top 2/3rds) of things to come now looks into your heart, and only sees bad things. So, he chastises you about it. "What's in your heart is no good," he chastises you.
mnemonics.reading: Why is he chastising you, really, though? He foretold Mrs. Chou coming back in a previous mnemonic, but you saved Mrs. Chou on the beach (once again, in a previous mnemonic), so you could have prevented her second coming. He is chastising you for saving Mrs. Chou (ちょう). In the 潮 kanji you saved Mrs. Chou from dying, so he is chastising you for it.

mnemonics.meaning: We put a flag to remember where we tried to use a jackhammer to measure your friend's heart. Granted, it was a terrible idea, but hopefully that flag of remembrance is some kind of consolation? Obviously it's not good enough consolation. Be furious about this.
mnemonics.reading: Even though you weren't happy with the flag, you were even more frustrated to watch an eagle (い) swoop down and grab the flag and fly away with it. Now you have absolutely nothing. Not even a consolation flag.

mnemonics.meaning: A badger, at the root of its heart, is a courteous creature. They may seem gruff and rude at first, but they'll still let you in their home in the middle of winter unannounced and offer you tea, a warm fire, and a place to sleep.
mnemonics.reading: Badgers are especially courteous to condors (こん). Condors live in the trees while badgers live in burrows under those trees. When humans tear down the condor's homes, the badgers who live below them always let them stay over until they get back on their feet. Picture a courteous badger taking care of an injured, and now homeless, condor. It's fluffing the condor's pillows, bringing it soup, and patting it on the shoulder saying, "There, there."

mnemonics.meaning: A bamboo stalk looks the same as a big ol' cylinder. Compare the two things in your mind and make them the same.
mnemonics.reading: Picture a cylinder shaped とうきょう. All the buildings are cylinders. The city itself is cylinder shaped too. Even... gasp! The people of とうきょう! とうきょう is a really weird city now that they passed the cylinder law. Imagine it so deeply that it weirds you out.

mnemonics.meaning: Hit by a tsunami the drunkard is propelled down a slide where he hits the ground which is covered in fire. He is immediately destroyed. Even if he wasn't saved by the slide (to avoid the tsunami) he would be in trouble. Seems like the world just wanted to destroy this drunkard.
mnemonics.reading: One could say this drunkard met (めつ) his fate.  Strangely, he just came from a Mets (めつ) game, so maybe that's why he had such bad luck.

mnemonics.meaning: A foot on a giant is a pretty long distance for a normal person to walk. Giants have big feet and can travel large distances very quickly. Compare the distance you can travel with one step compared to a giant. It's a considerable difference in distance.
mnemonics.reading: Going to Little Kyoto (きょ) is a short distance for a giant but a long distance for you. Imagine walking the distance between where you are and the (possibly made up) Little Kyoto. Think about the distance.

mnemonics.meaning: People had to ride their bamboo plows long ago to enroll in things. There were no cars yet, so they would hitch a cow to their bamboo plow, and dig their way to the government office or school to enroll. Picture the little hut that passed for school long ago. All of the bamboo plows are parked around it, as the people enroll themselves and their kids up for classes.
mnemonics.reading: If you enroll in something new people will find you very sexy (せき). This was true long ago too. There's nothing sexier than trying to improve yourself. Picture a line of people enrolling for new classes, sports, citizenship, etc. The moment they've enrolled they poof into the perfect, sexy person (in your eyes).

mnemonics.meaning: If the rain touches your foot and gives it a little rain kiss, you know that part of your foot is exposed to the elements. You can also see some dew forming on your exposed foot. So that's what rain kisses are! Ugh, you shouldn't have bought these open toed shoes, at least not during rainy season!
mnemonics.reading: You run along the road (ろ), trying to get out of the rain, but the road keeps going and going, with walls on both sides. You wonder how long this road will go. With exposed toes, your feet are going to get all wet with dew if you can't get off this blasted road.

mnemonics.meaning: A fire door is a door that leads to something full of fire. That thing is a furnace. Open the fire door and feel the heat of the furnace. Hot!
mnemonics.reading: You're using the furnace to melt tar to put on the road (ろ). Smell the tar baking from the furnace. Feel the heat from the furnace. Fix the road, while you're at it.

mnemonics.meaning: You've been ordered to spear this tree but you decide to be really gentle instead. Imagine gently poking the tree with your spear. You glance around nervously, hoping no one notices how easy on it you're being.
mnemonics.reading: You're being really gentle to the tree when a jewel (じゅう) falls out of its branches and hits you on the head. The jewel has a little note on it, "Thank you for being gentle." Did... did the tree just reward you for being gentle?!

mnemonics.meaning: You hold the roof of the festival up with your fingers but it grates on them. The roof is heavy, and you have to walk to keep up, so the roof is grating on them really, really badly. Have you ever been to a Japanese festival? There's always one of those portable shrines that are basically just roofs people hold up. That's what you're trying to hold with your fingers as the whole thing grates on them.
mnemonics.reading: Just when you thought the grating couldn't get worse, someone sat (さつ) down on the roof! AHG! It hurts! Picture a very large person that decided to sat down right on top of the roof you've been carrying through the festival. The weight makes the grating so much worse, you can feel the skin coming off of your fingers.

mnemonics.meaning: Two kings are here right now! We need to entertain them otherwise who knows what they'll do. Get out the harp, or the zither, or something. Imagine yourself playing a harp or a zither, even if you don't know how. Entertain these kings to the best of your ability, right now. That's why you're doing it and not someone who knows what they're doing. They want it now.
mnemonics.reading: You may already know that at a Japanese harp is called a こと, but here's a mnemonic to help you if you don't: When playing your harp, you always wear your coat (こと). Your harp playing is pretty bad, so you put your coat on just in case you need to leave in a hurry to escape an angry audience.

mnemonics.meaning: Look at the dirt on the ground at dawn and you'll be able to see all the hedges growing in the area really well. At any other time of day, hedges tend to blend into their surroundings. But at dawn, the shadows the sun makes really helps them stand out. This hedge also works as a fence. It borders an area and you can't walk through it. A natural fence! Picture yourself leaning over a balcony at dawn, looking at all the hedges appear and their shadows stretch over the ground.
mnemonics.reading: You're looking intently at one particular hedge because yesterday you dropped your car keys (かき) behind it. Now that you know where the hedge is you're going to need to search it to find your car keys. Imagine rooting around under some hedges, desperately trying to find your car keys. Hedges are prickly and there's spiders in here! If only you didn't need a car in the first place!

mnemonics.meaning: The root of a stamp is to get an instant picture down. Back in the olden days, people had to make seals and draw out things by hand, so stamps came about so you can—BAM—just stamp it and have what you want in an instant. Lots of things have roots from wanting to have something in an instant. Just think about instant ramen. The root of that was to get ramen real, real fast. Similar to stamps, ya know?
mnemonics.reading: Think about the thing you want to make instant. I'd want instant socks (そく)! Don't waste time searching for a matching pair or pulling them on. Just take out a pair of instant socks, add water, and the socks are already on your feet. In an instant! Imagine using instant socks. How do they feel? Soggy, but hey, it was fast!

mnemonics.meaning: A drunkard goes down a slide, hits the ground and bumps into a woman. Who is that woman? It's none other than her majesty. The problem is that you don't want to run into her majesty. That's a grave offense. Feel the fear that you're going to get your head lopped off from running into her.
mnemonics.reading: After you run into her majesty, her guardian eagle (い) swoops on you and pulls you off of her. Then it starts pecking at your eyes. Imagine fighting off an eagle trying to get at you.

mnemonics.meaning: A (fresh water) tsunami. Some horns. The ground. A bunch of poop. Combine these together and let them decompose a while. You'll have yourself some very nourishing soil. The stuff in horns is great for fertilizer. So is poop. So is water (as long as it's fresh water). So nourishing!
mnemonics.reading: This is the kind of nourishing soil that Jesus (じ) would make if he was into making soil, probably. Imagine him making soil made out of those things. Jesus approves of this nourishing soil.

mnemonics.meaning: A cow in the winter doesn't like to leave the barn to go to the pasture. It has to, though, because a cow's gotta eat. It's cold outside (it's winter after all). Imagine you having to herd all the cows out to pasture even though they don't want to leave the warm barn.
mnemonics.reading: ぼく is one of the common ways to say "I" in Japanese (which you should remember!). In this case, you're a boy... a cowboy, and you say, "ぼく will take these cows out to pasture!" Actually say that phrase out loud while thinking about bringing your cows to pasture.

mnemonics.meaning: The sound of spring water always puts you at peace. Everything from winter is melting and trickling and thawing. All the dripping sounds fill you with a peace you can barely describe.
mnemonics.reading: You want to feel this peace all the time, not just in spring, so you dip your tie (たい) in the spring water. Now your tie is making the peaceful dripping sounds you love. Imagine carefully dipping all of your ties in the peaceful spring waters and hearing that sweet sound you love at all times.

mnemonics.meaning: Take your spoon to the sun to be able to take a bite. It's delicious, you hear. That's the point of the spoon. Taste that delicious sun. It doesn't even burn!
mnemonics.reading: This delicious taste is... familiar somehow. You take a few more bites and then scream. It tastes like sheep (し)! You had your eyes closed because the sun is so bright. When you open them you realize the delicious sun you were eating is really just a giant, really bright, cooked sheep. You should probably point this out to NASA or something.

mnemonics.meaning: You take out a flag, lay a towel below it, and use your knife to carve the pattern through them both. Voila! This is exactly how old printing presses used to work. The old way of printing involved taking the pattern you want (the flag) pressing it against the place you want to print it (the towel) and then just slicing that sucker on there (with the knife).
mnemonics.reading: As you're working on printing your own flag onto this towel you look over and see someone else just sat (さつ) down on theirs. "Excuse me, where is your knife?" you ask. "Oh, this way is slower, but it's less work. I'm just pressing them together with my bum." I guess if you wanted to be slow you could do your printing if you sat down on it too...

mnemonics.meaning: The king's hat, not to mention the hair stuck to said hat, is incredibly rare. If you have your hands on either of these things, you'll be a rich duck. Imagine yourself holding a king's hat covered in his hair. Who will you sell it to? This is such a rare item!
mnemonics.reading: Then you look closer at the hat. It's about to get even rarer. Attached to the hair is the king's chin (ちん). Not sure how it got there, but you'll make a pretty penny from this. The king only had one chin, so that's about as rare as they come.

mnemonics.meaning: You need to make a measurement of an area so you take two clumps of dirt to seal in each side of your measuring tape, so it stays on the ground. This is the way people used to seal things back in the day, back when we didn't have fancy things like tape and glue. Picture sealing other things with dirt. Like the bricks in your wall. Or the hole in your floor. Dirt can seal in anything.
mnemonics.reading: You can also seal food (ふう) in dirt to make it last longer. That's how jerky came about, you know. Seal some meat underground and in a few months you'll have some tasty dried meats to chew. By the way, this has another reading you should probably know. It’s ほう. Most sealing is done in the home (ほう), you know? So just think about eating food in your own home! Dig up your sealed food and eat it in the comfort of your own home. Mm, delicious!

mnemonics.meaning: The simultaneous radical and the simultaneous kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: What simultaneously protects and kills? Your holy blue saber (せい). It's also simultaneously here and there at the same time. It moves really fast. And simultaneously glowing blue and white. Your saber is a lot of things all at once!

mnemonics.meaning: If a tsunami hits a pirate they are going to sink no matter how good of a pirate captain they are. Tsunamis are big. Pirates are small. Simple as that.
mnemonics.reading: As the tsunami comes to sink the pirate, the pirate holds his chin (ちん) up high. He will die with dignity. Imagine this dignified chin-holding-up-high pirate. Nod your head, because you know he got what he deserves.

mnemonics.meaning: Put your fingers in somebody's business by slapping them! This method also works if someone is getting too involved in your business. Slaps are basically your way of doing business with your fingers. Imagine giving someone a good, hard slap in the face. You're all up in their business now.
mnemonics.reading: ぼく is one way to say "I" in Japanese, usually used by dudes. But you're going to use it now when you slap this guy. Who's in everybody's business, slapping them? ぼく. Say that out loud, using ぼく. You're the boss, the boss of slap business.

mnemonics.meaning: When a yakuza takes a knife to clothes, it will of course cause a split or tear. It doesn't matter if it's a yakuza member or not. Any knife will cause a split or tear in clothes.
mnemonics.reading: "I want to split and tear that." You agree, so you say Let's (れつ) do it. Think of a thing you want to tear with your yakuza buddy. You're into it, so you agree and say "Ret's do it!"

mnemonics.meaning: A small tsunami comes in the morning with the moon. That just means the ocean gets bigger when the moon's out, and that my friends is simply the tide. The moon does affect the tides a bit, so you can imagine the tsunami as the water getting bigger whenever the moon is out. That's just the tide.
mnemonics.reading: You go check out the tide. The water is coming in a little stronger, and something washes up on the shore. It's a body! You roll the body over and it is Mrs. Chou (ちょう)! She wakes up and says, "If only you came at low tide then I would never have been saved!" She jumps up and runs off, yelling something about destroying the world.

mnemonics.meaning: This construction project made from shellfish will act as a tribute to the Crabigator. The Crabigator is a sea creature (maybe?), so making a tribute from shellfish makes some sense.
mnemonics.reading: This great tribute is being commissioned by Emperor こういち.  In his power, こういち has made a new religion around the Crabigator, to put the fear of kanji learning into his subjects. Hint: When you see 工 in a kanji it will often take the こう reading.

mnemonics.meaning: Who will say turkey? Who? WHO??? Say "who" over and over again, demanding someone says "turkey," for some reason.
mnemonics.reading: Then, someone says turkey. "Who said turkey? You? How dare (だれ) you." You're so mad at that person even though you demanded someone say turkey.

mnemonics.meaning: A sky attack is an air raid / air attack. Tora tora tora!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 僕が空を見上げると、ちょうど空襲が始まるところだった。
When I looked up at the sky, the air raid was just about to happen.

mnemonics.meaning: You learned another vocabulary word 札 as "amulet," but this is a special honorable amulet. It's a talisman.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for the 御 is お because ふだ uses the kun'yomi reading. Kun'yomi + kun'yomi = yes.

sentences: どうしてここに御札をはっているんですか？
Why did you put the talisman here?
これは、地元の神社でもらった御札です。
This is an amulet that I got from the shrine in my hometown.
英語圏の国にも、御札ってあるんですか？
Are there talismans in English-speaking countries, too?

mnemonics.meaning: A sphere of majesty, is the majesty someone has over a sphere, that sphere being a baseball, making this a pitcher's stuff, as in what he throws and how he throws it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 野球のシーズンが到来する春に近づくにつれて、あの投手の球威は益々増しています。
As it gets closer baseball season in spring, that pitcher gets better at his pitches.

mnemonics.meaning: If a 原子 is an atom and a 炉 is a furnace, what is a furnace that has atoms? It is an atomic reactor or nuclear reactor.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 原子炉の建設について、政府に忠告をした人もいました。
Some people warned the government against building nuclear reactors.

mnemonics.meaning: An attack attack is an attack or assault.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 警察の車は、暴走族に襲撃された。
A police car was attacked by a motorcycle gang.

mnemonics.meaning: The rights of the majesty are clear. His and Her Majesty have authority over all in the realm.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 権威を失ったのにまだ過去の栄光にしがみついていて、全く往生際が悪いったらありゃしないよ。
He's awfully persistent as he still clings to his faded glory even though he lost his authority.

mnemonics.meaning: This may look like a verb at first, but it's actually the adverb version of the adjective 凄い. When something is awful it's usually awfully awful.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You've learned this reading already, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ベトナムのコーヒー、凄く甘くて驚きました。
Vietnamese coffee was very sweet. I was surprised!
今日は、先生の気分が凄く悪くなったため授業が中止になった。
The teacher's health condition got awfully bad today, so class was canceled.
この長靴が凄く欲しいんだけど、Amazon Prime Nowでオーダーする価値あるかな？
I want these rain boots so bad. Do you think ordering them from Amazon Prime Now is worth it?

mnemonics.meaning: A 軍艦 is a battleship, and 島 is an island. Welcome to... Battleship Island (go Jurassic Park music).
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the on'yomi readings for 軍 and 艦, and the kun'yomi reading for 島. You learned all of them, so you should know the reading already! Oh, but watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: アイツはぜんぜん面白くないな。話題といったら軍艦島の都市伝説だけだし。
He isn’t interesting at all. All he talks about is the urban legend of Battleship Island.

mnemonics.meaning: A high furnace is one that's particularly hot and blasty. This is a blast furnace.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今朝の朝刊で、その鉄鋼会社は世界一大きな高炉の建設を計画していると読んだよ。
