I read in the newspaper this morning that the steel company is planning to build the world’s largest blast furnace.

mnemonics.meaning: A mud bog is a bog or marsh. Seems kind of redundant to call a bog muddy, but whatever.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the vocab readings of the two words, 泥 and 沼.

sentences: コスタリカの泥沼で、忍者トカゲとしても知られているバシリスクを見ました。
I saw some green basilisk lizards, known as Jesus lizards, in a marsh in Costa Rica.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, ぬま.

sentences: どっちにしろ沼に飛び込まなきゃいけないと思うしね。
I guess I have to jump into the swamp anyway.

mnemonics.meaning: The decision is split, causing a breakdown in all we've decided. A big ol' rupture.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの男は奴らの決裂を、牢屋の中で舌なめずりをしながら待っていたに違いない。
That guy must have eagerly waited out their breakdown from behind bars.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the na-adjective version of bright. The word is bright or cheerful.
mnemonics.reading: Of all the people who are bright and cheerful, one man comes to mind. The cheerful Hulk Hogan (ほが).

sentences: 朗らかな声をした知らない人から国際電話がかかってきました。
I got an international call from someone I didn’t know with a melodious voice.

mnemonics.meaning: A bright bright is something that's bright.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼はかつては明朗快活な青年だった。
He used to be a cheerful young man.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that you wrap is a bundle or package.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned it when you learned 包む, but here's a reminder of the mnemonic just in case: Remember how you wrap your bundles? That's right, with the two two technique. Your packages are always double wrapped.

sentences: 日付が変わる瞬間に包みを開けてもいい？
Is it okay if I open this package at the stroke of midnight?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.  This word covers a lot of meanings so it can be charm, taste, vibe, or even gist.
mnemonics.reading: If something has charm, your thought/思 (おも) goes in that direction/向き (むき).  You feel the vibe? Do you get the gist?

sentences: こんなに趣のあるお持ち帰り用の容器を見たのは初めてです。
I’ve never seen such a tasteful doggie bag before.

mnemonics.meaning: I would like to enroll into this country. This is citizenship.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本国籍がないんですが、司法試験を受験することは可能ですか？
I don’t have Japanese citizenship, but is it possible for me to take the bar examination?

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 慰謝 means "consolation?" Add fee to that and you get compensation. Or consolation money, depending on the situation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 慰謝料をよこせと脅されています。
They’re threatening us to send compensation.

mnemonics.meaning: The consolation of a problem is when I show my condolences. It is my sympathy call.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私達は毎週日曜日、セラピー犬たちと一緒に老人ホームを慰問します。
We visit a nursing home with therapy dogs every Sunday.

mnemonics.meaning: I show my consolation by apologizing. This is consolation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 保険会社から受け取る慰謝料は、税務署に申告する必要がありますか。
Do I have to declare the consolation money I receive from an insurance company to the revenue office?

mnemonics.meaning: The tribute I offer is my contribution.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうしてG20は財政支援への貢献を否認したのですか。
Why did G20 reject financially contributing to the bailout?

mnemonics.meaning: A reverse attack is a counterattack.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: パックマンは、追ってくるモンスターを逆襲して食べ始めた。
Pac-Man counterattacked and started eating the monsters that were chasing him.

mnemonics.meaning: A rare taste is a taste you can't have very often, because it's rare. This is a delicacy.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は痛風なのでビールを飲まない方がいいのは分かっているんですが、友人からビールに良く合う珍味をもらったので今日ばかりは我慢できませんね。
I have gout and I know I should avoid beer, but I can’t help drinking it today because my friend gave me some delicacies that go well with beer.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of delicious? It's delicious. It also means "skillful" and "clever" as well, because delicious things are skillfully delicious, right?
mnemonics.reading: What's especially delicious? Horse (うま) is delicious. Mmm, that delicious horse.

sentences: めっちゃ旨いお好み焼きの店見つけたから、今度一緒に行かへん？
I found a really delicious okonomiyaki restaurant, wanna go with me next time?

mnemonics.meaning: Extinction where everything is destroyed is destruction. It is extinction.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 全ての種の鯨が絶滅の危機に瀕している訳ではない。
Not all species of whales are endangered.

mnemonics.meaning: If you break and destroy something, that is destruction. That is annihilation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その都市は原爆により壊滅しました。
The city was annihilated by the atomic bomb.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi reading of the kanji, but you haven't learned it yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you: Dew is just the earth's way of giving water to you (つゆ). Rain is too forceful, you may not go to the ocean or a lake, so the earth gives dew to you by putting it on the grass outside your house everyday!

sentences: 葉っぱの上に乗っている露を集めているんだ。
I’m collecting dew that’s on the leaves.

mnemonics.meaning: Majesty is strict. If you don't have dignity and majesty, you won't be very majestic.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼はそれを威厳をもって言いました。
He said that with dignity.

mnemonics.meaning: I will chastise you and give you penalty. I do this as a discipline. A punishment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 違反者には懲罰が与えられる。
Violators will receive punishment.

mnemonics.meaning: Using violence I'm going to expose the truth! This is disclosure. This is exposure.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 暴 is strange and new, not what you learned with the kanji. Just think about how when there is disclosure or exposure of something, you are surprised. You can't believe that's the truth. You have to take a step back (ばく) to deal with the new information.

sentences: 暴露本の出版については現在再考中です。
I’m having second thoughts about publishing a tell-all book.

mnemonics.meaning: The illusion is destroyed. If your illusion is destroyed, that is disillusionment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼氏が道端で立ちションしてるのを見ちゃってさ。もう、完璧に幻滅した。
I saw my boyfriend taking a piss in the street and I was completely disillusioned.

mnemonics.meaning: The distance that is detached from the distance is the distance and range. Just think of one part of the distance, stretch it out, and then look at it. It shows the distance and range!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 年を取ったら長距離のフライトはきつくなるだろうね。
Long‐distance flights will be tough for me when I get old.

mnemonics.meaning: Destroy to death. If you are destroyed to this point, this will be your downfall and ruin.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: もしその超巨大火山が噴火をすれば、我々は滅亡を免れないだろう。
If the super volcano erupted, we would not be able to escape destruction.

mnemonics.meaning: Seal in the cylinder. This cylinder that is sealed in is an envelope. You just have to think back to the day, when things were more like in scroll form. So, a scroll's envelope would have been shaped like a cylinder, making this an envelope.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 金はきっちり人数分に山分けして、お前の取り分はその封筒に入れておいたぜ。
We divvied up the money and put your share in the envelope.

mnemonics.meaning: When what you expose is exited out of hiding, exposed for everything to see... that is exposure. It can also refer to photographic exposure too, in case you were wondering.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 思い直して、肌の露出が激しいドレスを着るのは控えることにしました。
I thought better of it and refrained from wearing such a revealing dress.

mnemonics.meaning: Slap that bug and destroy it. Haha! I slapped all the bugs away. This is extermination.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私達はみんな、飲酒運転撲滅運動をサポートしています。
We all support the eradication of drunk driving.

mnemonics.meaning: A fake thing is fake or counterfeit.
mnemonics.reading: You've learned both of these readings already. No fakes there.

sentences: あの男、俺に偽物のグッチの財布を自慢してきたんだぜ。
That guy bragged about his fake Gucci wallet to me.
イテウォンに行けばブランド物の偽物が買えますよ。
If you go to Itaewon, you can buy fake branded goods.
最近、ポートランドのダウンタウンにコウイチの偽物が住んでいるという情報をキャッチしました。
We have recently received information that a fake Koichi is living in downtown Portland.

mnemonics.meaning: Ah yes, wet clothes must be wet clothes-NOT! This used to mean "wet clothes" a long, long time ago, but these days it's used for false accusations. Think of it this way: if you make false, baseless accusations, it's like you're dumping water all over someone for no reason.
mnemonics.reading: This word is made up of the reading from 濡れる and the rendaku version of the きぬ reading of 衣. You learned this reading in the 衣 vocabulary, but here's a mnemonic to remember it. Imagine someone's dumped water on you and you're all wet. You might say "give new (ぎぬ) clothes to me!"

sentences: 僕がおならしたって？そんなの濡れ衣だよ。
Are you saying I farted? That's a baseless accusation.
コウイチに濡れ衣を被せられた。
Koichi accused me of something he was responsible for.
濡れ衣だったと信じてくれたのは、飼い犬だけだった。
The only one who believed that it was a false accusation was my dog.

mnemonics.meaning: Enroll your door... and by door, I mean enroll your family, because each family has one door to their house. Enrolling your family means you are enrolling them into the family register. This is actually an interesting topic. Look up "koseki" in Google and you're sure to find many fascinating histories.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 戸 is an exception. Instead of と it's こ. Just think about how the person who runs this census doesn't care about number of toes. They care about number of children (こ).

sentences: 私は戸籍謄本の写しが必要です。
I need an official copy of my family register.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Note that for the word fence in Japanese, フェンス is typically used. 垣 isn't very common but it's sometimes used in literature.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 少女は心に垣をめぐらせていた。
The girl built a wall around her heart.
野生動物に畑を荒らされないように垣を造る必要があった。
It was necessary to build a hedge to prevent wild animals from destroying the fields.
城の周りに石や木で強固な垣が築かれた。
A strong fence of stone and wood was built around the castle.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 主義 is "-ism." Add that onto an ism that is building a seal(ed) in system, and you have feudalism. Why? Because with feudalism, power is sealed in with one group or one family. Nobody else can get in (until they are overthrown, anyways), making this feudalism.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今日は歴史の授業で封建主義について学びました。
Today we learned about feudalism in history class.

mnemonics.meaning: A warm furnace is a furnace for warming you and other things. This is a fireplace or hearth or even a stove.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: うちの子がおしっこ漏らしをしちゃって、ズボンを洗ったから、今それを暖炉の前で乾かしているのよ。
My son peed his pants and I washed them, so they’re hanging in front of the fireplace to dry now.

mnemonics.meaning: I'm going to expose my bones for a second here and be blunt with you... this makes sense, because if you're exposing your bones at someone, you're not hiding anything. You're being frank and blunt.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女があまりに露骨にものを言うもので、少々面食らいました。
I was pretty surprised at how blunt she was.

mnemonics.meaning: Things that chafe and grate have lots of friction.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 摩擦によって静電気が生じるんですか？
Does friction cause static electricity?

mnemonics.meaning: A courteous talk is a friendly chat. We all know that "friendly chats" are never what they seem, though... right?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 来る10月22日に、マンションの住人の皆様との懇話会を予定しております。
We are holding a friendly get together for the apartment residents on October 22.

mnemonics.meaning: A courteous parent is a parent who knows when a kid needs a friend. Then, they set their kid up with you so that you can have a friendship. What a nice parent the other person is!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その会社の株主総会の後には、懇親会があります。
There will be a friendly reunion after the company’s stockholders’ meeting.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of gentle? It's gentle... but in this word's case, it's also flexible, soft, and tender.
mnemonics.reading: You find something that is so gentle and soft to the touch. You touch it. You can't stop. The monkey you're touching tells you to stop. It doesn't like to be touched. But, you won't stop. "Yah what (やわ) you gonna do about it, monkey?" "Yah, what can I do, I guess," replies the monkey.

sentences: あなたのセーターはとっても柔らかいですね。
Your sweater is so soft.

mnemonics.meaning: Gentle and peace. These are signs of gentleness.
mnemonics.reading: You didn't learn this reading of 柔 with the kanji, so let's remember it a different way. You have to provide a lot of gentleness if you want to touch something that's new (にゅう) to this world... a puppy, a kitty, a baby, etc. Anything new needs gentleness.

sentences: あそこで柔和な笑みを浮かべている理髪師は、実はこの辺りのポン引き男どもの親分なんだ。
That gentle looking barber over there is actually this area’s pimp boss.

mnemonics.meaning: The point of something is the gist and principle of it. So, what's the gist of this vocab word? It's gist as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the word 胸 (chest). So, the gist of your body is your chest (it's at the center, and holds everything together, right?). That's why these words are both read as むね.

sentences: 先生には、家庭の方針として、主人と私は子どもにそうした漫画は読ませたくないと思っているという旨を伝えました。
I explained the gist of our family policy and how my husband and I don’t want to let our kid read comic books to the teacher.

mnemonics.meaning: A bright news report is going to be one full of good news. A dark news report is probably bad news, but we only care about good news right now, don't we?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 朗報を伝えるためにここに来ました。
I’m here to tell you some good news.

mnemonics.meaning: A hedge (or fence) root is where the hedge and fence grow from. What grows from this? Well, it's simply a hedge or a fence.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. With 垣 that's the one you learned and with 根 that's the vocab version of the kanji.

sentences: 男は垣根の上にそっと義手を置きました。
The man placed his prosthetic hand gently on the hedge.

mnemonics.meaning: A full tide is a high tide or full tide. That's when the water comes up.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 一番釣りに適しているのは満潮時でしょうか？
Is high tide the best time to go fishing?

mnemonics.meaning: If something's got charm and is to your taste, then it's your hobby. Hobbies are activities that you find charming and develop a taste for.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私の趣味は家の大掃除です。
My hobby is housecleaning.

mnemonics.meaning: An instant sit is immediate. It's also instantaneous. Just imagine yourself sitting instantly. No time passes between when you were standing and sitting. The instantaneous nature of your sit is definitely... troubling.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 即座の結果は期待しないでください。
Please don’t expect immediate results.

mnemonics.meaning: If you see 即 before a word, you know that it's probably something that happens really fast or instantaneously. That's why this is immediate or instant.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: すごく可愛いテディーベアを見つけたので、即買いしちゃいました。
I found a super cute teddy bear and immediately bought it.

mnemonics.meaning: It's instantly effective! Sounds like something out of Pokemon. This word means immediate effect or instant effect.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening.

sentences: 即効で目の疲れを取る方法をお教えしましょう。
I’ll show you a way to instantly remove eye strain.

mnemonics.meaning: An instant interest in something you didn't have interest in before? Well, time for some improvisation, because you're going to have to pretend you have interest in it (since you don't actually).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening of そく.

sentences: みんなは彼が即興で作った詩をすごいねと褒めたが、口先だけなのは見え見えでした。
Everyone told him that his impromptu poem was great, but it was obviously just lip service.

mnemonics.meaning: The に on the end of this word turns sincerity into an adverb. What's the adverb version of sincerity? It's sincerely, or indeed. It really is.
mnemonics.reading: This shares the same reading as the vocabulary word 誠, but here's a reminder just in case: My coat (まこと) really is a coat! Indeed, it is.

sentences: 誠に申し訳ございません。
I sincerely apologize.
わざわざお越しいただき、誠にありがとうございます。
I really thank you for coming all the way here.
それは誠に素晴らしいことだ。
That is indeed wonderful.
誠に申し訳ありませんが、当ホテルは全室禁煙となっております。
I am really sorry, but all rooms in our hotel are non-smoking.

mnemonics.meaning: A courteous discussion is a little more formal than a friendly talk (because it's a discussion), but it's still fairly informal on the discussion scale, making it an informal talk.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 授業参観日の先生との懇談の間、彼女はずっとハンカチを握りしめてていました。
She was tightly clutching her handkerchief throughout the friendly talk with the teacher on parent’s day.

mnemonics.meaning: If 伺う is "to inquire" or "to visit" then the noun version would be a polite way to say inquiry or enquiry. In other words, a question. It can also mean a visit.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 伺う.

sentences: あなたのブログのURLをお伺いしてもよろしいですか？
Could I inquire about your blog’s URL, please?

mnemonics.meaning: An instant death is an instant death.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は潮津波に乗ってサーフィンをしようとしたが、残念ながら即死した。
He tried to ride tidal bore and surf it, but unfortunately he died instantly.

mnemonics.meaning: The idea of being courteous leads you to have more feelings of intimacy and kindness toward people. The more courteous someone is toward you (and vice versa), the more the closeness between the two of you grows.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その弁護士さんとはもう何十年も懇意にしていましてね。
I’ve been close to that lawyer for decades.

mnemonics.meaning: The gentle path is, surprisingly, judo. Yep, the sport / art based on throwing people around.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: もし柔道が何かを知らないって言うなら、ここに超簡単な入門書があるよ。
If you don’t know what Judo is, here is a book with a very brief introduction of it.

mnemonics.meaning: The harp, at least in Japan, is the koto, also known (to us) as the Japanese harp or Japanese zither.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 今けちって安い琴を買っても、どうせ後から質のいい方が欲しくなるんだから。
If you’re stingy now and you buy a cheap koto, you’ll probably end up wanting a better one later on.

mnemonics.meaning: A pasture place is a livestock farm. It's also a ranch. The place where things pasture is this place.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この牧場には、絞り立ての牛乳を使った自慢のアイスクリーム屋さんがあるんだ。
This farm boasts a good ice cream shop that uses fresh milk.

mnemonics.meaning: A bog earth place is a place where the earth is boggy. That's a marshland or wetland.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the ones you learned with the respective kanji.

sentences: もしかしたら、彼らがこの沼地にはドラゴンがいると言ってたのは、本当のことだったのかも。
Maybe they were telling the truth that there is a dragon in these swamplands.

mnemonics.meaning: A bog rice paddy is a marshy rice field. This is just a rice paddy in marshy form.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 沼田を裸足で歩いたことはありますか。
Have you ever walked barefoot through a marshy rice paddy?

mnemonics.meaning: Nourishing and fostering. The thing that gives you this is nourishment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 風邪を引いたら、大豆だとか林檎だとか、滋養のある物を食べなさい。
When you get a cold, eat nourishing food like soy beans or apples.

mnemonics.meaning: The furnace heart is the heart of the furnace. The heart of this particular furnace, the one we're talking about here, is the nuclear reactor core.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうして奴らは原子炉の炉心が溶解してしまったことを隠そうとしたんだ？
Why did they try to hide that the core of the nuclear reactor had melted?

mnemonics.meaning: A pasture teacher is one who leads his flock around through life. This is a pastor, minister, or clergyman.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 牧師さんはもう今日は教会を出ちゃいましたか？
Has the pastor already left the church for the day?

mnemonics.meaning: The pasture grass is the pasture and grass.
mnemonics.reading: With 草 you learned a different reading from the one here. Just think about how with this pasture you have to constantly sew (そう) it together to make it come together, otherwise it comes apart and moves all around, and that's no good for any pasture.

sentences: 氷点下の日々が続いているせいで、牧草が全てやられてしまった。
It has been below freezing for days, so all my grass is dead.

mnemonics.meaning: A pasture field is pasture land. It's also a ranch.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The secondary reading is a bit different. That's a family name, and uses the kun'yomi readings of both kanji. We'll consider this secondary for now, but you may have to come back to this when you see this as a name and are all like "what's going on here??"

sentences: 二、三年くらいしたら、父親が死んで、俺は父さんの牧野を相続する事になると思うよ。
In a few years my father will die and I’ll inherit his ranch.

mnemonics.meaning: Relax in peace. Wherever you are that's allowing you to do this, it is certainly peace. You feel security too.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの忌まわしい家族が未来永劫安泰でいられるなんて、誰が信じたいと思う？
Who would want to believe that horrible family would have eternal peace?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Additionally, a cylinder is a pipe as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: When it comes to pipes, you always want to have two sets of two of them, just in case. So, that's a two two (つつ) set of pipes, lined up next to each other for backup.

sentences: 使い終わったら、体温計を筒の中に戻しておいてね。
Can you put the thermometer back in its tube when you’re done using it?

mnemonics.meaning: The parts we need. The point of that. That is the point. That is the essentials. It's what we need and it's to the point, you know?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 授業前にその本の要旨を理解しておくと、プラスになると思うよ。
I think it would be a plus to understand the fundamentals of the book before the lesson.

mnemonics.meaning: The point to my theory is the point of an argument. That's what I'm trying to say in my theory / argument, man!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼の話の論旨があまりに不明瞭だったので、苛々しました。
I got frustrated because the point of his story was very vague.

mnemonics.meaning: With a seal we're printing everything out. The seal is what prints the words on the paper, making this printing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 我々の広告を上質の紙に料理のレシピと一緒に印刷すれば、みんなそれを冷蔵庫に貼っておいてくれるんじゃないかな。
We should print our advertisements on nice paper with cooking recipes so that people will keep them on their fridge.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of rare? It's rare. But, this can also mean unusual or curious (as in "odd" curious, not that you're curious about something).
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You know what's unusual and rare? This maze is rare (めずら). I don't think there's a way out of it. We've been walking around for days now, and we haven't gotten any closer to the exit!

sentences: この辺ではベーコンの乗ったドーナッツはそう珍しいものではありませんよ。
It’s not rare to see bacon on donuts around here.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can add the meanings curious and strange to this word as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this kanji is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. That in itself isn't too rare, wouldn't you say?

sentences: あなたの珍増税政策の理論的根拠を述べてくださいよ。
What is the rationale behind your strange policy for increasing taxes?

mnemonics.meaning: The instant day is the day that's going on this instant. It's the same day as now.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 即 is the normal one. For 日 you're going to want to use the じつ reading, because, the truth (じつ) is that it's the same day today.

sentences: この回転肉焼き器は、注文日の即日に発送致します。
We send out this rotisserie on the same day as you order.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji is seal in, but the vocab noun version is seal. This is simply a seal (not the water kind, the kind you use to seal something with).
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as one of the readings you learned: ふう. Don't be a fool, make sure you seal your envelopes.

sentences: 自分が六歳の子どもだってことは分かってたけど、父さんが勝手に封を開けて友達からの手紙を読んだことにはすごく腹が立ったわ。
I know I was just a 6-year-old kid, but I got so mad when my dad opened the envelope and read the letter from my friend without asking me first.

mnemonics.meaning: A seal in writing is writing that has been sealed into an envelope. This is a sealed letter.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 契約書にサインをして封筒に入れてありますが、まだその封書を郵送していません。
I signed the contract and put it in an envelope, but I haven’t mailed the sealed letter to them yet.

mnemonics.meaning: At one moment it happened simultaneously. It was simultaneous. It was all at once.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening of 一.

sentences: 生徒達は一斉に温度計に目をやりました。
The students looked at the thermometer simultaneously.

mnemonics.meaning: You have consolation so now you can relax. What a great feeling this is. You now have solace and relaxation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: うちの会社では、毎年強制参加の慰安旅行があります。
Our company has a mandatory recreation trip every year.

mnemonics.meaning: 誰 is who, 誰か is like asking "who?" If you don't know who it is, you just know it's someone.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: うちの家族の誰かが、母の死にあの善良な外科医が関与していると訴えたんですか？
Did someone in my family accuse that excellent surgeon of contributing to our mom’s death?

mnemonics.meaning: A part split is when things split into two parts. This is a split and division.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その政党は三派に分裂したと思っていたんだけど、実際は四派に分裂していたんだね。
I thought the political party was split three ways, but it was actually split four ways.

mnemonics.meaning: Sink and stagnate. Imagine something is doing just that. It is in the state of stagnation and inactivity.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 景気の沈滞により、たくさんの労働者が首を切られました。
A lot of laborers were laid off due to business stagnation.

mnemonics.meaning: A stone hedge is a wall (hedges are nice walls), but it's made of stone. It's a stone wall.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the readings for 石 and 垣 combined into one word. Be careful of the rendakus.

sentences: 彼は義足を付けていたので、石垣を乗り越えられませんでした。
He couldn’t climb over the stone wall because he has artificial legs.

mnemonics.meaning: An exposed shop is one that's not inside. It's outside, and exposed. It's a street stall.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの露店で買ったアクセは全部すぐ壊れちゃったよ。
Every accessory I bought from the street stall broke immediately.

mnemonics.meaning: A mutual slap is when two big guys run at each other and slap each other. This is sumo wrestling.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is pretty weird, and not one you've learned. But, you know what sumo is, right? It's just the same as that. It's すもう.

sentences: 今夜ビールを飲みながら相撲を見るってのはどうだい？
Do you want to drink some beer and watch sumo wrestling tonight?

mnemonics.meaning: An odd attack is an attack you don't expect. This is a surprise attack.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 敵の奇襲を予想できなかった。
We didn’t expect our rival’s surprise attack.

mnemonics.meaning: A bog swamp is a swamp or marsh.
mnemonics.reading: Oddly, this is the one word that uses the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. To remember this particular swamp, note how there are two kanji in here that make this area particularly swampy. Because it's the swampiest, boggiest place in all of Japan, of course the Shogun (しょう) wants it for himself. Even though it's useless land, he wants the best of everything, being the Shogun and all.

sentences: この黄色い花を咲かせる植物は、沼沢地に生息します。
This plant with yellow flowers lives in swamps.

mnemonics.meaning: A tides stream is the stream going through the tide. It's the tide or the tidal current.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 荒い潮流に逆らってボートを漕ぐのは簡単ではないが、コテージに戻るにはそれしか方法がない。
It’s not easy to row against the rough tide, but that’s the only way for us to get back to our cottage.

mnemonics.meaning: The wind tide is the direction in which the tide is blowing. Is it blowing in? Is it blowing out? It is the tide and current. These days, we usually use this word for the current trends that come in like the tide.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼らは、富裕層に反対する社会的風潮を生み出した。
They brought about a social trend against the rich.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: If you think of the tide, you think of the ocean. If you think of the ocean and what it's filled with (besides water) you think of salt (しお).

sentences: インターネットで調べたら潮の満ち引きの時刻が分かるんじゃない？
Can’t we find out when the tide rises by looking online?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means attack and the verb vocab version is to attack.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You going to attack me or something? Oh so scary you are. Oh so scary. Ho ho ho."

sentences: 俺は文字通りズボンを下げたところで、突然の激しい腹痛に襲われました。
I was literally caught with my pants down by a sudden, severe attack from a stomach ache.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 埋める means "to bury?" Well this is something that is being buried, maybe even you! Either way, you're not the one doing the burying. It means to be buried.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

sentences: カナダでは、十階建てのアパートが雪で埋まる。
In Canada, ten story apartment buildings are being covered in snow.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. The kanji means hoist, but the verb most commonly means to be fried up, ready to eat. Imagine something being hoisted up onto the table because it's fried and ready to eat. The verb can also mean, more logically, to be up.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 揚げる.

sentences: 唐揚げ揚がったよ！
The fried chicken (karaage) is fried up!
天ぷらが揚がるまで静かに待っていた。
We waited quietly until the tempura was deep fried.
旗が揚がったら出発だ。
We'll head out once the flag is up.

mnemonics.meaning: Take my majesty and stretch it. Your majesty is so stretched! That makes me so proud! That's why this word is to be proud or to be arrogant.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is from 威 and 張る.

sentences: ケンイチは会社のトップのような顔をして威張ってる。
Kenichi acts like the top dog of the company and he's being really arrogant.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means grate (as in, "to grate" on something). The verb vocab version is to chafe and to rub, which is pretty close.
mnemonics.reading: If you're going to chafe on me like that, I'm going to sue (す) you. It's making me very uncomfortable.

sentences: ペティコートは、スカートが肌と擦れることを防ぎます。
Petticoats prevent skirts from rubbing against your skin.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means consolation and the verb vocab version is to console.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm going to console you for what happened to you. The nag saw (なぐさ) was turned on and buzzed through your leg. What a nagging feeling. You need some consoling.

sentences: 落ち込んでいると、いつもうちのワン子が慰めてくれます。
Our dog consoles us whenever we get depressed.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means destroy and the verb vocab version is to destroy and to annihilate.
mnemonics.reading: You are going to destroy the hoe roe. This is the roe that comes from the hoe tools. If they create too much roe, they will create too many hoes. And if there are too many hoes, bad things will happen.

sentences: 奴らはメディアで情報操作を行って、日本を滅ぼそうとしているんだ。
They are trying to ruin Japan by manipulating information.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember 群れる, which means "to flock" or "to crowd."? This also means that!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a little different from 群れる, though. There's an extra ら in there. That being said, it's pretty similar, so you should be able to use one to remember the other after a few reps. You can also think about it this way: Everyone is flocking together in one place. Strange thing is, it's to a small 村 (むら). There's a 村 reunion going on, that's why.

sentences: 空港に到着するとファンが群がっていて、驚きましたよ。
We were surprised that fans had gathered to wait for us when we arrived at the airport.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conceal, but as a verb, this word means to go under or to pass through. Most commonly, this word means to dive underwater or to go underground. Can you see why the kanji for conceal kind of makes sense in these cases? If you're underwater or underground, no one can see you!
mnemonics.reading: 潜る has two possible readings: もぐる and くぐる. The first is used when you mean to dive underwater or go underground.  The second is used when you pass through or under something, sometimes with difficulty, such as crawling under a fence. We want you to focus on もぐる, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Why are you trying to dive underwater again and again? It's to get mo' goo (もぐ) to sell on the black goo market. Who knew that sea goo was such a commodity?

sentences: モグラが土の下に潜って行くところを見ました。
I saw a mole going underground.
水の中にどのぐらいの間潜っていられますか。
How long can you stay underwater?
うちの犬は、フラフープをジャンプして潜る技を身につけました。
My dog learned a trick to jump through a hula hoop.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means chastise but the verb vocab version is to learn by experience. I guess these are kind of similar. When you make a mistake, someone will chastise you, and then you will learn by experience (either via the experience or via the chastising).
mnemonics.reading: As a child (こ) you got a lot of chastising, I bet. A lot of learning by experience (of chastising).

sentences: 彼女に三度も振られてるっていうのに、お前まだ懲りてないのか。
You got turned down by her three times already and you still haven’t learned, have you?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means printing so the verb vocab version is to print.
mnemonics.reading: When you print something out, it's usually the paperwork needed in order to sue (す) someone. You're just that kind of person, always looking to sue.

sentences: 今年は年賀状何枚刷ればいいかなあ？
How many New Year’s cards should we print this year?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sink so the verb vocab version is to sink.  This is an intransitive verb, so it refers to something sinking on its own. You didn't do anything to make it sink. You know this is when something is just sinking on its own (you didn't sink it), because of the む, which shows it's a cow sinking. The cow stepped into some quicksand and now it's sinking, not because of you.
mnemonics.reading: You look at the cow. Poor cow. She's (しず) sinking.

sentences: なんだか沈んだ顔をしているけど、何を思い詰めてるの？
You look a bit depressed. What’s on your mind?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means split, but if you split something, you are going to tear it or to rip up it.
mnemonics.reading: In order to get it open, you need to tear and rip up a sack (さく). Sacks don't have tabs or zippers or any of those fancy things. If you want to get at the stuff in a sack you have to tear the top right off!

sentences: 私は彼女の才能を妬んでおり、彼女が絵画コンクールに向けて絵を描いていたキャンバスを切り裂きました。
I was jealous of her talent, so I tore the canvas she was painting for an art competition to pieces.

mnemonics.meaning: Open a letter that's been sealed already, it becomes an unsealed letter.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 開封前の商品であればいつでも返品可って書いてあるけど、開封後に中身が壊れてたり、その商品が好きじゃなかった場合はどうなんだろう。
It says I can return unopened products at any time, but what if I opened it and the stuff inside was broken or I didn’t like it?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 「彼女は誰かしら。」「名前を知らないの？クラスであなたの後ろに座っているよ！」
"I wonder who that girl is." "You don’t know her name? She sits behind you in class!"

mnemonics.meaning: The bathe clothes are the clothes you take with you to bathe with. This is Yukata.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is totally an exception. The reading comes from the meaning, though. Yukata = ゆかた.

sentences: 彼女は自分の古い考え方にしがみついて、毎晩パジャマの代わりに浴衣を着て過ごした。
She clung to her old ways of thinking and wore a yukata instead of pajamas every night.

mnemonics.meaning: It's kind of hard to see, but if you look at this the right way it looks like a tin can. The lines in the middle show the circumference, and the lines on the tops and sides show the outline of the can.
A turtle that stands up isn't a turtle anymore. It's evolved into a monster. What kind of monster? A dragon! Rawwwr.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means wind.
The radical blade and the kanji blade are exactly the same. Please, just know your radicals. Please!
mnemonics.reading: When you stab your blade into an enemy you shout "Ha (は)!" It's just the normal "thrusting with blade" sound. Ha, HA, HaaAA! Those are the blade sounds we all know and love.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical can is the same as the kanji can. Usually when we talk about a can with this kanji we mean a tin can, though. Picture a tin can in your mind as clearly as you can.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for a can is かん, which seems impossibly easy. If that isn't close enough for you, picture this: Genghis Khan (かん) is drinking out of a tin can. He glug glug glugs, gasps, and wipes his face. He holds out the can, "Khan made cans," and winks. かん is can, it's really easy, come on. Just take this one.

mnemonics.meaning: You put a stone into a wrap of some kind. This wrap happens to be a cannon, and you're shooting off the stone, just like I used to do to boats with the cannon we had growing up for some reason. This makes a lot of sense when you think about it, right? The muzzle of the cannon wraps around the rock, then you shoot the rock. Boom!
mnemonics.reading: You aim the cannon at your own home (ほう). You don't want to have a home anymore, you want to become a pirate, live on a boat, and (of course) shoot cannons all day long. Watch as the cannon goes off, the rock hurtles into your home. And just like that, there is a huge, rock-shaped hole in it. You'll have to shoot a few more rocks at your home with this cannon before it's completely gone.

mnemonics.meaning: A bamboo thing you put on your head to stand taller would probably be a hat. A bamboo hat is probably one of those hats you think of when you think of rice farmers, a conical hat. You know the ones I'm talking about? They're cone-shaped, sort of, and they go on your head, keeping the sun off your face.
mnemonics.reading: A conical hat is kind of like an umbrella on your head. What's the reading for "umbrella" in Japanese? Why, it's kasa (かさ)! Think about a bamboo umbrella on your head. They're pretty similar in shape, after all.

mnemonics.meaning: The dragon radical is the same as this kanji, which is dragon. Not to dragon with it, but make sure you know your radicals so you know your kanji!
mnemonics.reading: Imagine a dragon. You are talking to it, which is already pretty strange, but as you're talking, he turns into the Street Fighter character Ryuu (りゅう). Then imagine after his transformation he attacks you using his Street Fighter moves. "Hadouken!"

mnemonics.meaning: Your fingers told you that a flood last evening seemed to be imminent, and that there was nothing you could do to stop it. You felt it draw close, coming in the darkness of the evening. Think back to last evening, when your fingers twitched and twisted, warning you as the flood started to draw close.
mnemonics.reading: As the flood began to draw close you knew there was nothing you could do, so you sat (さつ) down  and waited. You sat down and now you're still there, waiting for the flood. It's still drawing closer... it'll come eventually.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a thread tying wolverine to a pig, balancing them over the edge of a cliff together. Picture wolverine and a pig hanging precariously over the edge. One move the wrong way and they'll both go toppling over.
mnemonics.reading: Suddenly, the pig squeals, pulls the thread, and sends them both over the edge. Straight to their end (えん). If you fall off the edge it'll be your end too. Always be safe and never get too close to any edges!

mnemonics.meaning: If someone puts a blade to your heart, you're going to have a rough time. They leave it there, for a long long time. They aren't going to cut you, but you can't move. You have to endure the pain and uncomfortableness of the situation. Imagine your chest and ribs are open. There's a blade on your heart. Now try not to move, or your heart will be cut!
mnemonics.reading: This is all a part of your ninja (にん) training. You must learn to stay totally still, without breathing. This is how they train you. If you can endure this you can endure anything, plus you can stay really still, which is good for ninjas. Just think about how much you want to become a ninja. You'll do anything, even endure this.

mnemonics.meaning: A gold pool is where you're going to go fishing. Because, if the pool is gold, hopefully the fish are too. Imagine yourself fishing in a gold pool, catching golden fish. What a great fishing spot this is.
mnemonics.reading: You caught a couple of gold fish. Two (つ) gold fish, actually! Count your golden fish. They're so nice! They're also worth their weight in gold, because, well, they are gold.

mnemonics.meaning: The good luck radical and the good luck kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: For good luck, you keep special kits (きつ) in your kitchen (きち). These kitchen kits contain good luck charms. Your good luck kitchen kits have charms that say things like, "good food," "good company," and "good luck not cutting off your fingers with kitchen knives."

mnemonics.meaning: The part of rice that stands up tall in the air (at the end of the stalks) is the grains. If you think about this one it'll make good sense. Just imagine rice stalks standing up into the air.
mnemonics.reading: You have a box of grains. Ryuu (りゅう) from Street Fighter is doing training by punching the grains to strengthen his fingers. He has his hands flat, and stabs his hands into the grains. Yah! Yah! Yah!

mnemonics.meaning: Your long hair is your friend. It's your hair and you're so proud of it. Just feel your hair, it's such a good friend, and you wish it was longer.
mnemonics.reading: Who gave you this hair? Probably the great 神 (かみ) of hair. You deserve this great hair. Pretend to pray to the great hair 神. What is his reply? Does he give you more hair?

mnemonics.meaning: An axe is stuck into the ground on a hill. Imagine climbing up the hill. The sun is coming up behind the axe,  silhouetting the whole thing very nicely.
mnemonics.reading: You reach the top of the hill and realize the entire hill is covered in cucumbers (きゅう). The axe has a little note on it that says "Cucumber Hill Axe - Please Use." You take the axe out of the hill and cut off some cucumber to eat. Mm mm!

mnemonics.meaning: The leader of a big rice paddy is standing in the middle of said rice paddy with an umbrella. Who is this wacky leader? Why, it is I. It is me. Imagine that this leader is you. Be rough about it, because 俺 is the "rougher" version of "I." You should only use it in casual situations or if you're a badass.
mnemonics.reading: Why am I standing in the middle of this rice paddy with an umbrella? I'm digging for ore (おれ). More accurately, I'm standing here with an umbrella so I don't get wet. My minions are doing the ore digging, but I am watching to make sure they don't slack off.

mnemonics.meaning: The ladle radical and the ladle kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: You use a ladle to distribute soup. But as you're ladling you find something odd floating in the soup. It's... a toe (と)! You scream, dropping the ladle and the toe on the ground. Your mom comes rushing in and smacks you on the head. "Fool!" she says, "This is toe soup, what did you think you'd ladle up?!" Oops.

mnemonics.meaning: The measurement radical and the measurement kanji are exactly the same. If you make sure to know the radicals, you'll also make sure to know the kanji too, automagically.
mnemonics.reading: You want to measure something... something that will make you famous. You decide you'll measure the biggest mass in our solar system. We're talking about the sun (すん). Imagine yourself deciding to do this. First step is to get a ridiculously long measuring tape. Then, you go up to the sun and start measuring. You immediately start getting burned. Feel the pain of the heat from the sun. Think about how this really probably wasn't a good idea. You still go forward, though, doing your best to measure the sun. Ouch, ouch, ouch.

mnemonics.meaning: The tree has an omen growing from it, one single peach that is the size of a house. Inside is a child who will save the village from demons. Of course, this tree omen of a peach refers to momotaro, the little boy who was born from a peach (you should look it up if you don't know this children's story).
mnemonics.reading: If momotaro (もも) wasn't enough, think about the peach growing larger and larger. You want it to grow bigger, so you yell at it: "MORE! MORE!" (もも). It grows bigger everytime you say "MORE MORE" twice. If you say it just once, it stays the same.

mnemonics.meaning: The grain you cut off a tree with a knife is a pear. I don't know if you've ever seen Asian pears, but they're pretty big and sturdy. You can't just pick them off of the tree, you need the help of a knife. That's why this is a pear, and not an apple or peach or something else. Imagine standing below a tree full of pears. You take your knife and carefully cut them all down, one by one.
mnemonics.reading: As you cut the pears down, you can't help but gnash (なし) your teeth. You want to eat these pears right now. You gnash and grind and wait though, because you want to have them all down before you start the feast. Imagine a beautiful, ripe pear in your mind. Now gnash your teeth. Mmm. You want to eat a pear right now, don't you?

mnemonics.meaning: The woman servant is the lower ranking princess. The queen is no servant. Hecks no. Just the princess, because she's a servant to what her parents tell her to do. Just imagine a princess saying "UGH, I'm just like a servant, I have to do all the crap you tell me." Then, all the servants roll their eyes, because, really, she's a princess, lucky duck.
mnemonics.reading: The princess goes on to do whatever she wants. She tells the real servants, "Don't tell my daddy, the king, I did this. He may (ひめ) not like it." The servants all know they should tell the king, because the princess is a servant to the king, just as they are, plus they don't want to lose their heads.

mnemonics.meaning: You use your fingers when you're in private to use an arrow to push open things. You're in private in your own room, no one else is around. Now you wrap your fingers around this big arrow, and you push open your door, your curtains, your windows. It's weird, but you really enjoy this.
mnemonics.reading: Your favorite thing to push open is your own eye (あい). You take the arrow into your fingers and gently push each lid open until you can see. Picture the arrow in your hands. You're facing a mirror, but you can't see because you're about to push open your eyes. The anticipation is killing you, push them open now!

mnemonics.meaning: A woman loves her catapult for some good ol' fashioned recreation. You ask the woman what she does for fun... for recreation. She says, she goes out and shoots her catapult.
mnemonics.reading: Her favorite thing to shoot at with her catapult for recreation is Godzilla (ご). Get out of here, Godzilla! I'm gonna shoot you.

mnemonics.meaning: I say, which weighs more: a kilogram of scooters or a kilogram of rice? This is a riddle! Think carefully and see if you can come up with the answer to my riddle before you read on.
mnemonics.reading: Did you figure out the answer to this riddle? Say your answer aloud to the screen right now.... not so (なぞ)! You're wrong. Did you say the answer to the riddle is that they're both a kilogram? Not so! A scooter is heavier than some rice! And don't you email me saying that's not so! It's my riddle, I can make the answer whatever I want. That's the law of riddles!

mnemonics.meaning: The leader of the temple isn't a monk like you'd expect. It's a samurai, who protects the monks in return for prayers that keep him safe. You walk up to a temple and you're surprised to find that there's a samurai guarding it. Talk to him for a while so he can tell you why he has been doing this job. He's quite a nice guy, actually.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is samurai, which should be easy enough to remember. If you know the meaning you know the reading as well! That doesn't happen too often with kanji, so consider yourself lucky!

mnemonics.meaning: From my mouth I have told you seven times not to do that. Now I have to scold you. SEVEN TIMES! You'd think you'd learn.
mnemonics.reading: What were you doing wrong that caused me to scold you? You were feeding the 鹿 (しか). If you feed them they'll never be able to feed themselves! Imagine yourself feeding the deer, then getting scolded (or you doing the scolding to someone else feeding the deer, whichever works best).

mnemonics.meaning: A tree with two moons on either side, holding the tree up in a horizontal angle, is a shelf.  So, your shelf is made up of a tree and two moons. Imagine this shelf and put things on it. The moons are kind of rolling around, making it hard to build your shelf.
mnemonics.reading: Your moon shelf is great. It's also huge, because moons are really big. That means you can store a ton-a-stuff (たな) on it. Think about the ton-a-stuff you're going to put on there. Like, literally, measure out a ton of things and put them on there. It can hold it!

mnemonics.meaning: You have mouth vines, so you shout! It's hard for you to talk normally, and even harder for people to understand you unless you shout. You were born with mouth vines (a rare condition where your mouth is always full of vines), so you've been shouting all your life. And yet people still can't hear you. It's very frustrating.
mnemonics.reading: You need to shout so that people can understand you through the mouth vines. You shout, "きょうと!" because you hear there is a temple there for people with your condition. Imagine the word きょうと not coming out clearly because of your mouth vines. People can only hear the きょう part, so they don't know where you want to go. SHOUT LOUDER! きょうと！

mnemonics.meaning: In the cage there are some legs. They are the legs attached to a small animal. You can only see the legs, though, because a cloth is covering the cage. What kind of small animal is it? Try to look.
mnemonics.reading: You look up through the cloth, and see a hairless cat. This small animal is hairless, but most surprisingly is covered in hickies (ひき). Who is giving this cat all those hickies? Pretty gross, if you ask me.

mnemonics.meaning: The spicy radical and spicy kanji are exactly the same! Hot!
mnemonics.reading: Imagine eating this spicy food, becoming blinded by the spicy heat, and knocking your shin (しん) on something while you bumble around. It's bleeding profusely and really hurts a lot. Plus your mouth is still burning from that spicy food you ate. It's pure agony.

mnemonics.meaning: A flowers fang is the bud that comes out of the ground. It's like a little fang, coming from the earth, and it will become a flower someday. This is a little sprout. Imagine a bunch of these. They look like big fangs poking out of the ground (that is, until they bloom and get into the air).
mnemonics.reading: When the sprout gets out of the ground and opens up, instead of a flower there is a human-looking 目 (め), looking right at you. You look at all the sprouts. They have all turned into 目s, looking straight at you. You're terrified.

mnemonics.meaning: The mountain wind coming down from the mountains is very fierce. It is so fierce it's a lot like a storm. Well, it is a storm, really. If you think about it makes sense. Those mountain winds that come down from the mountain are cold and windy and nasty. When they mix with warmer air down below, it creates a nasty storm.
mnemonics.reading: A storm is nothing to scoff at. If you get hit by the storm and get all wet and nasty and electrocuted, you're bound to get a rash (あらし). The rash comes from being wet and not drying off when you get home. Your skin gets irritated by this moisture.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami goes through a little door, and plops down a big drop on your face. This tsunami is your tears inside your eye area. The door is your tear duct. The big drop is the teardrop coming down your eye. Imagine a teardrop going through this process to get out of your eye, though in a more miniature teardrop size.
mnemonics.reading: Your teardrops always come at the worst times, ruining (るい) serious and/or happy moments. You can't stop crying. It is ruining your life! Think of several inappropriate situations to cry in. Put yourself in them. Think about how all this crying is ruining things, for real!

mnemonics.meaning: Rain on a rice paddy means only one thing... thunder! Get off the rice paddy! There's nothing but you to attract the thunder! Imagine hearing the thunder as you run. It is getting closer.
mnemonics.reading: You can't run fast enough to escape the thunder so you hitch a ride (らい) from someone driving by. Thank goodness, that was a close one. The guy who picks you up is named Ryan, though he likes it if you call him Ry (らい).

mnemonics.meaning: When dirt and flowers suit one another, the flowers grow so tall that they make a tower! A flower tower made of flower power! Imagine walking in the woods and coming across a huge tower made of flowers. It goes so high you can hardly see the top.
mnemonics.reading: The only place flowers grow into towers like this is in とうきょう. とうきょう dirt is the best. とうきょう flowers are the best. Thus, you end up with a lot of とうきょう towers. How do you think the とうきょう tower came to be, anyway? It was once a big flower tower. They just replaced it with metal later. BOOM! History bomb, you're welcome.

mnemonics.meaning: The slide to get off this jet is a beautiful, brilliant vermilion color. Vermilion is like an orange red, which is perfect for visibility purposes.
mnemonics.reading: You jump onto the vermilion slide. It's actually more of a steep chute (しゅ). And... oh... urp... it's making you sick. The vermilion chute spits you out and you spit out your lunch. And it looks vermilion. Uh oh. Hospital. Please.

mnemonics.meaning: A feather is on a rice paddy, and they are attached together. You put a feather on a rice paddy to create a giant airplane. Flawed, sure. But, this rice paddy + feather is going to be one wing of your amazing aircraft. Imagine a wing that is made of a rice paddy and a feather put together. Doesn't make sense, looks ugly, and probably will not fly. Imagine it anyways. It is your wing.
mnemonics.reading: To make the feather and rice paddy stick together you need some kind of sticking agent. This time we find the original bird that the feather came from and grab its eggs. We break the eggs open and use the yolk (よく). It's pretty sticky, but still probably not aircraft safe.  Imagine using the yolks to stick everything together. It's all over your hands, and things are pretty nasty.

mnemonics.meaning: A challenge (挑戦) someone is someone who is going to challenge you. They are a challenger.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 腕相撲の挑戦者は、握力を見せつけるために、右手で林檎を潰してみせました。
The arm‐wrestling challenger crushed an apple in his right hand, showing off the strength of his right hand.

mnemonics.meaning: A sleep bed is where you sleep. Where do you sleep? In a bed or a crib. Side note, if you're a baby sleeping in a crib, you must really want to learn kanji.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn the second kun'yomi reading for 床. You take とこ and rendaku it into どこ. How do you remember this? Just think about your bed. Then wonder, "where (どこ) is it?"

sentences: 「さぁ、そろそろ寝床に着く時間じゃぞ。」子供の頃、毎晩祖父にこう言われました。
"Come now, isn’t it about time for bed?" My grandfather used to say that to me every night.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 心配は要りませんよ、患者さん。私のこの手術用メスの鋭い刃で、すぐに盲腸を取ってあげますからね。
Don’t worry, my patient. I can immediately remove your appendix with the sharp blade of my surgical scalpel.

mnemonics.meaning: Gold hair is blonde hair. Makes sense!
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 髪 isn't the one you learned. It's actually はつ, but it's getting rendaku'd here. So, to remember the reading of it for this word, just think about how if you were blonde, you'd wear many hats (はつ) to hide it. I have no idea why you'd hide it, but you can come up with a compelling reason that makes sense to you.

sentences: 金髪になりたかったので、コカコーラで髪を脱色しました。
I wanted to be blonde so I bleached my hair with Coca-Cola.

mnemonics.meaning: A book shelf is a bookcase or bookshelf.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the ones you learned with the individual kanji. Be careful of the rendaku.

sentences: 彼の本棚に、食い逃げの仕方について書かれた本を見つけたんだよね。
I found a book in this bookcase about how to eat and run.

mnemonics.meaning: Both wings are both wings! There are two and you have them all!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 二遊間、外野の両翼のポジションはまだ空いています。
A ball was hit between the second baseman and the shortstop, and both outfield positions are still vacant.

mnemonics.meaning: A can of beer (ビール) is a can beer or canned beer. Not a bottled one.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: ああ、この缶ビールはマジでうますぎる。
Oh, this canned beer is way too good for me.

mnemonics.meaning: A can coffee (コーヒー) is coffee that's in a can. That's canned coffee or can coffee.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼らは、とても美味い缶コーヒーを販売して、大儲けしている。
They’re making a killing selling delicious canned coffee.

mnemonics.meaning: A big cannon is... wait for it... just a cannon. I guess all cannons are big, right? At least when you compare them to guns.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大砲がズドーンと鳴り響き、男は三人の子どもたちを残したまま逝ってしまいました。
The cannon went off with a bang and the man passed away leaving three children behind.

mnemonics.meaning: You know how 携帯 refers to a mobile phone? This is a strap (ストラップ) for a mobile phone, making this a cell phone strap or mobile phone strap.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the reading of 携帯.

sentences: あの携帯ストラップが気色悪すぎて、考えるだけでも吐きそうだわ。
The cell phone strap is so gross just thinking about it makes me puke.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji is distract and the adjective version is confusing or misleading.
mnemonics.reading: You know who is particularly confusing? That maggie (まぎ) girl. She's confusing because she uses magic (まぎ). Think of a Maggie you know, if possible.

sentences: 結局それはバスケットボールだったんですが、とても紛らわしかったです。私は完全に妊婦さんの大きなお腹だと思っていました。
It was a basketball after all, but it was really misleading. I thought it looked exactly like a pregnant woman’s stomach.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 私は彼女の笠にこっそりエーデルワイスの花を飾りました。
I secretly put some edelweiss flowers on my girlfriend’s conical hat.

mnemonics.meaning: The pipe control tower is the tower that controls all the pipes... think of the pipes not as pipes, but as directions things are moving in. You're controlling all of that on a map, and the pipe shows where everything is going and you're changing it to be where it needs to go. You are in the control tower.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: もし巨大な竜巻がこの地域を襲ったら、管制塔はどうなるんでしょうか。
If a huge tornado hit this area, how do you think the control tower would fare?

mnemonics.meaning: A door shelf is a shelf with a door on it. What kinds of shelves do you know of that have doors on them? How about cupboards?
mnemonics.reading: These readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 今日買った単三電池は戸棚の上に置いておいたよ。
I put the double A batteries that we bought today in the cupboard.

mnemonics.meaning: A fear dragon is a dinosaur. Dinosaurs are much, much scarier than dragons, and that's why dinosaurs are called fear dragons in Japanese.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 恐竜の化石を見つけるのに一番いい方法はなんでしょうか。
What’s the best way to find dinosaur fossils?
「今日はハロウィンなので、恐竜のコスプレをした忍者の仮装をしています。」「何だそれ、紛らわしいな。」
"It's Halloween today, so I'm dressing up as a ninja in dinosaur cosplay." "What the heck. That's confusing."
あの哲学者は、ペットに恐竜を四匹飼っています。
That philosopher has four dinosaurs as pets.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: その小説家は、55冊目の竜を題材にした小説でようやく大儲けすることができた。
The novelist finally hit pay dirt with his fifty-fifth novel about dragons.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  The edge of the cheese is what we call the fool (ふ) cheese (ち) because nobody wants that part.

sentences: 縁が無い眼鏡はありますか？
Do you have any rimless glasses?

mnemonics.meaning: A blade thing is an edged tool or cutlery.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned 刃's reading with the kanji, and you probably remember 物 from so many other words.

sentences: 刃物をちらつかせながら、男は低い声で私に「こっちへ来い」と言いました。
While brandishing his knife, he said to me in a low voice, "Get over here."

mnemonics.meaning: The blade's ahead is the farthest part of the blade away from you (since it's ahead of you). This is the edge of the blade or blade edge.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. For 刃 you learned that with the kanji. For 先 that's the vocab version of the kanji.

sentences: 刃先を俺の首に当てながら、奴は、皆にいつもご機嫌をとられてるってのはどんな気分なのかと聞いてきたんだ。
While putting the edge of the blade in my neck, the guys asked me what it’s like to have people fawning over me all the time.

mnemonics.meaning: The Eiffel (エッフェル) tower is the Eiffel Tower.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: エッフェル塔のどんなところが好きでしたか？
What did you like about the Eiffel Tower?

mnemonics.meaning: A one ladle can is a eighteen-liter container, which is also a five-gallon container. That must be one big ladle! If you live in Japan you've probably seen these. They're rectangular shaped containers made of metal that are used mostly for industrial purposes, for storing liquids like paint, fuel and chemicals. The 斗 actually refers to an old Japanese measurement, which is roughly equivalent to eighteen liters.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Just watch out for the 一, which gets shortened to いっ.

sentences: 一斗缶は洗剤や石油などを保管するためのものです。
Eighteen-liter containers are used to store things like detergent and oil.
その店では、一斗缶のキャンペーンを行っています。
That store has a promotion on five-gallon containers.
この一斗缶をあそこのコーナーに積んでください。
Please stack these eighteen-liter containers in the corner over there.

mnemonics.meaning: A sky can is a can that has nothing but sky in it. It's an empty can.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 空き isn't one you've seen before. Remember how 開く means "to open"? Well, this can is also open, because nothing is filling it. The readings are the same between the two, as well. 開く and 空く, though in this case it becomes the stem form: 空き.

sentences: 三人のホームレスの老人が、公園で空き缶拾い競争を行った。
Three old homeless men had an empty can gathering competition in the park.

mnemonics.meaning: Extinction caused by a shout. You are making everyone else's voices go extinct, and you scream and shout over them. You are making an exclamation, gosh darn it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the shortening.

sentences: 誰かがジェットコースターの上で、「覚悟しろ！」と絶叫した。
Someone screamed "brace yourself!" on the roller coaster.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

sentences: 父親同様、魚釣りは彼のお気に入りの気晴らしだ。蛙の子は蛙ってことだね。
Fishing is his favorite pastime, just like his father. They say like father, like son.

mnemonics.meaning: Four small animals is four small animals. Use this to count four dogs, or cats, or whatever else.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: うちの四匹のマルチーズは、昨日、誕生日だったので、とても美味しい晩ご飯を食べました。
My four Maltese dogs had a scrumptious supper because yesterday was their birthday.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 揚げる can sometimes mean "to fry"? This is the noun version of that meaning of that word, making it fried... delicious fried...
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 揚げる as well.

sentences: どんな食べ物でも、彼女の手にかかれば、美しく美味しい金色の揚げ物になるんです。
Every food she touches turns into beautiful, delicious fried food.

mnemonics.meaning: A hand sack is a sack for your hands... better put, these are gloves.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are both the kun'yomi vocab readings, so think of 手 and 袋 as individual words, put together to make hand sacks. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: どうして裸んぼで手袋だけはめて走り回ってるの？あんたは本当に馬鹿ね。
Why are you running around naked with only gloves on? You’re such an idiot!

mnemonics.meaning: Having good luck is a good omen to have. Good luck means more good luck, right?
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the きち reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: みんな、結婚式の日に吉日を選びたいのよ。
Everyone wants to choose a lucky day for their wedding.

mnemonics.meaning: Grains are made of single grains. You can also use this to refer to a bead or use it as a counter for grains.
mnemonics.reading: You take all the grain and put it in a tube (つぶ). Just imagine doing this, grain by grain.

sentences: 私は一粒の岩塩をオブラートで包みました。
I wrapped a single grain of rock salt in a wafer.

mnemonics.meaning: Push open the door to the conversation that is going to be imminent by saying the proper greeting or salutation. This word might also refer to a short speech you give at an event or ceremony.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

sentences: まだ小さいのに挨拶ができて良い子だね。
You're such a good child for greeting people properly even though you're still so little.
挨拶はコミュニケーションに欠かせない要素です。
Greetings are an essential part of communication.
近くにいたので、挨拶しに来ました。
I was in the area, so I came by to say hi.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 握る is "to grasp"? This is the noun version, making it a grip.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 握る, so get a grip on that!

sentences: 怒ったコウイチは、握り拳で机をバンバン叩いた。
Angry Koichi banged on the desk with his clenched fists.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Just be sure to know that this is the hair on your head.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 生まれたての赤ちゃんは、毎日お風呂に入れてあげて髪を洗ってあげた方がいいのかな。
I wonder if I should give my newborn baby a bath and wash her hair every day.

mnemonics.meaning: Your hair model is how you model your hair. It's your hairstyle or hairdo.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the vocab readings of the individual kanji. For 髪 that's no problem. For 型 just remember that it's the individual vocab reading. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: ビートルズみたいな髪型だね。
Your hairstyle looks like the Beatles’.

mnemonics.meaning: Your hair fur is the hair fur that's specifically on your head. It's your head hair.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings, 髪 and 毛, put together.

sentences: 「ねえ、サーモン。今何してんの？」「髪の毛セットしてるとこ。」「終わったら、ちょっと時間ある？」「無理〜。これが終わったらネイルもしなきゃなの。」
"Salmon, what are you doing right now?" "I am doing my hair." "After that, do you have time?" "Nope. I have to do my nails next."

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for the vocab version of this word is the same as 岡 which has the same meaning and the same reading. Lucky!

sentences: 初めてマニュアルで運転した時、丘のてっぺんでエンストしてしまいました。
On my first day of driving a stick, my car stalled at the top of a hill.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: やあ、コウイチ！俺、久しぶりにお前に会ったから、話したいことが山ほどあるよ。
Hey Koichi, we’ve got a lot to catch up on.

mnemonics.meaning: How much can you hold in this ladle? Why, exactly eighteen liters of course! Eighteen is your favorite number, how convenient.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 一斗のお米が入った袋は置いてますか？
Do you have a bag of 18 liters of rice?

mnemonics.meaning: The left wing is the left wing, as in the "left wing party" or "left wing politics" or something like that.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 左 is the on'yomi reading, さ. You can remember this because the left wing uses saws (さ) to cut down their right wing enemies. Imagine left wing hippies sawing down old right wing conservatives. BBrrrrbbbbbbzzzzz!

sentences: 取材であの左翼支持者の方とお会いできるのがとても楽しみです。
I am so excited that I get to meet with the left wing movement supporter for an interview.

mnemonics.meaning: Let's take the edge and discuss it. That edge is the edge of getting married. But, when you reach that edge, before you jump over, you have to do a marriage proposal.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 高卒以下の学歴の男との縁談を私に持って寄越すなんて、一体どういう神経してる訳？
How dare you to bring me a marriage proposal from a guy who has less than a high school education?!

mnemonics.meaning: One of the easiest methods of measurement is to just check the size and dimensions, and there you go, you've got the measurement.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that the ほう changes to ぽう.

sentences: この寸法は正しいですか？
Is this measurement correct?

mnemonics.meaning: Your mourning clothes is your mourning dress or mourning clothes.
