mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the on'yomi for 服 and the kun'yomi for 喪, which you learned with the word 喪. You should know how to read this word!

sentences: 私の妹は拒食症なのですが、喪服を着ているとより一層痩せ細ってみえました。
My sister is anorexic and when wearing her mourning dress, she looked even skinnier.

mnemonics.meaning: A riddle is a riddle, but in this case, more of a mystery.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. No mystery there, I suppose.

sentences: あの映画のその場面がいつも謎なんだよね。
That part of the movie is always a mystery to me.

mnemonics.meaning: A spicy win is a narrow victory. Kind of makes sense, right?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: トーフグは著作権侵害の裁判で辛勝しました。
Tofugu won a narrow victory in a copyright infringement suit.

mnemonics.meaning: An endure someone is someone who can endure. Who endures everything better than anyone? A ninja.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: コウイチは忍者に、正々堂々と勝負で勝った。
Koichi beat the ninja fair and square!

mnemonics.meaning: The edge of wake up is right before you wake up. And, by wake up I mean you're about to wake up to the truth. But, you're only at the edge, so for now what you see is an omen... an omen that will show the truth.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that 起 is rendaku'd and becomes ぎ here.

sentences: カラスは、日本だけでなくヨーロッパでも、縁起の悪い鳥とみなされます。
The crow is seen as an ominous bird not only in Japan but also in Europe.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is not good luck is ominous and sinister. It's also bad luck and an ill omen.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: すごく不吉な夢を見たもんで、あんたのことが心配になってこうして電話をした訳さ。
I had such an ominous dream that it made me really worried about you, and that’s why I called.

mnemonics.meaning: One small animal is one small animal. Use this to count small animals like cats and dogs.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening and the rendaku.

sentences: 「なあ、今夜俺たちと遊ばないか？金曜日の東京の繁華街はめちゃくちゃ楽しいぜ。」「俺は一匹狼なんだよ。放っておいてくれ。」
"Do you want to hang out with us tonight? Downtown Tokyo is crazy on Fridays." "I’m a lone wolf. Leave me alone."

mnemonics.meaning: Before you take the last measurement, you know you're on the brink of something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

sentences: 私の会社は破産寸前である。
My company is on the verge of bankruptcy.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 泊まる is "to stay the night." The noun version is a overnight stay or sleepover.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 泊まる, so pull from that and you shall know this.

sentences: うちの子、幼稚園のお泊まり会をすごく楽しみにしてたんだけど、風邪を引いちゃって、今抗生物質を飲ませたところなんです。だから、残念ながら今夜は欠席させて頂きます。
My kid was really looking forward to the kindergarten sleepover, but he got a cold and I just made him take antibiotics. So, sadly, he’ll be absent tonight.

mnemonics.meaning: If you only have one wing you only have part of a bird. Or a plane. Either way, you only have a part of it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大きなプロジェクトの一翼を担えることになりました。
I’ll handle part of the big project.

mnemonics.meaning: A grain's child is even smaller than a grain. It's a particle, sometimes even an atomic particle.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 光が粒子なのか波なのかを考えていて、昨日は眠れませんでした。
I was thinking about whether light was a particle or a wave and I couldn’t sleep last night.

mnemonics.meaning: A spicy hug is a hug that feels not so great. But, it's not really painful all at once, either. As you're receiving a spicy hug, you just have to show patience and endurance while it lasts.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn the reading of 抱's on'yomi reading, so think about how much patience and endurance you need to learn how to be good at bowling (ぼう).

sentences: 場違いだって思うかもしれませんが、私のためだと思って辛抱してください。
You may feel a little out of place, but please be patient for me.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 大リーグの試合で、ピッチャーがボールの代わりに桃を投げました。
The pitcher threw a peach instead of a ball in the MLB game.

mnemonics.meaning: A peach color is a peach color.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from the vocab readings (and kanji readings, actually) of the two kanji.

sentences: 桃色のバンで母親が迎えにきた時は、恥ずかしかったですね。
I was embarrassed when my mom came to pick me up in the peach colored van.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: この洋梨のマカロンは、お好みで冷やしても美味しく御賞味頂けます。
These Bartlett pear macarons can also be refrigerated if you’d like that.

mnemonics.meaning: A philosophy scholar (学者) is someone who studies philosophy. They're known as a philosopher.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その哲学者は強風を通って歩いたので、自分のベレー帽をしっかりと掴まなくてはならなかった。
The philosopher had to hang on to his beret as he walked through the strong wind.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 滑る is "to slide"? Then, how 台 is a counter for machines? In this case, this slippery machine is a slide, more specifically a playground slide.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 滑る and 台.

sentences: 甥っ子の誕生日祝いに滑り台を作ってるんですが、少々予定が遅れ気味なんですよね。
I’m making a slide for my nephew’s birthday, but I’m a little behind schedule.

mnemonics.meaning: Recreation and comfort are things you do for pleasure and amusement. So nice!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 娯楽小説を読むことの何が悪いって言うんですか？
What’s wrong with reading light novels?

mnemonics.meaning: The princess (formal name ender) is the princess, and you're talking to her politely. She is the princess.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the reading of 姫 and 様 combined together.

sentences: お迎えにあがりましたよ、僕の小さなお姫様。
I’m here to pick you up, my little princess.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be used to refer to a noble girl as well, as in a girl of the noble family.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: わかったわ。じゃあ、これからはアヤのこと、アヤ姫って呼ばないといけないの？
Okay, so from now on we have to call her Princess Aya?

mnemonics.meaning: A vermilion colored seal is a red seal. Just look up the (Japanese) word in Google Image search and you'll see what this is.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この紙に御朱印を押してもらえますか？
Could I get the red seal of the shogun on this paper?

mnemonics.meaning: A riddle riddle is a riddle, and it's also a puzzle or an enigma.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji you learned, twice. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 子どもはみんな謎々遊びをするのが好きだろう。
Pretty much all kids like solving riddles, right?
広告に釣られて謎々の本を買ってしまった。
The advert tempted into buying the riddle book.
この謎々が、分かる人〜？
Does anyone understand this riddle?

mnemonics.meaning: The right wing is the right wing. As in, "right wing politics" or "right wing beliefs."
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 右, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Those in the right wing love eating uni (う), not because they like the taste, but because uni is expensive. Picture some right-wing people in your mind right now and watch as they try really hard to pretend they like eating uni as they shovel buckets of it down their throats.

sentences: 自分は、極端な右翼思想を持って生まれたように感じます。
I feel that I was born with extreme right-wing ideas.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the meaning and the reading of the kanji: さむらい.

sentences: 「今の侍としての仕事が気に入らないのなら、他の仕事を探したら？」 「口で言うほど簡単じゃないよ。」
"If you don’t like your job as a samurai, why don’t you find another one?" "Easier said than done."

mnemonics.meaning: A sand hill is a sand dune.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その砂丘には駱駝もいるんですよ。
There are some camels on that sand dune.

mnemonics.meaning: A netting door is a screen door. Makes sense, right? Screen doors are like little meshy nets made into a door shape.
mnemonics.reading: You've seen 網 on its own. We're going to use that reading. Then, add the 戸 reading with rendaku and you have yourself あみど.

sentences: あの古い網戸は本当に気持ち悪いね。
That old screen door is so gross!

mnemonics.meaning: Earth and sand is earth and sand, or sediment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word and it uses the on'yomi for both kanji. This on'yomi for 砂 is a bit less common, and you haven't learnt it yet, so here's a mnemnonic to help you: If there's too much sediment, you need to speak to a shaman (しゃ) about it. Only a shaman has the power to get rid of all that earth and sand and get the river flowing again.

sentences: 川底にはたくさんの土砂がたまっている。
There's a lot of sediment in the riverbed.
津波で大量の土砂が二階の教室に流れ込んだ。
Due to the tsunami, a large amount of earth and sand flowed into the second-floor classroom.
地震の後には土砂災害の危険があります。
After an earthquake there's a danger of landslides.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: フグが僕のことをデブって呼ぶんだよね。自分のことを棚に上げてよく言うよ。
Fugu calls me fat. Talk about the pot calling the kettle black. (Literally: to talk about it while putting himself up on the shelf)

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 大きい方の犬は車庫にいて、もう一匹は室内にいるよ。
We keep our bigger dog in the garage and the other one in our house.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 堅い is "solid" or "tough." When your hand is solid and tough, it's solid and steady. If your hand is shaky, it's the opposite, or something.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the two words 手 and 堅い combined together. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 中々手堅い仕事みたいだから、葬儀屋になるための勉強をしようかなって思ってるんだよね。
I’m thinking of learning how to become an undertaker because it looks like a pretty secure job.

mnemonics.meaning: The fee for fragrance and spicy in your food is the fee of spices. If you don't pay your spices fee, you aren't going to have any spice or fragrance in your food. If you do, you'll have those things and your food will be awesome!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: クミンシードは、インドカレーには欠かせない香辛料のうちの一つです。
The cumin seed is one of the most important spices for Indian curry.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. That being said, this can also mean difficult or painful as well. I guess if you're in a spicy situation it's going to be a difficult one.
mnemonics.reading: Depending on the context, the reading for this word could be からい or つらい. The からい reading is the spicy one, you can remember that because that spicy feeling comes from (から) your mouth. The つらい reading is the difficult or painful one. You can remember this because two Ras (つら) are way more difficult to deal with than one Ra.

sentences: 「やばい〜！超辛い～！でも、このカレーすっげ〜美味しい！」
"Omg! My mouth is on fire, but this curry is sooo good!"

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: ニンニクの芽はいつもどうやって料理に使いますか？
How do you usually cook the garlic shoots?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 「彼女、もしかして本当は全然怒ってないんじゃない？」「ただの嵐の前の静けさだよ。」
"Isn’t it possible that she really isn’t that upset?" "This is just the calm before the storm."

mnemonics.meaning: A wild wave will make for some stormy seas or raging waves. Don't go out in these kinds of waves.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, 荒 (the secondary reading you learned with this kanji) and 波 (just the vocab version).

sentences: アイツはまだ社会の荒波に揉まれた事のないただの若造だよ。
He is just a young boy who hasn’t been tossed in the stormy seas of life yet.

mnemonics.meaning: This measurement also refers to a specific measurement, a "sun", which is about 3.03 centimeters. You'll hear it brought up from time to time to measure things, though usually with more traditional Japanese items.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the kanji! Congrats! Now to remember it's three point zero three centimeters.

sentences: 1寸は1尺の10分の1で、約3.03センチです。
1 sun is 1/10th of 1 shaku, which is approximately 3.03 centimeters.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Your teardrops are like little waves. What are they? They're 波だ (なみだ).

sentences: 面白過ぎて片腹が痛いし、涙も出てきたよ。
It’s so funny that my side hurts and there are tears in my eyes.

mnemonics.meaning: The feeling of teardrops is a feeling that makes you cry. But, it's not a bad feeling, these are tears of gratitude.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どんな時に人は感涙にむせび泣くと思いますか。
When do you think people would burst into tears of gratitude?

mnemonics.meaning: What can you see in the north that looks like a ladle and is made up of seven stars? That's the group of stars we call the Big Dipper or, depending on where you are in the world, perhaps the Plough.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji.

sentences: 北斗七星は七つの星で構成されています。
The Big Dipper is made up of seven stars.
晴れた日には、窓から北斗七星が見えるよ。
On a clear night, we can see the Big Dipper from our window.
この写真は、１１月３日未明の北斗七星です。
This photo is the Big Dipper before dawn on November 3.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading think about thunder. Back in the day, it was probably terrifyingly loud. Like the cry of the gods! Wait a sec, the "cry of the gods" would be 神鳴り (かみなり).

sentences: 雷の音で、洗濯物を取り入れなくちゃいけないことを思い出しました。
The thunder reminded us that we had laundry to bring inside.

mnemonics.meaning: Thunder that falls from the sky is a thunderbolt.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 落雷が直撃したのに、奇跡的に無傷だった。
Even though the thunderbolt was a direct hit, I was miraculously unhurt.

mnemonics.meaning: A thunder rain is a rain that's coming with thunder. For all intents and purposes, if you see this, you'll think thunderstorm.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the on'yomi readings. For 雨, you haven't seen the on'yomi reading, which is う. To remember this, just think about how in a thunderstorm, it rains uni (sea urchin). You go outside, dodging the thunder, to collect these uni.

sentences: 今朝の強烈な雷雨で停電になったので、今はインターネットが使えません。
The severe thunderstorm this morning caused a power outage, so I can’t use the internet right now.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. It also just sounds like can.

sentences: 私のお父さんは桃の缶詰工場で働いています。
My father works in a peach canning factory.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 紛らす means "to divert" or "to distract." This is when you're not doing the action, now, making this word to be diverted or to be distracted.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 紛らす.

sentences: 解熱剤が他の薬に紛れちゃってて、どれがどれだか分かりません。
The fever medicine slipped in with other pills and I’m not sure which one is which.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember 揺る which means "to shake" or "to jolt"? This is like that, but now you're not doing the shaking and jolting, making it to be shaken or to be jolted. You know this because it's really rare (れる) for you to be shaken like this.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 揺る.

sentences: 公園のブランコが風で揺れた。
The swings at the park swayed in the wind.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means split, so this verb has to do with something splitting.  This is an intransitive verb, so this verb means to be split, to be torn, or to burst apart.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 裂く.

sentences: 最近は毎朝、裂けるチーズを食べています。
Lately, I've been eating cheese that can be split (AKA string cheese) every morning.
ねえ、ケンイチ君。ジーンズの股が裂けてるよ。
Hey, Kenichi. Your jeans are torn at the crotch.
悲しすぎて、心が裂けちゃいそうだよ。
I'm so sad that my heart feels like it will burst apart.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 焦げる is "to be burned" or "to get burned." This word however is when you're doing the burning, making it to burn or to scorch. You know this because when it comes to burning, you pull out all the stops. You use lots of gas (がす) to burn whatever it is you burn.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 焦げる, so if you know that you know this word as well.

sentences: いつもトーストを真っ黒に焦がしてしまう。
I always burn my toast completely black.

mnemonics.meaning: 克服 is "conquest" so the verb version of that is to conquer.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 三歳の頃犬に噛まれてから、ずっと犬に恐怖心を抱いていたんですが、この小さな仔犬に出会って犬嫌いを克服しました。
I’ve been afraid of dogs since I was bitten by one when I was three, but I’ve overcome my hatred for them since meeting this little puppy.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means endure so the verb vocab version is to endure.
mnemonics.reading: Those who are able to endure are those who have had a lot of training. Who has had the most training of anyone? Ninjas. What group are they part of? The shinobi (しの).

sentences: 父さん、どうして僕たちはアイツらの侮辱を忍ばなきゃならないの？
Why do we have to endure their insults, dad?

mnemonics.meaning: The thing you want to take has escaped. Meaning you failed to catch this thing. This word is to fail to catch.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 取る and 逃がす.

sentences: 犯罪者を取り逃がすふりをするのは、ちょっとやり過ぎじゃない？
Don’t you think pretending that you failed to catch the criminal is a bit overkill?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fishing so the verb vocab version is to fish.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 後で何匹釣れたかお知らせしますね。
I’ll let you know how many fish we caught later.

mnemonics.meaning: 荒れる is "to be stormy" or "to be rough." This is when you do the stormy rough things. You go wild on everyone, trying to lay waste and to devastate everything around you.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 荒れる.

sentences: 昨夜車上荒らしにあって、マックを盗まれました。
My car was broken into last night and my mac was stolen.

mnemonics.meaning: 逃す is "to let go" or "to let escape." If something escapes your seeing, then you are going to overlook it.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 見 and 逃す.

sentences: その法律に抜け穴があることを今の今まで見逃していました。
I hadn’t noticed that there was a loophole in the law until now.

mnemonics.meaning: A dragon scroll is a dragon that's shaped kind of like a scroll, spinning around. This is a tornado.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. For 竜 just think about how it's a standing (立つ) dragon, because it would have to be if it's a tornado. Your まき reading comes from 巻く, but the kana is pushed into the kanji.

sentences: 昨夜、竜巻警報が出て、停電にもなりました。
There was a tornado warning and a power outage last night.

mnemonics.meaning: Fish thunder is underwater thunder that shoots at things and are kind of shaped like fish. That's a torpedo. Load the fish thunder!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 小包を開けると、中には自動追尾魚雷が入っていた。
When I opened the package there was a homing torpedo inside it.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scold and the verb vocab version also means to scold.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 二重瞼の整形手術をした時、親から貰った顔に傷をつけたと両親からこっぴどく叱られました。
When I got double eyelid surgery done, I was harshly scolded by my parents because I hurt the face I inherited from them.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shake so the verb vocab version is to shake.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 揺る.

sentences: コウイチが木を揺さぶったので、ビエットは枝に掴まった。
Viet held onto the branch because Koichi shook the tree.

mnemonics.meaning: Shake plus "to do" is the verb version of shake. That's to shake or to rock slowly.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 揺る.

sentences: 僕の伯父さんは、今まで蜂に刺されたことがなくて、どんなものか試してみたかったから、蜂の巣がある木を揺すったんだそうです。
It seems that my uncle shook a tree with a beehive in it because he had never been stung by a bee and wanted to try it out.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shout so the verb vocab version is to shout. Can also be to scream.
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading of this, just think about how you start to shout and to scream when you drink way too much sake (さけ).

sentences: 「感情を吐き出すために叫ぶのが終わったら、ちゃんと電気を消してね。」「了解。」
"Turn the light off when you’re done screaming about your emotions." "Roger."

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sink so the verb vocab version is to sink.  This is a transitive verb, so it's used when you're sinking something else. You can differentiate it from the intransitive 沈む by imaging that you're watching an enemy ship sink, and they shout out, "Who did this to me!" You respond, me (め). I did."
mnemonics.reading: When you sink something, like a battleship, you go on and say: "she's (しず) sunk, I sunk her." That's like your tagline, or something. You say it for some reason because you think it's cool.

sentences: 彼はソファに身を沈めながら、アカデミー賞の授賞式の生中継を観ています。
He is watching the broadcast of the Academy Awards ceremony and sinking into the sofa.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be a pagoda. If you think about it, pagodas were the towers of the olden days.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 五重の塔の売買契約の手付金を支払いました。
I paid the deposit on a contract for a five-storied pagoda.

mnemonics.meaning: バベル's 塔 is Babel's tower. That's the Tower of Babel.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the reading of the kanji.

sentences: バベルの塔に辿り着く一番速い方法はなんですか？
What’s the fastest way to get to the Tower of Babel?

mnemonics.meaning: If something has a nothing edge, it's probably unrelated to what you're doing. There's no edge, your stuff always has edges.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この田舎道は、渋滞とは無縁です。
This country road is free from traffic jams.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can also say it's scarlet red or blood as well, though more in a poetic sense, I'd say. I don't think you'll hear surgeons calling blood 朱.
mnemonics.reading: The reading あけ is like the beginning of 開ける, which means "to open." Just imagine you're opening (あけ) a person up, and out gushes a vermilion colored blood. You shouldn't open people up like that.

sentences: この布を朱に染めたいんです。
I want to dye this cloth vermilion.

mnemonics.meaning: I plus たち is we. Remember 私達? It's just like that. Remember, 俺 is going to be much more casual and rough sounding, so be careful to only use it amongst friends / when you're shaking someone down.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 俺たち、生き別れになっていた妹に会いに、来月北海道に行くんだ。
We’ll go to Hokkaido next month to meet our younger sister, who has been separated from us for all these years.

mnemonics.meaning: I with a ら on it makes it plural. It's less formal than 俺たち (if you've seen that word yet), but has the same meaning. It's we.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the kanji's reading.

sentences: ごめん。 俺らがこの会話をするのは明らかにすごく早すぎたよな。でも、ただ、俺はお前と結婚したいと思ってるってこと、言いたかったんだ。
I’m sorry. It’s obviously way too early for us to be having this conversation, but I just wanted to tell you that I want to marry you.

mnemonics.meaning: 荒い is rough. Double that to 荒々しい and you have the same thing: wild or rough.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 荒い. Since you already know that 々 means it repeats, you already know this reading!

sentences: 彼は荒々しい声で、寝ている時に奥さんが毎晩顔に小便を掛けてくることに怒り心頭していることを公言しました。
In a wild voice he proclaimed that he was totally “pissed off” at his wife for "pissing" on his face every night while he was sleeping.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: In each political  wing there are two bosses (つばさ). It's a weird system, but that's how they're doing it these days. Imagine your favorite / least favorite political wings, all with two bosses, arguing with each other.

sentences: つけたい翼を選んで下さいね。
Please pick up the wings you want to wear.

mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means again.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means house.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means protect.

A spoon to measure a geoduck is a very approximate measurement. Geoducks are big, spoons are small. Still, we'll get the approximation going, right? Do the comparison. A spoonful of geoduck aka a whole geoduck on a spoon. This is a spoonful, right? This is what the recipe wanted, I think...
mnemonics.reading: Maybe this is too much geoduck, even if we're going for an approximate. So, you take the core (ころ) of the geoduck and measure that instead.  That's a little better. Not too much geoduck. Still a lot, but more like an approximate.

mnemonics.meaning: When you leave grains in your mouth for long enough, they'll turn into flowers of bacteria. These aren't the nice, pretty flowers you'd give your mom on Mother's Day. These are little bacteria flowers that are taking over your mouth. Maybe brush your teeth next time. Imagine how much bacteria would flower in your mouth if you just left grains in there for like, I dunno, a month. That's a lot of nasty bacteria!
mnemonics.reading: There is a lot of this bacteria in the King (きん) of England's mouth. He eats a lot of grains, and he won't let anyone touch his mouth to clean it, but he refuses to do things himself... so it's absolutely chock full of bacteria. Picture the King's mouth up close. Look at all the bacteria squiggling around and through his teeth and gums. Bleh! Barf!

mnemonics.meaning: Something made of gold stands in a village. It's a bell!  The village bell. Every village has a bell of its own, standing tall and proud and shiny in the middle for everyone to see and hear.
mnemonics.reading: The bell rings whenever the Shougun (しょう) arrives in the village. Its ringing echoes throughout the entire village so everyone knows they have to come out and pay their respects. The Shougun bell even sounds like it's warning you that the Shougun has arrived. It makes a loud, low shooooouu shooou sound.

mnemonics.meaning: The boat radical and the boat kanji are the same! Boats are boats, you know?
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the kanji 船, though there's an extra reading there as well, ふな. They're close, so you should be able to remember it based off of ふね. Try to answer ふな a couple times when doing your reviews. It'll help when we get to the vocab part.

mnemonics.meaning: The woman who makes your house a home is your bride. She's in your house because you married her. Thus, she's your bride. Your house is now a home.
mnemonics.reading: Now that you have a bride in your house, you can get rid of your maid (よめ), since your bride will do all the cleaning. Your bride is very upset at how sexist you're being right now, and makes you do all the cleaning instead. The maid still gets fired.

mnemonics.meaning: Looking up to the cliff, you see the trees, and the sun shining down on them. Using the sun and the trees (up there on the cliff), you've devised a method to tell what time of the year it is, based on where the shadow from the trees fall. After a while, you develop a bigger system. This system is a whole calendar. Look at the different shadow patterns. Know what they all mean. This is your very own calendar system.
mnemonics.reading: Remember the word 歴史, which means "history"? Using a calendar, you too can remember history (otherwise, who knows when these things happened). So, the reading for this kanji is the same as the reading for 歴史's beginning, because they're related. Make sure you make the connection between the word 歴史 and this kanji. If you do, it'll be much easier to remember the reading of this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: The sun is being blocked by a rain cloud, making it cloudy. You look up at the sky, trying to find the sun, but it's so cloudy that you can't even find where the sun should be.
mnemonics.reading: Remember 雲? It means "cloud" and has the same reading as "cloudy," making them both くも. If it's cloudy there are clouds, so if you can read one, you can read the other!

mnemonics.meaning: An alligator is considerably dangerous. Considerably terrifying too. Considerably [put your scary adjective here]. The radical meaning and the kanji meaning aren't the same, but we'll get through this together. Just put a considerable amount of effort into this and you'll learn considerably more quickly.
mnemonics.reading: Speaking of considerably terrifying, that place known as Narnia (なり) is pretty terrifying. Not sure why children want to go there. Also, things that are "considerably" anything start somewhere. They become (なり) whatever "considerable" thing they are now from something smaller before.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a sock circle in the dirt on your way to cram school. Every day after school you walk straight until you get to the sock circle, you run around it, and then head off in any direction. Somehow it always leads to cram school. Picture the sock circle in the dirt in your mind. Now look up and see cram school through the trees.
mnemonics.reading: The sock circle seems to have a bit of a gravitational pull, so to make sure you get to cram school on time you have to juke (じゅく) around it every day, to make sure you can get past it. Normal kids would probably try to juke cram school, since it's hard and it's more school than they think they need. But you're a good kid who want to cram, so you juke the circle instead.

mnemonics.meaning: From the mouth of your older brother comes... a curse! Imagine him cursing you. He's not a fan of you, since you are siblings, but to think he'd go so far as to put a curse on you? You can't believe it. What kind of curse did he put upon you?
mnemonics.reading: Turns out, he put the no road (のろ) curse on you, meaning you can never walk on roads. In your mind, walk around the area where you live. Think about the places you can go that aren't roads. If you try to walk on a road, you can't. This is the no road curse, after all.

mnemonics.meaning: After the tsunami the sun comes out again and shines on these spikes. They were super wet before, but you figure the sun probably dried them off. You lean down to touch them and nope, they's still damp. The sun did a little bit of work, so they aren't wet, but they aren't dry either. They're damp.
mnemonics.reading: As you're looking at the damp spikes, a shih tzu (しつ) prances over, slips on the damp ground, and falls right on the spike! Oh nooo! Luckily the shih tzu is kinda pinned between the spikes, so it isn't dead or anything, but it's definitely stuck. You try to help it out, but you slip because it's so damp and you fall in too! Imagine the sound of your cries mixing in with the shih tzu's as you both struggling to get out but can't because of how damp everything is.

mnemonics.meaning: The grains you have stored in your house reflect on your earnings. If you earn a lot of money, you have more grains. Imagine looking at the grains in the houses of people who make vastly different earnings. The poor artist has only a few sacks of grain. The rich samurai has an extra house just for holding his grain. That's how you know he has much higher earnings than the artist.
mnemonics.reading: Another way to check someone's earnings is to see if they have a car (か). Would someone who doesn't make a lot of money have a car? No! Picture your own earnings. Can you afford a lot of grains and a car?

mnemonics.meaning: I have sick in my skin. Just look at it, it doesn't look too good. Whenever I have sickness in my skin, I know that I'm probably exhausted. Imagine yourself being really, really exhausted. Then look at your skin. It's all sickly looking.
mnemonics.reading: When you're exhausted, your muscles are all probably worn out. Being this worn out, you can probably imagine that your body is all heated (ひ) up, from all the exercising. Imagine exercising so much that your body gets all exhausted and heated (ひ) up.

mnemonics.meaning: A sheep with feathers (and presumably wings, too) is able to fly. Imagine the sheep with feathers taking off and flying around. It's an odd sight, but makes sense, kind of.
mnemonics.reading: Using this sheep that can fly, you're going to get rich! But there's a problem... you have to catch the sheep. So, you get some cake (かけ) and use it to lure the sheep to your trap, where you catch it! Ha HA! Everyone knows sheep love cake. Works every time. Now this flying sheep is yours!

mnemonics.meaning: I'm putting all my shellfish on someone, hoping they'll win the race! This is a gamble and you're gambling. Remember, shellfish used to be used as money. So if you're betting shellfish on someone, you're just gambling. And you probably won't get any of those shellfish back.
mnemonics.reading: If you win this gamble you'll have enough shellfish to buy a brand new car (か)! If you go to any of those fancy (and not so fancy) gamble-places, they always have a car sitting in the middle of the room. Usually rotating, really slowly, to make you want it more, making you gamble more.

mnemonics.meaning: Coming down with the rain is two spikes. They go right through two ghosts. The ghosts are pinned to the ground by the spikes, unable to move.
mnemonics.reading: You come across the ghosts, who are stabbed into the ground. "Please," they beg. "Please use that ray (れい) gun that's in that row (りょう) boat and end our suffering." A ray gun, coincidentally, is the only thing that can kill a ghost, and there it lays, just out of reach. You'll have to be the one to pull the trigger of the ray gun. Do you pick up the ray gun out of the row boat to destroy the ghosts?

mnemonics.meaning: Tsunami vs lifeguard. Who will win? After the water drains away, we find the lifeguard in the gutter. To be fair, it's pretty obvious who would win. Nobody knows what that lifeguard was thinking.
mnemonics.reading: In the gutter is a lifeguard, so Emperor こういち decides to survey the damage. "This lifeguard didn't believe in the power of kanji learning," こういち says to the press. "He was punished by the great Crabigator, who sent its tsunami as a warning for all." Hint: when you see the "lifeguard" radical, the reading is probably going to be こう.

mnemonics.meaning: I protect my own animals by going to hunt other animals... like wolves and cougars and such.  My animals can't protect themselves, that's why I hunt other animals instead.
mnemonics.reading: I also do all my hunts using a car (か). I just run those animals down with my car. Kind of cheating, but vroom vroom anyways. Imagine hunting down animals in a car.

mnemonics.meaning: If you've been to the moon in the past, you had to get the special stamp on your leg. This leg stamp not only proved you went, but lets everyone around you know you've been to the moon before!
mnemonics.reading: You've only met one other person with the same mark on their leg and it was Kyaku (きゃく) the customer. Kyaku visits many places all over the world, so it only makes sense that they've also been off-world too. Picture Kyaku lifting up their pant leg and showing you all the stamps from all the different places they've been. There are even some planets on there!

mnemonics.meaning: When the tsunami struck, it hit your tent full of beans. When you lost your tent of beans, you had a moment of lucidity. You don't need so much stuff, you can live without it! Then you went back to being crazy. That moment of lucidity was only temporary, and you go back to stockpiling beans.
mnemonics.reading: Your lucidity is clear to everyone because you wear a suit (す). Everyone knows that lucid people wear suits! Imagine yourself wearing a sharp suit and being a model of lucidity

mnemonics.meaning: A dirt demon is just a lump. Just like a dust bunny is just a clump of dust. Picture a lump of dirt. Is there a demon hiding under there? No. It's just a saying, ya nerd.
mnemonics.reading: Have you ever heard of the game "Katamari Damacy?" That game is about a little guy who rolls a ball around, turning it into a bigger and bigger lump. What do you think the Katamari (かたまり) part means? It means lump, of course. If you don't know the game and have never heard the music (especially), it's great stuff! If you have, this word will be really easy for you. If you haven't, look it up!

mnemonics.meaning: The animal king? He's just this guy who lives in the forest and thinks he's king of all the animals. He's a lunatic, though. While we're speaking of animals, he's absolutely bat sh*t crazy.
mnemonics.reading: You might see that crazy lunatic hanging around the outskirts of きょうと. He'll lurk near your trash cans and scream, "I AM THE ANIMAL KING!" and run away with some orange peels. I think he maybe got too friendly with some raccoons and beavers and went crazy. Watch out for him if you live in きょうと, rabies is no joke.

mnemonics.meaning: A woman who is a nurse should be called miss. Compare this to a man who is a nurse. You should probably call him mister. That's why you know a woman who is a nurse is "miss."
mnemonics.reading: "Call me Miss Jourm (じょう)," Jourm says to you. When you think of "miss," remember the time that Jourm asked you to call him "Miss Jourm." You thought he was a big, ten foot tall guy, but now he suddenly wants you to call him Miss Jourm. Okay, that's up to Jourm so you should respect that.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're showing me your "spirit fruit" then you are just naked. You're nude. You know what I mean by "spirit fruit" –– yep, it's out there and you're naked.
mnemonics.reading: Known for being naked (and showing you his spirit fruit) is the ancient Egyptian god Ra (ら). Don't look up "Ra Egyptian god naked" in Google. Nothing good will come of it. Instead, just imagine your own Egyptian god Ra being naked in front of you.

mnemonics.meaning: An axe is sticking in the ground on top of a mountain. It's sticking into the very peak. Because why would you bother to stick your axe anywhere else on the mountain to prove you climbed it?  Picture that axe, jammed into the mountain's peak. The person who did that must have been really cool to get all the way up there.
mnemonics.reading: You can't help but gawk (がく) at the peak. Somehow it looks even higher now.  Go ahead, imagine this peak with an axe in it and actually gawk a bit at how far you have to go to get that high.

mnemonics.meaning: Below this canopy of trees is a stone. Since it's the only stone here, you make sure to polish it. It's a single, perfectly round stone under this canopy of trees. It didn't start this way, but thanks to all the polishing you did, it has become nice and smooth.
mnemonics.reading: You polish the stone due to your meager (みが) lifestyle. There's only this one stone under these trees, and polishing the stone is the only job here. Still, you don't get much from it, thus the meager life of polishing your stone.

mnemonics.meaning: This building now has a cloud over it, creating shade. This shade is really convenient right now, because it's been such a hot day. Ahh, shade is so nice and cool.
mnemonics.reading: The building that's getting this nice shade is the inn (いん) you're staying at. Picture an inn with a cloud right above it right now. Look at the cloud-shaped shade keeping everyone visiting the inn cool and sunburn-free.

mnemonics.meaning: The moon table is a table that's made entirely of skin. You thought the table was made of moon, with all those pores and such, but when you look more closely, you realize it's skin. Disgusting, porous, skin. Touch it and feel the "moon table." You know it's not made of moon. How ridiculous.
mnemonics.reading: But, when you go to touch this "moon table" made of skin, you realize that it's harder (はだ) than you expected.  You'd think skin would be softer, but it's pretty hard. Much harder than you expected.

mnemonics.meaning: The cloud floating above a demon has its soul in it. If you can manage to get through to the demon, to make it see that it doesn't have to be evil, it might remember who it is and return to the spirit it once was. Right now, however, the demon is looming over you, and you can't see anything in the cloud above its head. It just looks mad, like it's gonna pummel you or eat you.
mnemonics.reading: You shout out and beg its soul for help until, finally, you see the cloud take the shape of a condor (こん). Aha! "You were a condor before you became a demon! Remember who you are and turn back!" POOF! Now there's a condor spirit floating in front of you, crying. "Thank you, human. You've saved my soul!" it says, and float/flies off and disappears.

mnemonics.meaning: The spear radical and the spear kanji are the same! Spears are spears. It makes sense!
mnemonics.reading: You take this spear and stab it into a cow. "MOO (む)!" it cries. The cow bites the spear out of your hands and stabs you back. "MOO!" you scream. How do you like it? Don't stab cows with spears, you monster.

mnemonics.meaning: When your eye catches an omen, it's only natural that you will stare at it.  You don't see omens that often, so of course you're going to stare. We'll imagine what the omen is in the reading mnemonic.
mnemonics.reading: As you stare at the omen, you see Mrs. Chou (ちょう) knocking down buildings, putting nails on the street, and making herself way longer than you ever thought possible. Oh, and there she is, destroying the world. Whenever you see an omen (radical), remember that the omen will probably have Mrs. Chou in it!

mnemonics.meaning: You feel like a stone (again!). When you feel like a stone, your body is feeling very stiff. Touch your stiff body. It feels like a stone.
mnemonics.reading: You remember how you used to cure these stiff body times: your old friend こういち would just massage them out for you. If only you could ask こういち to give you massages again, but he's too busy for you, now (being emperor and all).

mnemonics.meaning: The toe is early. I hate it when the toes show up early. Well, if the toes are going to show up this early, I guess it's best to put them on the table. See all the toes lined up on the table. They are the ones who showed up early.
mnemonics.reading: What do all the early toes on the table do while they're waiting until it's the right time? They just sit around on their table, talking (たく). Imagine the toes talking to each other. "Hello Mr. Toe!" "Oh hello other Mr. Toe!"

mnemonics.meaning: If there's a treasure chest, there's always a villain too. The villain is trying to get to the treasure chest before the hero of the story. And the villain always gets to the treasure chest first, often via nefarious means. That villain is SO important when it comes to treasure chests.
mnemonics.reading: The villain beat you all the way to きょうと to get this particular treasure chest.  Arrrg! If only you had been closer to きょうと! Then you might have beaten this dastardly villain.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami in the shape of a dragon flies off the cliff, then comes crashing down to the ground. This skinny tsunami of water flying down to the ground is a waterfall. Can you see why a tsunami dragon (especially the Asian skinny snake-like kind) could be a waterfall? Try to imagine it.
mnemonics.reading: Despite how cool a dragon waterfall is, to be honest it's also pretty tacky (たき). Now imagine it being a bit tacky. Dragons are alright but... you just don't want to overdo it, you know?

mnemonics.meaning: The well radical and the well kanji are the same. Make sure you remember that this is a well of water not a "well, actually."
mnemonics.reading: There is a single well in each and every town thanks to the Shougun (しょう). One of the first things he decreed when he came to power was that all people have the right to easy and central access to water. The Shougun also really likes watching people do physical labor, so forcing his citizens to haul water up from the well is a plus too. But hey, they aren't thirsty!

mnemonics.meaning: いつ is "when" and 頃 is "about." Combine those together and you have "about when?" or "how soon?"
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, just rendaku'd.

sentences: トーフグはいつ頃Eブックマーケットに参入するつもりですか？
How soon will Tofugu enter into the e-book market?

mnemonics.meaning: A warn bell is a bell that goes off when you need to be warned about something. This is usually an alarm bell or a fire bell.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 研究者たちは、どれだけ速く氷山が溶け出しているかについて警鐘を鳴らしている。
Researchers are sounding the alarm on how quickly the icebergs are melting.

mnemonics.meaning: The year approximate is your approximate age.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the reading of the vocab version of 年 plus 頃, put together.

sentences: うちの年頃の娘に一体何をしてくれたんだ？
What have you done with my adolescent daughter?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. When used as a suffix, it means approximate time and around (as in "around 3:00").
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Bear in mind that it's pronounced ころ when it's a noun, but it's usually ごろ when it's a suffix, though some people say ころ in both cases.

sentences: じゃあ、7時頃また電話しますよ。
Well, I'll call you again around 7 o'clock.
あの頃、俺は人気者だったんだよ。
I was popular back then.
今日のお昼の三時頃、この公園でツキノワグマが目撃されました。
Around three o’clock this afternoon, a moon bear was seen in this park.

mnemonics.meaning: A villain who is bad is the most atrocious and fiendish villain of them all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 誰もが、その凶悪犯が刑務所で大人しく刑期を務めるのは無理だろうと思っていました。
Everyone believed that the atrocious criminal would not fare well in prison.

mnemonics.meaning: A thin bacteria is... well... a bacteria. I guess all bacteria are really thin. So thin you can't see them with your naked eye, in fact.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

sentences: 最近真剣に細菌について勉強をし始めました。
Recently, I started seriously studying bacteria.

mnemonics.meaning: Your 趣味 is your hobby. It's the thing you do on habit. A bad hobby is a habit that you do all the time that's no good. This is a bad habit.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 母は、父が悪趣味な人形を集めることを禁止しました。
My mom forbade my dad from collecting tasteless dolls.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Seeing the bell, you decide you need to ring it. You take your cane (かね) and hit the bell as hard as you can, making it chime.

sentences: 私が旅行者だと言うと、男は鐘の形をしたお守りの値段を明らかに釣り上げたが、何だかそいつに悪い気がして、そのまま何も言わずに言われた通りの値段を払ったんだよ。
Apparently he raised the price of the bell shaped charm since I told him that I was a tourist, but I felt a little sorry for him, so I didn’t say anything and paid the price he told me anyway.

mnemonics.meaning: The noun version of gamble is gambling or betting or a gamble or a bet. Whatever you do, put it all on black 13. Trust me.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: あいつとの賭けに勝ったよ。
I won a bet against him.

mnemonics.meaning: A small boat is a boat or small craft. If something is a "big boat" it's better to call it a "ship" I think, which is why this is just a boat.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are all ones you've seen before. 小 uses its こ reading, so just think of this like a "child boat." This makes sense because it's small. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 太平洋上には小舟がひしめきあっていた。
The Pacific Ocean was filled with little boats.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Note that this word isn't usually used by itself (that would be 船). It's usually attached to things that are boat-related, but I wanted you to learn it individually so you can use it that way.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Also the same as 船.

sentences: いさり舟をハンマーで叩いて破壊した。
I destroyed the fishing boat with a hammer.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 靴下を裏返しに履いちゃうと、嫁が怒ってうるさいんだわ。
My wife gets upset with me whenever I wear my socks inside out.

mnemonics.meaning: An electricity table is a calculator. Why is this? You can think about it in a couple of different ways. Maybe in the past, a calculator (aka abacus) would take up a whole table, making this "electric" version a calculator. Or, maybe it can be used to solve tables. Wrong kind of table, but should help you to remember the meaning of this word.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 頼むから電卓を叩くのをやめてくれ。気が狂いそうになるだろ！
Please stop drumming on the calculator. You’re driving me crazy!

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: When looking at a calendar, the 子読み (こよみ) of it is to... well... not be able to read it at all. Because, children can't really read. So, when you look at a calendar you have to explain it to a child, since they cannot read it.

sentences: うちの会社は暦通りの営業になります。
Our company’s business days follow the regular calendar.

mnemonics.meaning: The heaven well is the well that goes up into the heavens. This is above you, and it is a ceiling. Maybe the "well" part is referring to the chimney that goes up through the ceiling to the heavens when you look up in a super old house?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the rendaku.

sentences: ある日天井に小さな穴が空いてるのを見つけたんですが、ストーカーがたまに屋根裏に上ってその穴から私のことを覗いていたことが後から判明したんです。
One day I saw a small hole in the ceiling, then later I found out that I had a stalker who would occasionally peep at me through the hole from my attic.

mnemonics.meaning: A ghost garden is where many ghosts are harvested and where many ghosts grow. This is a cemetery.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 家族でうちの犬をペット専用霊園に連れて行きました。
My family took our puppy to a pet cemetery.

mnemonics.meaning: The West's calendar shows the history and time period of "The West." To the Japanese and Chinese, this era is known as the Christian Era. It also used to be used as a way to refer to the Western Calendar, though we usually just say カレンダー nowadays.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 昭和は西暦何年に終わったんですか？
What year in the Western calendar did the Showa era end?

mnemonics.meaning: The noun version of cloudy is cloudy weather or cloudiness. In some cases, this can also refer to the type of fog you'd find on a window or your glasses. Despite being a noun in Japanese, you'll actually see this translated as the adjective "cloudy" in English a lot. Don't let that fool you, though, it still behaves as a noun in Japanese! It's just another example of word types not quite matching up between English and Japanese.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 実は、眩しい午後の日差しの下よりも、曇りの日の方が写真撮影には適しています。
Cloudy days are actually better for photography than bright afternoon sunlight.
曇りとは、空の９割以上が雲でおおわれている状態のことです。
Cloudy weather means that more than 90% of the sky is covered in clouds.
窓の曇りが中々とれない。
I'm having trouble defogging the windows.

mnemonics.meaning: Stiff freight always has to be paid for in coins, because coins are also stiff. You can't go paying for something stiff with something not stiff, that would make no sense at all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 十円または百円硬貨を入れてください。
Please insert a ten-yen or hundred-yen coin.
祖母は財布の中に硬貨を貯めていました。
My grandmother saved coins in her wallet.
もう製造されていない硬貨にはどんなものがありますか。
What are some coins that are no longer being produced?

mnemonics.meaning: You're all naked, which makes you completely naked or totally naked.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 一度しかない人生だろ！なぁ！一緒に全裸でスカイダイビングしに行こうぜ。すんげぇいい経験になると思うんだよね。
You only live once! Come on. You should go skydiving nude with me. It would be a great experience for us.

mnemonics.meaning: It's possible that it's considerably considerable. It's considerably, fairly, and quite... something. Also please note that this is almost always written in kana and not kanji. But, we're learning kanji here, so gosh darn it we're going to learn some kanji.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 日本で初恋の人にバッタリ出くわした時は、可也驚きました。
I was quite surprised when I bumped into my first love in Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned in the kanji.

sentences: 塾に何か問題でもあるの？
What’s the matter with your cram school?

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 学生 is "student"? This plays off that. A cram school "student" is a student of a cram school, a cram school student.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は塾生たちの中で一番記憶力が悪かった。
He has the worst memory out of all the cram school students.

mnemonics.meaning: Despite looking like an adjective this is a noun. It means the same thing as the kanji: curse.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 魔女はお姫様に、コップを逆さまにしか持てなくする呪いをかけた。
The witch put a curse on the princess that made it so she could only hold cups upside down.

mnemonics.meaning: A villain vessel is a vessel used by a villain. This vessel holds bullets, and is a dangerous weapon.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「アチョーーーーーー!」と叫び声を上げながら、コウイチはビエトの手から凶器を叩き落とした。
As he screamed, "Achooo!" Koichi knocked the dangerous weapon from Viet’s hand.

mnemonics.meaning: An eating table is a dining table.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私がお皿を洗うから、あなたは食卓を綺麗にしてくれる？いいかしら？
I’ll wash the dishes and you can set the table for me. Is that okay?

mnemonics.meaning: A reject water gutter is drainage, which we also call a drain, or a gutter. This word covers both the drain in your sink or bathtub, and roadside gutters.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お風呂の排水溝が髪の毛で詰まっちゃったみたいなの。
It looks like hair clogged the drain for the bathtub.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 戸籍 is the family register? This is referring to that, and that makes this word mean entry in family register.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 結婚式の前に入籍をする予定です。
We are planning to be entered in the family register before the wedding ceremony.

mnemonics.meaning: An evil ghost isn't so much a ghost as it is an evil spirit.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Note this uses the secondary 霊 reading of りょう, so imagine an evil spirit rowing a boat.

sentences: 悪霊がいると聞いたので、トンネルの中ではスピードを上げて運転しました。
She drove speeding through the tunnel because she heard there was an evil spirit in there.

mnemonics.meaning: You're exhausted from labor. From this, you're showing fatigue and weariness.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今納税の手続きをしているんだけど、もう疲労困憊だよ。
I’m doing the taxes and I’m already totally exhausted.

mnemonics.meaning: Skin color is flesh colored or skin colored.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings of each kanji, 肌 and 色 combined into one.

sentences: その男は強引な押し売りで私に肌色のクレヨンを一箱売りつけました。
The guy used high pressure sales tactics to sell me a box of skin colored crayons.

mnemonics.meaning: A "ばい" bacteria is a germ. In case you're wondering, the ばい is referring to the kanji 黴, but people don't usually write that part.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: ホームレスだからって、俺がまるでばい菌のように人にジロジロ見られるのは、とても腹立たしい。
Even though I’m homeless, it’s really irritating when people stare at me like I’m some kind of germ.

mnemonics.meaning: A deceased ghost is a ghost (all ghosts are deceased). Can also refer to "the dead."
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 亡霊はめげずに、人々を怖がらせ続けました。
The ghost continued to scare people without getting depressed.

mnemonics.meaning: A shade energy is a shady feeling. It's a feeling of gloom and melancholy.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: アイツのYoutubeビデオを見るまでは、てっきり陰気な男だと思っていたよ。
I was certain he was a melancholy guy until I saw his Youtube videos.

mnemonics.meaning: Bird skin is goosebumps. Makes sense, since a goose is a bird and a bird's skin is bumpy.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the individual vocab readings of the two kanji, 鳥 and 肌.

sentences: 「ゴキブリ」という名前を聞くだけで、鳥肌が立ちます。
I get goosebumps just from hearing the name "cockroach."

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  What goes in the gutter? 水. But, the reading isn't exactly right. It's みぞ not みず, but close enough to create a hook.

sentences: コインパーキングの横の溝に、万札が落ちてるのを見つけたんだよ。
I found a 10,000 yen bill in a ditch beside a coin operated parking space.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're half naked you're half nude or half naked.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: きゃー！たった今夢が叶っちゃった！半裸のイケメンが淹れたての珈琲を飲みながら、私が目を覚ました瞬間に「おはよう」って言ってくれるっていう夢が！
Ahh! My dream just came true! It was the dream where a half naked hunk said "Good morning" the moment I woke up, while drinking freshly brewed coffee!

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though you'll want to know that this refers most specifically to human skin.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: その温泉に入った後は、お肌がツルツルになるよ。
Your skin will be really smooth after bathing in the hot spring.

mnemonics.meaning: An "add dampness container" is a container that adds dampness to the air. That's a humidifier.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 最近加湿器の調子が悪いんだよね。
Something has been wrong with my humidifier.

mnemonics.meaning: A hunt person is a person who hunts. A hunter.
mnemonics.reading: You learned the reading of 狩 when you learned the kanji, but the reading for 人 is totally irregular. Just imagine that you're hunting a reindeer named Rudolph (りゅうど). He has an unusually red nose, which makes him easy to spot and puts him at a bit of a disadvantage.

sentences: 狩人が週休二日制だってのは初耳だな。
I didn’t know the hunters used the five-day workweek system.

mnemonics.meaning: You have the noun version of hunt. That is hunting.
mnemonics.reading: The reading uses the reading from the kanji.

sentences: 来週はずっと山で狩りをしている予定です。
I’ll be hunting in the mountains all of next week.

mnemonics.meaning: A ghost feeling is inspiration. For some reason, the feeling of ghosts is the feeling of inspiration. I guess a ghost goes inside you and makes you feel this inspiration? Oh, wait, you can feel that because you have the sixth sense.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女は非常に霊感の強い霊能力者で、あの世の人と話をすることができます。
She’s a spiritual person with a strong sixth sense and can talk to people on the other side.

mnemonics.meaning: The black tide isn't what you think, most likely. This is the Japan current, aka the Kuroshio Current. It's a Northern flowing  current on the West side of the Pacific Ocean. Have you heard of the Gulf Stream? It's kind of like that.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the two kanji, put together. 黒 and 潮.

sentences: 黒潮の流域とは正確にはどこになりますか？
Where exactly is the basin of the Kuroshio Current?

mnemonics.meaning: The near approximate is the approximate time that was near to you. This period of time is the lately period of time. It's recently.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 近い and 頃 put together.

sentences: 近頃は製菓工場で夜勤の仕事をしているんだ。
Recently I’ve been working the graveyard shift in a confectionery factory.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 足, which also means leg and foot.

sentences: 夜になると脚がムズムズして、よく眠れないんです。
My legs are restless at night and I can’t sleep well.

mnemonics.meaning: A far distance detachment is a distance that is far. It is long distance. Also remember that 距離 is a "distance" so a far distance is a long distance.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本では、遠距離通学や遠距離通勤はよくあることです。
In Japan, having a long distance commute to school or work is pretty common.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Recognize this word? Na naaa na na na na na na naaa ♬.

sentences: 店に入ると、カウンターにドンと置かれた肉の塊がまず一番に目についた。
When I went in the store the first thing I noticed was the lump of meat that was placed on the counter.

mnemonics.meaning: The former calendar is the calendar from before. It's the lunisolar calendar and the traditional Japanese calendar. Certainly not the current calendar, anyways.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 旧暦の正月といえばいつになりますかね。
When will it be the lunar calendar’s New Year?

mnemonics.meaning: Lunatic energy is madness and insanity.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その申し出を断るなんて狂気の沙汰だよ。
You must be insane to decline that offer.

mnemonics.meaning: I'm offering to stand up and announce what's on the menu for today. I'll tell everyone about today's meal plan. This word doesn't mean the kind of physical menu you see in a restaurant, but rather a menu, or meal plan, in the sense of the foods you're planning to eat.
mnemonics.reading: You didn't learn this reading for 献 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm actually announcing the menu for condors (こん). You thought I was going to tell you what's on the menu for humans? No no, that's a surprise. Condors need a heads-up for these things, because meals are extremely important to condors, given their size and everything.

sentences: そろそろ今晩の献立を考えないと。
I need to start thinking about the menu for tonight.
全員に喜んでもらえる献立を考えるのは難しい。
It is difficult to come up with a menu that will please everyone.
私は、いつも冷蔵庫の中身を見て一週間の献立を立てます。
I always do my weekly meal plan by looking at the contents of my refrigerator.

mnemonics.meaning: When you control your hand an approximate amount, you are going to be a very moderate and reasonable person.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 手頃な値段ですね。
This is a reasonable price, isn’t it?

mnemonics.meaning: A damp energy is a feeling of dampness. It is moisture and humidity.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful of the shortening, and the irregular reading for 気.

sentences: 日本の梅雨は湿気が多いので嫌いです。
I don’t like the rainy season in Japan because it’s very humid.

mnemonics.meaning: The mountain peaks are just the mountains. Just because you can only see the peaks doesn't mean the rest of the mountain doesn't exist.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この山岳地帯では、少なくともあと三ヶ月は冬の季節が続くだろうね。
Winter will continue for at least three more months in this mountain district.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: You are naked now. You used to wear a car, but you don't have it anymore (and you're not wearing it). You had a car (はだか), but now you don't have a car. That's what you'll explain when someone asks you why you're naked.

sentences: キモイ！今あそこの横断歩道で、裸に袖無しエプロンを着た男を見かけたんだけど。警察に通報した方がいいかな。
Gross! I just saw a naked dude wearing just a sleeveless apron at the crosswalk over there. Should we call the police?

mnemonics.meaning: 分裂 means "split" or "division." The nucleus version of this split is nuclear fission.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 核分裂の過程について、分かりやすいスライドショーを作ってもらえますか。
Can you make an easy-to-understand slide show on the process of nuclear fission?

mnemonics.meaning: An ocean gutter is an ocean trench.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 鰻がフィリピン海溝の近くで産卵することは、フィリピン人に知られているのでしょうか。
I wonder if Filipinos know that the spawning place for eels is close to the Philippine Trench.

mnemonics.meaning: The young approximate is the approximate age of when you were young. This, approximately, is one's youth or early life.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 若い and 頃 combined into one.

sentences: 若い頃は食べ物について気にしなかったけど、今はお医者さんに糖尿病予備軍だって言われたので、食べ物に気をつけるようになったし、いつもレシピに書かれてるよりも少ない砂糖を入れるようにもなりました。
When I was young, I didn’t care about what I ate, but now I do and I always add a little less sugar than the recipe calls for because my doctor told me that I’m at risk for diabetes.

mnemonics.meaning: A small bundle is merely a package. Something big would be a big package, I guess.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 小 (which is a reading you've seen a couple times now, I'm sure) and 包み, with the み pushed inside the package. Beware of the somewhat weird rendaku. You don't see づ too often.

sentences: この小包は、ほんの友情の印です。
This package is just a symbol of our friendship.

mnemonics.meaning: A polish is a polish or even a shine.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: Excelのスキルに磨きをかけて、仕事が見つかればいいな、と思っています。
I am hoping to find a job by polishing up my Excel skills.

mnemonics.meaning: A righteousness cram school is, for some reason, a private school. Maybe because they don't think the public cram schools are any good, so they take their righteousness somewhere else to start a private one? I'm not sure.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 義塾に通い始めた初日、思いっきり場違いだと感じました。
I felt completely out of place on my first day of private school.

mnemonics.meaning: You stare at hope. It looks good. That is your prospect and view, as you stare at hope.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: そのホテルの部屋からは美しく青い海を眺望することができました。
We were able to view the beautiful blue ocean from our hotel room.

mnemonics.meaning: A waterfall river is a river that's moving like a waterfall! Fast and furious! Water that moves like this are rapids.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab reading of each kanji: 滝 and 川. Careful of the rendaku.

sentences: 祖母に、滝川を泳ぐのは危険だと言われました。
My grandma told me that it is very dangerous to swim in the rapids.

mnemonics.meaning: The previous approximate was the previous approximate time, which is recently or the other day.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of the two kanji. That's 先 and 頃 (the reading you learned) put together. The 頃 is the rendaku'd version, ごろ so be careful.

sentences: つい先頃までとても仲良くしてたのに、彼が急によそよそしくなったんだけど、理由が全然分からないの。
We’d been good friends until just recently, but he suddenly grew really cold toward me. I don’t understand why.

mnemonics.meaning: This (この) approximate is this approximate time. It is recently or nowadays or these days.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the 頃 reading from the kanji reading. Be careful, it's the rendaku'd form.

sentences: この頃、風味を出すために砕いたヘーゼルナッツを珈琲に加えてるんです。
These days I’ve been adding chopped hazelnuts to my coffee for added flavor.

mnemonics.meaning: A stiff fix is when you fix something to be stiff, which leads to rigidity, stiffness, or stiffening. This word feels pretty formal when used as a noun. You can also add している or した to mean "rigid," but it doesn't mean that on its own.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 心理的硬直は問題を解決する妨げになると思われる。
I believe that psychological rigidity can hinder problem solving.
社会の硬直化は解決しなければならない問題です。
The rigidity of society is a problem that we need to fix.
死後どのぐらいで死後硬直が起きるんでしょうか。
I wonder how long after death rigor mortis sets in.

mnemonics.meaning: The origin villain is the villain who's running everything. They're the person responsible for the villainy going on. They are the ringleader or main culprit.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 人類の半分を一掃した凶悪なウィルスの元凶は、ウォッカのつまった西瓜だった。
The source of the terrible virus that wiped out half of mankind was a vodka-filled watermelon.

mnemonics.meaning: A leg book is just the legs of a book. Not a whole book. It only contains the parts that walk around and move, not so much the descriptions (things that don't move). This kind of book is a script or screenplay. These "books" are focused on actions and things people say, which is why it's just the legs.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 他の脚本では出来なかった事を、彼の脚本はやってのけたんだよ。
What the other scripts weren’t able to do, his script did.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Also means shadow.
mnemonics.reading: Look at a shadow. It's long, surprisingly long. It's in the shape of a cage (かげ), because that's what is producing the long shadow. Check out each bar of the cage. Maybe you're inside the cage? Whatever is going on, a long shadow is being created by the cage and shade.

sentences: 陰でこそこそ私の陰口言うの、止めてくれない？言いたいことがあるなら、はっきり言ってよ！
Can’t you stop making fun of me behind my back? If you have something to say, say it to my face.

mnemonics.meaning: A 距離 is a distance and 近 is near. A near distance is a short distance.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: タクシーの運ちゃんは大体みんな近距離乗車は嫌がるよね。
Taxi drivers generally dislike short distant trips, don’t they?

mnemonics.meaning: A 距離 (distance) that is short is a short distance.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ほんの数年後、彼女はようやく自分がその短距離走で優勝した短距離走者だったことを認めました。
Only years later did she finally admit she was the sprinter who won the short distance race.

mnemonics.meaning: 一斉 is simultaneous or all at once. Add the に in there and you're heading towards those things. For "simultaneous" that becomes simultaneously. For "all at once" it stays at all at once.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 一斉.

sentences: 派遣社員たちは、景気の悪化で一斉に解雇されることを心配しています。
The temporary workers are worried about being fired simultaneously in the recession.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Look inside your soul. You see all the bits and bobs that make up your soul rolling around and around, being pushed by the Katamari Tamashii (たましい). He keeps your soul nice and big and safe!

sentences: 小さな天使とベーコンのビデオを観て、魂が震えました。
The video about the little angel and the bacon deeply moved my soul.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The person who's holding the spear is a little hoe 子. It's a child who learned to fight with a hoe, and he's turned the hoe into a spear to fight with. Imagine him swinging his hoe spear around like a little dork.

sentences: この美しい矛は、白金とプラチナで作られています。
This beautiful spear is made from white gold and platinum.

mnemonics.meaning: When attached to a word, this refers to a ____ spirit. It's  the same meaning as the kanji, too.
mnemonics.reading: This word is made up of a single kanji, but it uses the on'yomi reading, not the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, you've learned this reading already. Yay!

sentences: 死者の霊魂に捧げる為のイラストを描いてほしいとアヤに頼みました。
I asked Aya to draw an illustration to offer to the souls of the dead.

mnemonics.meaning: If you kill bacteria you are performing sterilization. You're killing those bacteria.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening.

sentences: トイレを殺菌する一番いい方法は何ですか？
What’s the best way to sterilize a bathroom?

mnemonics.meaning: Someplace with nothing amounts of bacteria is sterilized.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: トーフグのステッカーが無菌かどうかの問い合わせのメールが来たんだけど。
I just got an email asking whether or not the Tofugu stickers are sterilized.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of stiff? It's stiff, hard, or firm.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as a very similar word, 固い. So, if you can use that word to help you to remember, you'll remember the reading of this word in no time as well!

sentences: 彼の筋肉は、岩のように硬い。
His muscles are as firm as rock.
新人モデルは、緊張で表情が少し硬くなっていた。
The new model's expression was a little stiff with nervousness.
ダイヤモンドよりも硬い石があることは、ご存知ですか？
Did you know that there are stones that are harder than diamonds?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 麻雀するなら、うちに雀卓があるけど。
There is a Mahjong table in my house if you want to play.

mnemonics.meaning: Table sphere is a sport where you have a table and then you use a sphere on it. That's table tennis or ping pong. Makes sense, right? You use a ping pong ball and you play on a table.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of たく's shortening.
