sentences: あの卓球の音のせいで気が変になりそうだ！
That ping pong noise is driving me crazy!

mnemonics.meaning: The skin touch is  the feeling of touching with your skin. That is the touch of, feel of, or texture of something. It's what you feel when you touch your skin to something!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 肌 plus 触る's reading, combined. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: このタオルはとても柔らかくて心地よい肌触りです。
This towel is very soft and pleasant to the touch.

mnemonics.meaning: The tide time is the tidal hour.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the individual words, 潮 and 時. Watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 今こそタバコをやめる潮時だ。今すぐニコチンパッチを買いに行くんだ。
It’s high time that you quit smoking. Go get some nicotine patches right now.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 襲撃 is an assault or attack? This is the verb form, so it's to attack or to assault.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 飛行機で巨人を襲撃することができるようになるとは、知る由もなかった。
Little did they know they would be able to attack titans by air.

mnemonics.meaning: Something with lucidity is clear. That's why this word is to become clear or to become transparent.
mnemonics.reading: You learned this reading when you learned the kanji.

sentences: 池の水、昨日は濁って緑色だったのに、今はすっかり澄んでいるじゃないか。一体何があったの？
The water in the pond was green yesterday, but it’s totally cleared up now. What happened?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means exhausted and the verb version means to become exhausted, to become tired or to get tired. Don't confuse this with "to be sleepy." No, this is a different kind of tired, like a physical or mental one, like you just worked out or studied a ton.
mnemonics.reading: For example, if you tried to lift two cars (つか) you'd become exhausted for sure. So, think about that as you learn this word's reading.

sentences: トイレが詰まって、すっぽんで詰まり抜きをする前に水が溢れちゃって、朝早くから掃除をしなくちゃいけなかったから、とっても疲れました。
The toilet was clogged and it flooded before we used the plunger, so I had to clean it up early in the morning and I’m really exhausted.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means damp so the verb vocab version is to be damp or to be moist. Ewww.
mnemonics.reading: You have to think of something that's damp and moist. To do that, think of He-Man's girlfriend, She-Man (しめ). She has been hanging out in a greenhouse and is now kind of damp. He-Man hands her a towel to dry off.

sentences: 昨日の夜、寝汗をたくさんかいちゃったから、ベットが何だか湿ってるのよね。
I sweat a lot when I was sleeping last night and my bed is a little damp.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means destroy so the verb vocab version is to be destroyed. You know you're not destroying things because of the beer (びる). You'd never destroy beer... but someone else might. Grrr.
mnemonics.reading: "THE HORROR!" (ほろ) you cry, as your beer is about to be destroyed.

sentences: 地球がじきに滅びるんだとしたら、どうしてベーコンを食べるのを我慢しなくちゃいけないの？
If the earth is going to be destroyed, why should I resist eating bacon?

mnemonics.meaning: This is a bit of a weird word. The kanji is char, and a previous word you learned (焦げる) is "to be burned." This, on the other hand, is "to be in a hurry" or "to be impatient." I guess if you're getting burned or have that feeling, you're going to be in a hurry and you're going to be impatient. You can tell that this is that word because it only has one kana, る, which stands for rude. You're feeling someone is being rude (or maybe you are), which is why you have this feeling of impatience and hurrying.
mnemonics.reading: You're being rude, but you're also being a big ass (あせ) with your impatience.

sentences: 焦るなよ。小便に行きたい以外は、急ぐ必要はないよ。一日一日を着実にな。
Take your time. Other than needing to pee, there is no rush. One day at a time.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means curse, and the verb version is to curse or to put a curse on.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 夫が心的外傷後ストレス障害と診断された後、私はそれが誰であれその戦争を始めた人を呪いました。
After my husband was diagnosed with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder I cursed whoever it was that started the war.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means earnings and the verb vocab version is to earn income, because you can't "to income" something. Can also be to make money.
mnemonics.reading: You earn your income, and every time you're paid, you're given your money in a briefcase (かせ). Imagine getting your income from a briefcase, opening it up, and grabbing the money from within. Then, you have to give the briefcase back at the specified dropoff.

sentences: 現職の大統領が、前大統領よりもどれだけ多くのお金を稼いでいるか知っているかい？
Do you know how much more money the incumbent president earns than the former president?

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means fly, so the verb version means to fly.
mnemonics.reading: You learned this reading already! You should be able to read this too!

sentences: それは、まるで天空を高く翔る不死鳥のようでした。
It looked just like a phoenix soaring high in the air.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means gamble and the verb vocab version is to gamble.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 彼女は競馬で、中々の大金を賭けるんだよ。
She gambles considerable amounts of money at the horse races.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cloudy and the verb vocab version means to get cloudy or to become cloudy.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. It also happens to be the same as 雲, which has a very similar meaning (clouds).

sentences: ラーメンの湯気で眼鏡が曇っちゃうのが好きじゃないんだよね。
I don’t like it when my glasses get cloudy from ramen steam.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lunatic or crazy. The verb version of this is to go mad (you don't really "go lunatic" now, do you?) or to go crazy.
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading, just think about how when you go crazy, you are coming (来る) to crazy town. Just imagine some voice beckoning you to come. Come here! Please come here! Come to crazy town! Give in to the voices!

sentences: 「サーモン、今週末、ラスベガスで結婚しよう。」「フグ、気でも狂ったの？」
"Salmon, let’s get married in Las Vegas this weekend." "Fugu, have you lost your mind?"

meanings: to let someone stay the night

mnemonics.meaning: 泊まる is "to stay the night." Now you're letting someone else stay the night, which makes this to let someone stay over or to let someone stay the night.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 泊まる.

sentences: うちに知らない人を泊めるのは嫌です。
I don’t want to have some stranger stay at our house.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bride and the verb vocab version is to marry, because you can't really "to bride" someone.
mnemonics.reading: Imagine you're getting married to a valley girl. You're all like. Hey, I'm gonna marry you! And she's all like Tots (とつ), we gonna get, like, married! Imagine her saying more "tots" things (tots = short for totally in valley girl speak, at least in my imagination).

sentences: 嫁ぎたての頃は、息子の嫁はかまととぶっていました。
Around the time they got married, my son’s wife pretended she was a prude.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means polish and the verb vocab version is to polish or, strangely specifically (and we'll learn an even more specific word for this later) to brush your teeth.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 何で切れた電球なんか磨いてるの？
Why are you polishing a light bulb that’s already burnt out?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means grate and this verb means to rub or to scrub. It will help to think back to 擦れる which means "to chafe" or "to rub," which is more similar to this verb than the kanji meaning is.
mnemonics.reading: This kanji shares the reading from 擦れる but it also has another reading, こする. Both are considered "common." Most likely, you'll use する's reading the most because it is the same as すれる's reading, but for now try to keep the other one in your mind as well.

sentences: 花粉症で目を擦ってたら、片方のコンタクトレンズが破けました。
I was rubbing my eyes because of my allergies and one of my contact lenses was torn.

mnemonics.meaning: Everything we're doing is to serve you, you know. This verb is a bit archaic and therefore has a formal feel to it. It's used to talk about serving emperors, kings, and gods, among others.
mnemonics.reading: To serve you well, we've gotten ourselves two cars (つか). If one breaks down, we can still serve you with the other car.

sentences: この家に仕える使用人は、とても礼儀が正しい。
The servants who serve in this house are very polite.
その女性は、明治天皇に仕えていた女官のようです。
The woman seemed to be a female official in the service of the Meiji Emperor.
はじめまして。今日から神に仕えることになった天使です。
Nice to meet you. I'm an angel who started serving God today.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stare and the verb vocab version is to stare at (or to look at in a very staringish way).
mnemonics.reading: To learn the reading, just think about how you're looking at something for a lonnnnng time if you're staring at it. In Japanese the word "long" is 長い, and guess what the reading of the kanji part is? It's なが, just like ながめる's kanji-part reading.

sentences: うちの甥っ子は新幹線を見るのが好きで、一日中眺めていることもできます。
My nephew likes watching the Shinkansen so much that he can stare at it all day long.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 裂く is "to tear" or "to rip up." So, if you're trying to tear or rip up something, and you're pulling it at the same time, you are going to tear up that thing, or more accurately perhaps to tear off something, since you're pulling.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 引く and 裂く.

sentences: あのカップルの仲をうまく引き裂く事ができたら、お知らせ致します。
I’ll let you know if I succeed in splitting up the couple.

mnemonics.meaning: As usual, you can guess this is a verb thanks to the う sound on the end. The kanji means frustration, and unfortunately frustration tends to torment people. This verb is pretty advanced, but still useful to know!
mnemonics.reading: We all know it's not okay to to torment each other. So how about we all sign a (さいな) contract saying that we'll never torment anyone ever again?

sentences: 無力感に苛まれてるんよ。
I'm tormented by feelings of helplessness.
うだるような暑さが私達を苛む。
The sweltering heat torments us.
被害者はまた何か悪いことが起こるのではないかという不安に苛まれていました。
The victims were tormented by the anxiety that something else bad would happen.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 一位のチームには、賞品として滝修行が授与されます。
The top team will be awarded with a prize of doing aesthetic waterfall meditation.

mnemonics.meaning: A well door is just a well. It's the door that goes into the well hole, making it a well.
mnemonics.reading: This kanji uses the kun'yomi readings for each kanji, for some reason. You learned the kun'yomi reading for 戸, but in this case it's rendaku'd so it becomes ど instead of と. You didn't learn the kun'yomi version of 井 with the kanji. Think of this well, and look inside. There you see an eagle (い), stuck inside. As you pull it out, it scratches your eyes out.

sentences: よく冷えた井戸水を飲むと、冷たいアイスクリームを食べた時のように頭がキーンと痛みました。
When I drank cold water from the well, I got brain freeze like when I ate cold ice cream.

mnemonics.meaning: The damp earth is where water seems to congregate, but not so much that there's a lake or ocean or anything like that. Just damp. This is a wetlands.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 確か、北海道には湿地が多いんだよね？
If I am not mistaken, there are a lot of wetlands in Hokkaido, right?

mnemonics.meaning: A 包み is a bundle or package, and 紙 is paper. What paper goes around bundles and packages? That would be wrapping paper.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 包み and 紙 combined together. Be careful of rendaku.

sentences: この包み紙には点字が施してあるわ。
There is braille on this wrapping paper.
